Dealers attributed the decline yesterday to the gold sale planned in September by the International Monetary Fund.

BORDENTOWN, Aug. 22 A woman confined to a wheelchair today began preparing an in-depth report that will outline the needs of the handicapped and recommend legislation and other governmental action that could help ease the plight of New Jersey's physically and mentally disabled.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 (AP) San Francisco's 1,800 transit workers voted tonight to acecpt a wage and fringe benefit offer, thereby averting a threatened strike that could have shut down other city services as well.

TORONTO, Aug. 22 (UPI) Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina defeated Jaime Fillol, of Chile, who played unaware of a death threat against him, and Wojtek Fibak of Poland beat Brian Fairlie of New Zealand today in the semifinals of the $155,000 Canadian open tennis championships.
The city was a cauldron yesterday as the 94-degree temperature brushed a record set 60 years ago.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) Stewart Shane of Havre de Grace, Md., defeated Jack Van Denman of Oceanport, N.J., by two feet today in the Governor's Cup invitation race of the 37th annual East Pointe national sweepstakes regatta.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 There is a construction worker here who drew $104 a week in state unemployment benefits while building his own home and regularly turning down jobs to work at his trade.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 This city's mounting attention to street crimes was diverted by reports that several top officials of the Detroit Police Department were under investigation by Federal law enforcement authorities for possible involvement in narcotics payoffs.

The rally in the money and bond markets that began in July ended last week, and most fixed-income security prices floated downward in quiet trading from Tuesday through Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Senator Robert J. Dole conceded today that he felt he had been chosen as the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee not to broaden President Ford's base of support among voters but to try to "bridge the gap between those who were strongly for Ford and those who felt strongly about Reagan."

PARIS, Aug. 22 The French Government has vetoed the sale to an American company of one of the best vineyards in the land, Chateau Margaux.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 22 Rik Massengale, a taciturn Texan whose speech is as slow as his walk, surveyed what his closest opposition was doing today and responded with five birdies on the back nine, two of them on the final holes, to win the Greater Hartford open.
MADRID, Aug. 22 The fatal shooting of an 18-year-old leftist by the Civil Guard has dramatized a problem worrying many Spaniards: how to control what the people here call "the forces of order."

DALLAS, Aug. 22 (AP) The Dallas School District will open the new school year tomorrow with an extensive desegregation plan that was produced by a private volunteer group and that educators hope will be a model for the nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 In a new set of guidelines on the use of X-ray techniques in the detection of breast cancer, the National Cancer Institute will recommend this week that the X-rays not be used routinely on women between the ages of 35 and 50 unless they show specific symptoms or are otherwise classified as "high risk."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Gloria Swanson has agreed to pay 35 cents on the dollar to settle a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over alleged discrimination against single taxpayers, David R. Shelton, a tax lawyer and longtime friend of the actress, said today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (UPI) --Nine days before the start of school, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit approved today the same courtordered busing desegregation plan for the schools in Louisville, Ky., and suburbs that set off violence there a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) --The 35 largest cities in the United States use at least 14 different scales for measuring air pollution, so a Federal panel today offered a single new index for the nation.

George Foreman, former heavyweight boxing champion, will fight the undefeated New England champion, Dino Dennis, in a 10-round bout in Miami Beach on Sept. 17. Don King, the promoter, announced here last night.
MARANELLO, Italy, Aug. 23 (AP)--The Italian Ferrari racing factory decided today to resume participation in Formula One championship races, reversing an Aug. 5 decision to stay out through the year.

YONKERS, Aug. 23--Representative Bella Abzug's day of campaigning for the Democratic Senate nomination began this morning with taping a radio program in Westchester County, during which she told interviewers she was running for the Senate because "the voters deserve the best."

Olu Dara, the trumpeter, and Phillip Wilson, the drummer, performed as a duo at the Tin Palace on Sunday, and although the spare instrumentation did not seem to hold much promise, the music was remarkable.

Long stretches of Union Turnpike in Queens, Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn and Eastchester Road in the Bronx are among the major resurfacing and rehabilitation projects in its current program, the New York City Highways Department said yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)--Dr. James Olds, a behavioral biologist credited with the discovery of "pleasure centers" in the brains of rats, died accidentally on Saturday while swimming in the ocean on a vacation at Laguna Beach. He was 54 years old.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 23 (UPI) --Australia's Bicentennial gift to the United States, six koala bears, have required the planting of 30,000 eucalyptus trees at the San Diego Zoo to provide a continuing supply of food.

NOVO HAMBURGO, Brazil, Aug. 18--Ten years ago, a local shoe manufacturer, Claudio Strassburger, took a suitcase of samples to New York in a quixotic attempt to convince United States shoe salesmen of the Merits of Brazilian footwear.
Steve Davis, the prodigal halfback, returned yesterday to the Jets' training camp, admitted he made a "mistake" when he went AWOL on July 20 and was welcomed back by Coach Lou Holtz.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- The House voted tonight to ban within three years the manufacture of PCB's, a class of chemical that has been linked to cancer and birth defects, water pollution and the contamination of wildlife.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- The televised debates between President Ford and Jimmy Carter, as planned by the League of Women Voters, may be illegal under the new campaign law.
A new X-ray machine that will be marketed soon may greatly reduce the amount of radiation used in detecting breast cancer. The Associated Press reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) --The 35 largest cities in the United States use at least 14 different scales for measuring air pollution, so a Federal panel today offered a single new index for the nation.

Clyde J. Wingfield, 45 years old, president of Baruch College since 1971, is going to the University of Miami Nov. 1 as provost and executive vice president for academic affairs. His resignation is the first among presidents of the City University's nine senior colleges since the full onset of the university's financial crisis.

"I can't believe I said those things about my father." The statement is attributed to a crying Patricia Hearst, the kidnapping victim turned fugitive who in taped messages during her flight is believed to have called her father "Adolph," a "corporate liar" and a "pig."

THE HAGUE, Aug. 23 (Reuters)--Peter Custers, a Dutch freelance journalist and development aid worker detained by the Bangladesh authorities since last December, was due to be tried by a special martial law tribunal in Dacca today, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

CAIRO, Aug. 23--An Egyptian airliner with more than 100 people aboard was seized by Arab guerrillas this morning shortly after takeoff from Cairo but was recaptured by Government commandos this afternoon at an airport in southern Egypt.

For the third time in four seasons, Joseph Papp has changed the theatrical policy at Lincoln Center. This time he has decided to reduce by halt his 1976-77 series of plays at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.
WASHINGTON, Aug 23 (UPI) --The Senate by a vote of 75 to 0, today ratified an international coffee agreement and extended through 1978 a treaty governing foreign wheat sales.

A young New York couple walked into Bonwit Teller recently, took one look at the store and walked out to find out if they were in the right place. To their shocked eyes, it looked more like a subway stop than a Fifth Avenue store.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 23-- Young black demonstrators in the black township of Soweto stoned buses and trains today as they attempted to force compliance with a three-day national strike among black workers on whom the economy of white-ruled South Africa depends. Police shot and killed one black youth and wounded at least six others.

ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 23-- Most of the inmates at Attica prison refused to leave their cells today, in a peaceful protest against conditions and to press for negotiations with the state on a list of nine demands.

It pays to advertise. Because of advertisements in two Sunday newspapers that cost $26,000, Mike Burke, the president of Madison Square Garden and the Knicks; Eddie Donovan, the Knicks' general manager, and John Ferguson, the Rangers general manager, and coach, spent hours yesterday talking by telephone with prospective seasonticket holders.
Walter Krinsky, president of the Neil A. Walters Realty Corporation in Mineola, L.I., died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Woodmere, L.I. He was 51 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Secretary of the Army Martin R. Hoffmann intervened today in the West Point cheating scandal by offering guilty cadets who have been ousted the chance to reapply for admission after a one-year period of "reflection," preferably on active service as enlisted men.
BUDAPEST, Aug. 23 (AP)-- Jeno Kenessey, composer, has died at the age of 71, the official Hungarian press agency reported today.

William J. Murphy, president of J.L. Murphy Inc. and a leader of many groups in the plumbing, heating and ventilating industries, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 68 years ald and lived at 933 Fifth Avenue.

YONKERS, Aug 23--A provisional elementary school is being set up by white parents who have refused to allow their children to be transfered from their closed neighborhood school to another about two miles away.

Private customers of the Consolidated Edison Company will see a new cost added to their electricity bills in the fall when the City of New York and other public entities drop out as Con Edison customers and begin to buy their power from state sources.
TORONTO, Aug. 23 (UPI)-- Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina captured his second Canadian open tennis title tonight, beating Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 6-4, 7-5, 6-2.
VIENNA, Aug. 23 (Reuters)-- Experts from oil-exporting countries today began a week of studies here that could bring the world closer to a new rise in oil prices.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP)-- Some 300 General Motors dealers in New Jersey, charging the state has too many G.M. car outlets, have threatened to call for a Congressional investigation unless the company agrees to restructure its franchise network.
A 23-year-old member of the Unification Church plunged to his death early yesterday from the 22d floor of the New Yorker Hotel.
With most new purchasers of color television sets today already owners of one, how does a manufacturer advertise to reach this market?
Prices Improved slightly yesterday in quiet trading in the Government and corporate bond markets. The tax-exempt market was unchanged in equally quiet trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 23--The current session of the slow-moving Law of the Sea Conference is threatening to founder over the issue of ocean-floor mining.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 23 --Just about anything floating in the harbor here today --old tires, beer cans a piece of driftwood--looked like a shark fin.

VAIL Colo., Aug. 23--President Ford's election campaign strategy, which aides have said calls for him to underline his incumbency through high-visibility White House activities, evidently will have to wait until next week to commence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23-- Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

In a victory for the Beame administration, a State Supreme Court justice yesterday declared invalid the controversial Stavisky-Goodman Law, which was designed to require an increase in education spending in New York City by as much as $150 million.

Having lost three straight games to the California Angels over the weekend, the Yankees took revenge on the Minnesota Twins last night at Yankee Stadium. They pounded 17 hits, equaling their season's high in that department, to post a 9-4 victory before a crowd of 17,558.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)--A Viking 1 instrument looking for organic material on Mars found nothing in a second test that would indicate life forms had been there in the past, a project biologist said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22-- The Ford Administration is engaged in protracted and intricate negotiations with more than a dozen nations to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. At the same time, critics of these efforts have become more vocal, charging that the Administration's nonproliferation diplomacy is too little and too late.

PAGAN, Burma--With painful slowness, while monsoon torrents continually wash away mortar, exposing ancient temples to the danger of collapse and threatening to crumble irreplaceable wall paintings 800 years old, Burma is setting about the repair of its unique royal city of Pagan.

One of the country's top women players led a team of young experts to victory in the summer Swiss team championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday night.

A memorial service for Samuel L. Brookfield, senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Webster, Sheffield, Fleischmann, Hitchcock and Brookfield, was held yesterday at Christ's Church in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Wendell Phillips, rector, and Episcopal Bishop J. Stuart Wetmore officiated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--The State Department softened its reaction today and said that the message received from President Kim II Sung of North Korea expressing regrets about last week's incident in the demilitarized zone was "a positive step"

A New York City employee picked the wrong time and parked his car in an area reserved for vehicles of the city's Investigation Department. It resulted in the arrest of the 26year-old employee and another man on charges of illegal possession of four pounds of marijuana.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--A delegation of black Americans urged Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today to "communicate to South Africa in the strongest terms" America's opposition to the racial policies that have led to several weeks of rioting and more than 250 deaths.
Dr. John D. Pinto, chief of staff of the Westerly (R.I) Hospital, died there Saturday of cancer. He was 55 veers old.

NEWARK, Aug. 23--Telephone rate increases and new "directory assistance" call charges were recommended today for New Jersey Bell Telephone by two hearing examiners of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioner, who also proposed a special discount rate for the poor and the elderly.

Alfred Jaretzki Jr., a retired partner in the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell and an expert on investment companies, died Saturday in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 895 Park Avenue.

Prices of gold bullion were sent to their lowest levels in 32 months yesterday by dispirited traders on both sides of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Serious crime is increasing at a faster rate in rural America and the smaller towns than it is in the big cities, according to Federal Bureau of Investigation that found an overall oneyear increase of 10 percent. The report was issued today.

NEWPORT, R.I. Some years ago, so the story goes, Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, was having tea with Mrs. Katherine Warren, founder of the Preservation Society of Newport County. Miss Duke was interested in doing some preservation work of her own, but she was concerned about overlapping with the existing organization. Finally, she turned to Mrs. Warren and said, "All right, Katherine, you take the 19th century and I'll take the 18th."

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 24 Representative Allan T. Howe was found guilty today in his second trial on charges of soliciting sex acts for hire from two Salt Lake police decoys. WAD MEDANI, the Sudan, Aug. 18 Omer Abdel Sid farms 13 acres of cotton, with a little peanuts and sorghum on the side. Last year he made $2,000 17 times more than the average Sudanese so he has no complaints.

The death in an auto crash of Brazil's Juscelino Kubitschek de Oliveira at 73 removes from the Latin American scene not only one of the more colorful political figures of recent times but a man of formidable accomplishments. ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed today a federally ordered plan for resegregating the Omaha school system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The State Department said today that the latest move by South Africa to grant South-West Africa independence by the end of 1978 was "a step in the right direction," but that it did not go far enough to meet American and United Nations demands.
CAIRO, Aug. 24 Libya and Egypt today accused each other of having planned the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner yesterday by three Arab gunmen.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 Three Americans pleaded guilty in a Moscow court today to heroin smuggling in an incident marking the latest phase of a Soviet crackdown on narcotics traffickers who have been using Moscow as a transit point from Asia to Western Europe.

James V. Napoli Sr., long identified as a leading underworld figure, and eight confederates were convicted yesterday of operating a $35-milliona-year policy and horse race gambling operations reportedly one of the largest in the nation.

Borden Inc., the nation's 57th largest national advertiser, will spend around $50 million for advertising in 1976. But this year's total will include a project that it has never attempted before and that surpasses previous efforts of this kind.
DETROIT I am outraged, and so is everyone I know. The city is in desperate condition. It may, in a real sense, be dead the first dead large city in the nation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (UPI) The chairman of the American Independent Party said today that he thought Lester G. Maddox would have a chance to beat Jimmy Carter in Mississippi, Louisiana and Tennessee if he entered the Presidential race.

LONDON, Aug. 24 Prime Minister James Callaghan called an emergency Cabinet meeting today as the country's worst drought on record threatened to disrupt the economy. There were predictions that workers in some industries faced layoffs or a three-day work week.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 24 Nobody's suggested wooden nickels, but short of that almost anything is fair game for studies of the size, shape and denomination of the currency of the future.
OTTAWA, Aug. 24 Canadian bankers have cautiously welcomed the Government's proposed revisions to the Bank Act, which will increase both competition and controls in the industry here.

Sons traditionally go into their fathers' businesses, although it often entails strong urging on Dad's part. But now so many daughters are asking, even coaxing, to join their fathers that John A. Smith Daughter may become no more unusual than John A. Smith Son.

VAIL, Colo., Aug. 24 President Ford, seeking a tactical advantage in the first Presidential campaign debates since 1960, proposed today that Jimmy Carter agree to begin their face-to-face confrontation in about two weeks.

SEATTLE, Aug. 24 Jimmy Carter was vigorously booed by hundreds of American Legion members here today after he told them he would issue a pardon to Vietnam War draft resisters if he should become President.
WEST HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 24 (AP) Conrail has postponed a closed hearing into a July 13 train crash that killed two persons.
A suit filed against Ohio by the Thrall Manufacturing Company is one of the first attempts by a company to challenge the validity of state laws that seek to control mergers and acquisitions.

Ramsey Clark, insisting that lasting peace will never come to the Middle East while the population of most Arab countries are impoverished and illiterate, yesterday proposed the creation of a Mideast Development Authority to which the United States would contribute up to $2 billion a year, mainly to improve life in the poorest Arab nations.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. At the seaside Marine Biological Laboratory here, one of the world's leading centers for the study of creatures from the oceans, five scientists are focusing their research on elephants.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 The city commissioners rejected today the recall movement against Mayor Frank L. Rizzo on grounds that more than half of the 211,000 petition signatures gathered against him were invalid.
BONN, Aug. 24 Theo and Agnes Rohl, both 35 years old and in perfect health, are childless. They work, take frequent vacations and are used to living well.
Maj. Gen. Charles M. Duke, retired, who served as division engineer of the Army Corps of Engineers for the North Atlantic Division, died Saturday in a Fairfax, Va., nursing home. He was 59 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Nobody's suggested wooden nickels,. but short of that almost anything is fair game for studies of the size, shape and denomination of the currency of the future.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's second largest tire producer, reported yesterday that earnings for the quarter ended July 31 plunged 38.9 percent under the impact of a 126-day strike at nine domestic tire plants.

Incidents involving the operation of citizens band radios have resulted in the jailing of two upstate men, one on a charge of manslaughter, the other of allegedly using "racial slurs and vulgar, obscene language."
Tony Oliva, a grand old member of the major leagues, treated the Yankees to a bit of nostalgia last night, but the Yankees preferred the treat that Willie Randolph, a major league newcomer, provided.

CALCUTTA, India After 14 months of emergency rule and the suspension of most civil liberties, India's intellectual community appears demoralized and in disarray. Its mood ranges from acceptance of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's exercise of authoritarian power to total rejection, albeit in most cases whispered.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 24 Federal election records on file here show that Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican VicePresidential nominee, accepted as a 1974 campaign contribution the cost of anti-abortion advertisements that he said last Sunday he had disavowed.

MANILA, Aug. 24 (UPI) President Ferdinand E. Marcos today rejected an American offer of aid for the victims of last week's earthquake and tidal-wave disaster in the southern Philippines.

Abraham Hirschfeld called yesterday for repeal of the section of the New York State Banking Code that permits savings and commercial banks to invest some of their deposits in mortgages out of the State.
VAIL, Colo., Aug. 24 Vincent L. Broderick, a Democrat who was the New York City Commissioner of Police a decade ago, was nominated today for the Federal bench by President Ford.
The outspoken Oakland A's have been saying all along that the Kansas City Royals would fold under the pressure of the division race in the American League's Western Division.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP) Two Soviet astronauts returned safely to earth today after spending nearly two months aboard the orbiting Salyut 5 space station, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported. Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market finished lower yesterday in moderate trading.

At one community college in Michigan, student chefs prepare a gourmet meal that they offer in the cafeteria for just 50 cents more than the regular lunch price.

Coopers Lybrand and Arthur Young Company, two major accounting firms, filed court briefs yesterday siding with the Securities and Exchange Commission in its dispute with Arthur Andersen Company, a third big auditing firm, over how accounting rules should be written.

Gearhart-Owen Industries, an oil services company in Fort Worth, will become the second company to retain its Amex listing when it lists its stock on the New York Stock Exchange in the near future, the American Stock Exchange said yesterday. Varo Inc., of Garland, Tex., became the first dually listed stock last Monday.
Fire Department and hospital officials are investigating a "suspicious" fire that caused $100,000 worth of damage Monday night at the new Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 24 Youth had its fling in the $60,000 Tennis Week open today, but experience called the final shots as Dick Stockton and Dr. Renee Richards posted victories over a pair of promising teen-agers, Billy Martin and Caroline Stoll, at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
SEATTLE, Aug. 24 (AP) The city's American League baseball expansion franchise got a name today the Seattle Mariners.

JERSEY CITY, Aug, 24 The New Jersey Department of the Public Advocate, the consumer's special-interest representative in the state government, today supported lower utility rates for the poor and the elderly but contended that such a program should be combined with incentives for energy conservation.

Stock prices dropped sharply, yesterday in moderate trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average off 8.56 points to 962.93, its low for the session.

A Department of Agriculture proposal to redefine the word "meat" to include pure fat and a mixture of crushed bone and bits of flesh was condemned yesterday by a consumer group as an attempt to adulterate the food supply in order to enrich the meat industry.

TOKYO, Aug. 24 More than two-thirds of the parliamentary members of the governing Liberal-Democratic Party met today and unanimously called in effect for the ouster of their own party leader, Prime Minister Takeo Miki.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The International Monetary Fund announced today that it would proceed on schedule with its next auction of 780,000 ounces of gold Sept. 15, but with a different auction technique.

TRENTON, Aug. 24 The total number of building permits issued for new residential units in New Jersey rose slightly between May and June following two months of decreases, according to Joseph A. Hoffman of the Department of Labor and Industry.

The two private companies that maintain New York City's street lights have been penalized a total of $738,000 by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin after an audit found that they were not making timely replacements of burned-out and broken lights and were tardy in other repair work.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 (UPI) Israel today issued rare praise for Egypt and the "courageous" Egyptian commando raid that freed passengers from a hijacked jet in Luxor yesterday.

The tax-exempt credit market, facing an estimated $1.6 billion in new financings in the next 30 days, moved slowly yesterday on several new offerings.

Forty New York labor leaders set up a committee yesterday to show the amount of union support that Representative Bella S. Abzug had already obtained for her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate and to promote her cause among union members.

Nearly a third of the employees of the New York City Housing Authority's elevator repair division were accused yesterday of cheating the city out of more than $1 million. a year in fraudulent overtime claims.

Carol Channing is scheduled to open on Broadway in mid-January in "The Bed Before Yesterday," one of three hits that the 90-year-old playwright Ben Travers now has running in London.
The National Golf Foundation, in an effort to promote the sport of golf, will begin a pilot program this fall to introduce the game to high school students.

NEWPORT, R.I. Some years ago, so the story goes, Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, was having tea with Katherine Warren, founder of the Preservation Society of Newport County. Miss Duke was interested in doing some preservation work of her own, but she was concerned about overlapping with the existing organization. Finally, she turned to Mrs. Warren and said, "All right, Katherine, you take the 19th century and I'll take the 18th."
Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday a net income for July of $17.9 million, or 23 cents a share, against $19.2 million, or 31 cents a share, earned in the year earlier month.
Margaret F. Josten, a former opera singer, and collector of Impressionist paintings, died in her apartment at 944 Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Josten was 88 years old.

Janet Hart yesterday was named director of the Office of Saver and Consumer Affairs of the Federal Reserve Board. She is the first woman ever appointed head of a division at the Federal Reserve.

About half of 2,163 institutions of higher learning examined in a new economic analysis of the nation's colleges and universities have been found to be in poor financial condition, according to a survey conducted for the magazine Change, a higher-education monthly.

Mieczyslaw Munz, a former concert pianist who appeared with many of the world's leading orchestras, died yesterday of a heart attack in an ambulance as he was being taken to a hospital from his home at the Ten Park Avenue Hotel. He was 75 years old.

"The New Man" at the No Smoking Playhouse (17 West 24th Street) is a cooperative venture. Everyone in the company helps building scenery, painting walls, selling tickets and everyone shares in the box-office income.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 20 A fisherman standing on the bank of the Blue Nile, just across from the Sudan Hotel, pulled out a 10-foot-long snake the other day. No one in the crowd that quickly gathered could identify it, but they all agreed it was poisonous. It was promptly thrashed to death.

Harrington has asked the House Banking Committee to hold hearings on the failure of the Emergency Loan Guarantee Board, set up to supervise Federally backed loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, to detect some $25 million in improper payments made by the company in recent years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 A year and a day after he pitched a no-hitter against them, Ed Halicki of the San Francisco Giants defeated the New York Mets in more routine fashion this afternoon, riding a six-run sixth inning to a 7-1 decision.

For 5 hours and 26 minutes, the Yankees and the Minnesota Twins played baseball last night and early today, and when they finished at 1:36 A.M., the Yankees had won, 5-4, on Mickey Rivers's two-out, runscoring single in the 19th inning.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 25 (AP) Talks are under way here on a new contract for 35,000 pier workers along the Atlantic Coast. The key issue is how to preserve jobs while the shipping industry adopts technology requiring less manpower.

Edward Raquello, a program officer for 26 years in the European field service of the United States Information Service until his retirement in 1968, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 130 East 93d Street and was 76 years old.

Thousands of demonstrators from France and neighboring countries clashed with police near Lyons last month while protesting the construction site chosen for France's Super-Phoenix, planned as the world's first large commercial fast breeder. A well-known former prisoner, Charles W. Colson, told the American Correctional Association yesterday that "uncertainty, helplessness and paranola" afflict the inmates of the nation's prisons. West Europe's lack of fossil fuel sources and its heavy dependence on Mideast oil led most countries there to step up plans for nuclear energy expansion even more than the United States in the wake of the 1973-74 oil embargo and five-fold oil price increase. But economic factors and public concern over safety, the environment and weapons proliferation now have led to a slowdown similar to that in the United States.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 25 Adopting what appeared to be an old American plan, North Korea today proposed a partition of the Panmunjom truce site as a way to avoid incidents like the one last week in which two United States Army, officers were killed by Communist guards.

YONKERS, Aug. 25 Board of Education members met with city officials last night to decide how to carry out an arbitrator's order to rehire 300 dismissed teachers and discovered to their dismay that they could not do it.

Mark (The Bird) Fidrych made his customary appearance in front of the Detroit Tigers dugout last night in Tiger Stadium after beating the Chicago White Sox, 3-1. The rookie right-hander held the White Sox to five hits, raised his won-lost record to 15-5, retired the last 13 batters in hurling his 18th complete game in 21 starts. The victory was Fidrych's 11th in Tiger Stadium in 14 decisions.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 25 (AP) Prime Minister Seni Pramoj took over the Defense Minister's post today after the resignation of Gen. Tawit Semiwong, who has been criticized for his handling of an exiled strongman's brief return.

You come out of this place into a Macdougal Street that seems quiet by comparison, which takes some doing on a Saturday night in Greenwich Village. Make that Sunday morning, at 2 A.M., with the Feenjon (a Turkish coffeepot) still percolating.

WASHINGTON The deepening resistance to Soviet dominance of the international Communist movement exposed this summer in the conference of European Communist parties challenges the anti-Communist basis of United States alliance policies. Rather than threatening to ostracize Western nations who allow Communists into their governments, we should be asking if the anti-Communist coalition also has begun to outlive its usefulness and needs to start giving way to a less aligned pattern of world politics.

In the days when college-bound women searched for a serious wardrobe to take to school with them, something plaid was as much a basic as something borrowed for the bride.

Chain store sales last month were up 8.4 percent from July 1975, according to a compilation made by Chain Store Age magazine. For the first seven months of the year, sales were 11.8 percent ahead of the corresponding period of 1975.

Thomas J. Flavell, a vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union and manager of its Local 169 here, died Friday in Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 1108 New Hyde Park Road, New Hyde Park, L.I.

Judges in New York State are sending more convicted felons to state prison, according to an analysis by the Division of Criminal Justice Services to be submitted today to Governor Carey and the Legislaure.

Mayor Beame and his budget aides received a kind word from an unexpected source yesterday when the Citizens Budget Commission said, in issuing its annual fiscal summary, that the city "appears to be in the process of transition to a more stable future."

The 18-nation International Energy Agency in Paris recently reported that the member country with virtually the worst record in conserving energy was the one that conceived the I.E.A. in 1974 to reduce the vulnerability of the industrial nations to another Arab oil embargo or price increase. MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (Reuters) Marshal Pyotr Koshevoi, who led an infantry division at the Battle of Stalingrad and, from 1965 to 1969, commanded Soviet Union forces in East Germany, died here today. He was 71 years old.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 30 (UPI) The University of Alabama's football coach, Paul (Bear) Bryant, and its basketball coach, C.M. Newton, testifying today on behalf of two assistant coaches fighting an N.C.A.A. rule limiting the size of coaching staffs, agreed that it would not be easy for the assistants to find coaching jobs at another major university.

TRENTON, Aug. 30 The New Jersey Commission of Investigation said today that it had uncovered widespread fraud during an 18-month check of "Medicaid mills" in the state, and it recommended that the state hire undercover agents to pose as patients to try to keep the program honest.

TOKYO, Aug. 30 (Reuters) Prime Minister Takeo Miki offered today to shuffle his Cabinet and the executive of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in an effort to end the most serious crisis in the party's 21-year history.

ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 30 When James Cronk woke up early today in his cell at the Attica State Correctional Facility here he did not, as he would normally have done, swing off his bunk bed. Instead, he lit a cigarette and reflected on last week's strike by inmates to protest prison conditions.
CINCINNATI, Aug, 30 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today that school officials cannot arbitrarily go through a school library and remove books they dislike.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 30 With 18 elephants and assorted other circus animals outside and Charlie Finley and his new hairpiece inside, the Yankees and Oakland played a game at the Coliseum tonight that held considerable importance for the A's.

NEWARK, Aug. 30(AP) The Board of Public Utility Commissioners announced today that it would order the Public Service Electric and Gas Company to refund $17,113,000 to customers by reducing the utility's raw materials adjustment charge (RMA) by 6 percent from October 1976 to September 1977.
The Taylor Wine Company, a leading domestic producer of wines, disclosed yesterday that the investment banking firm of Lazard Freres Company had offered to purchase from the...

NORTH STONINGTON., Conn., Aug. 30 (UPI) Two women with a shotgun today surprised a couple of young burglary suspects who entered their house for the second and apparently last time, the police reported.

ATLANTA, Aug. 30 Jimmy Carter quarreled today with President Ford's assessment of the most important issues in the 1976 Presidential election campaign, saying leadership and the restoration of trust in government were questions that would most affect voters this year.

MONTREAL, Aug. 30 The temperatures obligingly dipped into the 40's, and the hockey season began tonight in Montreal, where Team Canada and the Czechoslovak national team played as fine a kind of hockey as one could see in midseason.

OTTAWA, Aug. 30 Canadian sensibilities have been ruffled by the naming of a number of Saskatchewan politicians, senior civil servants and corporations by the United States Department of Justice as "unindicted co-conspirators" in charges relating to the fixing of the price of potash produced in the province and used in fertilizer sold mostly to American farmers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 Women's organizations that have worked long and hard for legal protection from sex discrimination are taking their battle one step further.

The Senate is about to debate Attorney General Edward Levi's national security wiretapping bill, so it's necessary once again to ask the question: What emergency justifies a Democratic Congress in rushing to pass a Republican Administration bill so full of loopholes and ambiguities? Why shouldn't such an important matter be left to the next Congress, when either the CarterMondale Administration will be in office or the Ford Administration will have been given electoral legitimacy?

Fifteen decrepit, largely vacant, tenements near the northeast corner of Central Park are scheduled to be rehabilitated into new housing for 272 poor and moderate-income families, Federal housing officials said yesterday.

LAST COOL CALL. Today and tomorrow, Rockefeller Center is presenting to midtown office workers and visitors the final admissionfree programs with some of the top jazz artists on the local scene, performing in an aptly festive setting. The site is the Channel Gardens, between Fifth Avenue and the Lower Plaza, 49th to 50th Street, and the title of the series speaks for itself "Music for a City Evening," scheduled for 4:30 to 6 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The League of Women Voters will be able to finance debates between national candidates of the Republican and Democratic parties without violating the new ban on private campaign contributions in the general election, the Federal Election Commission ruled today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) Prices of soybean futures declined by more than 15 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today and strongly influenced lower prices in other farm commodities.

Steel production in the week ended Aug. 21 declined 2.6 percent to 2.48 million net tons from 2.54 million tons the week before, but was ahead of the 2.03 million tons produced in the week ended Aug. 30, 1975, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The rate of capacity utilization, or effective capacity, receded to 81.7 percent from 93.9 percent in the previous year.
The United States Steel Corporation, bowing to competitive and customer pressures, took the unusual action yesterday of rescinding a 4.5 percent price increase scheduled to go into effect Oct. 1.
Prices improved in light trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI) The country's first right-to-die bill for terminally ill patients won final legislative approval today and was sent to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (Reuters) A Soviet delegation left Moscow today to attend Libya's Revolution Day celebrations as the Kremlin came down hard on the side of Libya in its quarrel with neighboring Arab countries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 Senator Walter F. Mondale today charged the Nixon and Ford Administrations with a "profligate" and "scandalous" record on arms sales and suggested that a special session of the United Nations Disarmament Commission be convened as a start toward control of such sales.

It was during the 1955 pennant race that John Campbell Burton the city's newest Deputy Mayor, found himself in the position of making what he terms a "contribution" to the fortunes of the Brooklyn Dodgers. Mr. Burton was then the club's statistician, a job that plunged him into baseball fever in a way open only to a certain kind of specialist.

Scientists working for the Army Corps of Engineers said yesterday they had found no evidence that dredge-spoil dumps, such as the one that the corps operates six miles east of New Jersey, posed a threat to the environment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) Saying the American consumer needs more protection from possibly harmful imported wines, the Government today proposed rules to insure that the quality of imports is the same as that of wine produced in this country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) Conservationists expressed both delight and suspicion today about President Ford's proposal to double the size of the nation's park, wildlife and refuge areas over 10 years.
About 3,000 sociologists from every state descended on the city yesterday with about as many descriptions of the world's social ills, but with few proposed solutions.
LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) David Moorcroft, a 23-yearold Briton, defeated Filbert Bayi of Tanzania in an upset in the mile run at the British Games today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (AP) New England's quarterback, Steve Grogan, threw for 335 yards and two touchdowns, both in the last two minutes of play, but the Cleveland Browns came away with a 30-27 victory tonight, their fourth straight National Football League preseason triumph.

The management committee of the International Lawn Tennis Federation fined the national associations of the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Hungary $10,000 each yesterday for having walked out of the women's Federation Cup tournament on political grounds.

Touche Ross Company, the accounting firm, assailing a lawsuit brought against the Securities and Exchange Commission by Arthur Andersen Company, another large accounting firm, urged in a statement yesterday that "a sensible solution" be worked out by the S.E.C. and the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 30 August P. Petrillo, the Mayor of this city since 1968, died on the weekend, apparently of a heart attack. Members of his family found him dead yesterday at his summer home in Southampton, L.I. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Senator Frank E. Moss's investigation of Medicaid fraud was derided today during a Cabinet meeting at the White House. F. David Matthews, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, noted that Medicaid was a state-managed program, whereas Medicare, which is federally managed, had a good record.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 30 A South Korean fishing vessel with 23 crew members aboard was fired upon and then seized by North Korean patrol boats today in the Sea of Japan off the eastern end of the demilitarized zone.
A Fire Department lieutenant died last night when he was trapped in a four-alarm fire that engulfed and destroyed a three-story brick commercial building in the Ridgewood section of Queens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) The House approved overwhelmingly today a bill to increase Federal payments to the needy blind, elderly and disabled by more than $32 million a year.

LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) Heavy rain fell on England and Wales over the weekend, but authorities warned that the downpour, though it amounted to as much as two inches in various places, did little to alleviate Britain's worst drought in 500 years.

Stocks advanced yesterday in response to bargain-hunting in blue chip and glamour issues as well as spreading cancellations of scheduled steel price increases by industry leaders. The steel price actions were viewed as encouraging news on the inflation front.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The House ethics committee voted unanimously today to hold formal public hearings next month into allegations at improper and illegal conduct by Representative Wayne L. Hays.

Two divisions of the Fall Highweight Handicap occupied the featured spots on the program yesterday as thoroughbred racing returned to Belmont Park for a 48-day stand. MONTILLA, Spain, Aug. 29 Anatoly Karpov won first prize in the Torneo del Vino here by finishing with an undefeated 7-2 score, putting him 1 points ahead of his nearest competitors.

VERSAILLES, Ky., Aug. 30 (AP) Doug Davis Jr., one of the most successful trainers in Kentucky thoroughbred racing, died here today of an apparent heart attack. He was 59 years old.

MARINA DEL REY, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) Joel Halpern, a wealthy, 38-year-old contractor from Bronxville, N.Y., captured the Marina Del Rey offshore powerboat race yesterday and won the national powerboat championship. Halpern, driving his 38-foot Cobra with twin 428-inch Mercury engines, traveled the 188-mile course in about 2 hours.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 30 I.W. LONDON, Aug. 30 A noisy, happy calypso carnival, with steel bands and crowds of dancing West Indians, turned into a riot here this afternoon and at least 400 people were injured, the majority of them policemen, Scotland Yard reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said in a letter released today that there was "no foundation in fact" to charges that the board was dominated by banks and big business.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP) Bjorn Borg of Sweden dropped an error-plagued first set, but then won the United States pro tennis championship tonight for the third consecutive year with a 6-7, 6-4, 6-1, 6-2 victory over Harold Solomon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) A senior Agriculture Department economist said today that although retail meat prices were lower than a year ago, middlemen were not fully passing along the reduced prices farmers have been getting for livestock.

JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 30 Black strife in Soweto is reported to have caused at least six more deaths in the last 36 hours, bringing the total who have died in the black township since a fresh upheaval broke out a week ago to at least 42. A total of 296 people are unofficially estimated to have died since anti-Government unrest broke out in South African black townships two month ago.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 More than 50 persons, including members of Local 1419 of the International Longshoremen's Association, are reportedly under investigation for the suspected embezzlement of $1.2 million from a union welfare fund, according to sources close to the case.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 30 A "pretty good" bonus from the Cleveland Browns is in the bank; a twoyear, no-cut contract with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats waits in Canada.

Burmah was to provide tankers to ship Indonesian liquefied natural gas to Japan.

The West German bankers say that if the American bill becomes law, it could constrict the flow of European investment to American companies and cities that badly want foreign capital.

The long-smoldering La Soufriere volcano on the Caribbean island of Guadeloupe exploded yesterday. French authorities said it spewed lava and boiling mud and that twelve scientists had been trapped briefly, of whom two were injured.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 Judge Mark Brandler of Superior Court refused today to grant a new trial to William and Emily Harris, the accused kidnappers of Patricia Hearst.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) The number of stockholder resolutions voted at corporate meetings more than doubled this year although the resolutions continued to lose when opposed by management.
New York City yesterday settled suits brought by two Westchester communities Mount Vernon and Greenburgh but will pay the claims with water, not cash.

DUBLIN, Aug. 31 (AP) The 13th World Methodist Congress ended here today with a call for continued talks with the Roman Catholic Church on world church unity and for similar discussions with the Lutheran and Eastern Orthodox Churches.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that stoking the nation's atomic reactors with the controversial fuel plutonium would pose no special health problems and would be economically sound.
Four-year-old Jason Briggs tried to sip from his CocaCola, but his nose kept hitting the upright tab. His mother looked on helplessly. "I don't know how it works," she said, shrugging her shoulders.
The big American steel producers, under the lead of the United States Steel Corporation, began to announce price rises two weeks ago, and, by Aug. 23, all top 10 companies had followed suit.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 More than 3,000 clergymen and job trainers of the Opportunities Industrialization Centers vowed today to push for passage of a pending bill in Congress that would allow community groups to train and provide jobs for a million unemployed persons in the next four years.
The New York City Housing Authoriy, damaged by an overtime-fraud scandal in its elevator-repair division, is instituting major changes in an effort to avoid such abuses in the future.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Prices of farm products dropped in the month ended Aug. 15, marking the first decline in this basic element of food costs since last March and signaling a prospect of some relief for consumers at grocerystore meat counters.

The United States, confronted with demands by Britain for a larger share of the air traffic market between the two countries, has raised the possibility of a shutdown in bilateral air service if pending talks to resolve major differences fail.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 31 A study committee recommended to the Southern Governors Conference today that it endorse the development of a streamlined regional Presidential primary system to replace the present state-by-state system.

Dr. Renee Richards said yesterday she would sue the United States Tennis Association unless the association waived its sex chromosome test and admitted her to the United States Open championships as an alternate.

Thirty-three upstate Democratic county leaders 26 of whom are supporters of Daniel P. Moynihan in the five-way race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate called on Representative Bella S. Abzug yesterday to repudiate her vow not to support Mr. Moynihan should he win the Sept. 14 primary.
LONDON, Aug. 31 Scotland YYard was accused today of ing helped to provoke the bloody confrontation last night between white policemen and black youths in a poor neighborhood in London.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 31 The group of African countries today asked the Security Council to impose sanctions on South Africa to force it to relinquish its control of Namibia, r South-West Africa.
Jerry Reuss, who has not won 20 games in his seven years in the major leagues and doesn't appear to be headed for that number this year, outdueled the major leagues' first 20-game winner last night.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 31 Oakland's Unsigned Six became the Unsigned Seven with the acquisition by the A's of Willie McCovey, but one more potential free agent isn't going to cause any drastic changes in the life and times of Charles O. Finley.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 31 Two New York City chiro- practors who will soon begin serving five-year prison sentences for Medicaid fraud told a Senate subcommittee today how they built their Medicaid empire and why they had felt "encouraged" to cheat the Government.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 31 President-elect Elias Sarkis flew to Damascus today for discussions with the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad, on future Lebanese-Syrian relations and on ways for ending the 17month Lebanese civil war.

LOVELAND, Colo., Aug. 31 (AP) The number of known dead in the July 31 flood in Big Thompson Canyon has risen to 130 with the discovery of a woman's body by debris re moval crews, the authorities reported. A data coordinator at the Loveland Disaster Center, said the death toll was expected to reach 156.

LONDON, Aug. 31 The criticism directed against the metropolitan police's role in yesterday's racial disturbance in London was aimed mainly at their planning arrangements, not at physical tactics that might have been regarded as "brutal" had they occurred in the United States.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 32 (AP) No disciplinary action is contemplated against Tom Weiskopf for his disqualification in the American Golf Classic, Deane Beman, commissioner of the Professonal Golfers' Association tour, said today.

A study commissioned by a New Jersey legislator concluded Monday that the offshore area where New York City dumps its sewage sludge might have spawned the mass of algae that had been plaguing the Jersey shore this summer.
DALLAS, Aug. 31 (UPI) Frank D. Reece, assistant managing editor of The Dallas Morning News, died yesterday. He was 51 years old.

The most obvious way to eliminate labor from a Labor Day feast is to assemble an assortment of good things in advance. It has long been our contention, in fact, that some of the best dishes in the world are those that bear the unseemly and unpalatable label "leftovers." Two of the merest cases in point are roast turkey and roast beef (or even roast pork, for which there is a recipe on this page).

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 31 The New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. proposed today through its president, Raymond R. Corbett, that the labor movement join with the recently created Coalition of Northeastern Governors in an effort to promote economic recovery in the region and to obtain a larger share of Federal assistance.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31 (UPI) Ohio Secretary of State Ted Brown said today that he had authorized the names of Lester G. Maddox and William Dyke as official American Party candidates for President and Vice President on the state's Nov. 2 ballot.
In the always percolating pot of television news, the latest ingredient promising consumer satisfaction is being called "Gonzo" broadcast journalism.
To listen to Manager Joe Frazier of the Mets, you would have thought his team had lost to the San Francisco Giants last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Julian S. Kulski, former President, or Mayor, of Warsaw during the Nazi occupation from 1939 to 1944, died in the Polish capital Aug. 18, his son said here today. He was 83 years old.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 31 Extraordinary precautions were taken at the autopsy today of a bartender at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia to determine if he might have been the victim of a mysterious disease that has killed 28 people and sickened another 151 in Pennsylvania.

A spokesman for the Roman Catholic hierarchy said yesterday after a meeting with Jimmy Carter in Washington that the Democratic Presidential nominee had continued to withhold support for a constitution- al amendment to ban abortion and that the clergymen remained "disappointed" with his position.

In Porno Chic such movies as "Emmanuelle" and "The Story of O" the action is given a lush romantic treatment, and the clothes, no longer on the actors, seem to be draped over the cameras: hence the misty effect.
A new $85-million annex for Senate offices will be named for Senator Philip A. Hart, the Senate has decided by a voice-vote resolution.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., Aug. 31 Senator James L. Buckley and his younger brother, William F. Buckley, nomally have few differences politically, but when they do, their disagreement has political impact.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 31 The United Steelworkers of America convention turned back a challenge today to the union's no-strike agreement in the basic steel industry, which the leadership calls the capstone of its achievement and dissidents call a sellout of the membership.

A cowboy out of the old Wild West has been whooping it up along the country's bridge trails for the last nine months. He is Don Oakie, and he comes from San Jose, Calif., which is certainly West if not very wild. And he used to be a lumber-mill operator, a tough rural occupation, even if not actually a bovine one.
TRENTON, Aug. 31 The weather was beautiful in downtown Trenton today much too nice a day to work.

WASHINGTON Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, who surely knows more about the subject than anyone else, believes it would be both wiser and more efficient for the United States Government to have two Cabinet officers jointly charged with supervision of the President's foreign policy.
TANAH RATA, Malaysia, Stanley Middleton-Foster is carving an old English inn out of the jungle.

Now and then classical ballet dancers have unwittingly inspired something of a vogue for the way they look, for what they wear. Remember all those ballerina slippers that used to go pattering along the street on people who wouldn't know an entrechat if they saw one?

BERN, Switzerland, Aug. 31 (AP) Seventy-five steelhelmeted Swiss militiamen set out one night last week on a maneuver with 50 horses, most of them pack animals, and soon discovered that they had invaded Liechtenstein.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 31 How can the destiny of an entire football team, as to its success or failure in the coming season, depend upon the ability of

BERN, Aug. 31 (AP) Seventy-five steel-helmeted Swiss militiamen set out one night last week on a maneuver with 50 horses, most of them pack animals, and soon discovered that they had invaded Liechtenstein.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Senate and House conferees reached a compromise today under which limited funds would be appropriated for the B-1 bomber but a final decision on full production would be delayed until next year.

Monday morning the glorious day before yesterday, when New York decided to be perfect for a while the newspapers were full of President Ford's promises on parks. One and a half billion dollars is a lot of park promises.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 Assemblyman George A. Cincotta, a Democrat from Brooklyn, who as chairman of the Assembly Banking Committee was a key sponsor of the bill that gave savings banks the right to offer checking accounts, has received campaign contributions from 62 savings banks this year, a check of financial records at the State Board of Elections here has shown.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (UPI) Phil Seghi, the vice president-general manager of the Cleveland Indians, rejected today an offer from the New York Yankees to purchase Rico Carty, a designated hitter, for $200,000.

Despite the scandals that have swirled for years about so-called Medicaid mills in New York City, authorities do not know how many there are or who owns them, and are enjoined by a court from finding out.
Citing increased demand for aluminum, the Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it had scheduled reactivation of idle capacity at three plants in the next two months.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 31 (AP) The police used tear gas to disperse a crowd of more than 1,000 antibusing demonstrators tonight on the eve of the opening of Jefferson County schools for a second year under court-ordered busing.
The oldest continuing weekly one-night jazz engagement in New York is now in its 15th year at Arthur's, 57 Grove Street, where the Grove Street Stompers began playing on Monday nights in 1962.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 Three present or former officials of a waterfront union were charged by a Federal grand jury here today with conspiring to extort $13,330 from several small grain companies over a five-year period.

Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, chancellor of the City University, reported yesterday that applications for state tuition assistance by full-time students at the university were running well ahead of initial estimates, but that requests for city funds by part-time students were fewer than expected.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 31 (AP) Nicos Sampson, the terrorist who was made President of Cyprus for a week in the Greek-led coup that temporarily ousted President Makarios in 1974, was sentenced today to 20 years in prison.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 President Ford, sounding a probable theme of his campaign against the Democrats this fall, attacked Senate and House conferees today for "giving the country only half a loaf" with their decision to extend a $15billion tax cut through next year.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd met with 75 New York City-area department-store executives yesterday to explore ways of halting the rash of firebombings in the last month. The Commissioner said he would assign additional police officers to the case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today that he had been questioned by Justice Department investigators about possible misuse by him of Government services and property in his home.

Jimmy Cliff's concert at the Schaefer Music Festival Monday night had its considerable virtues, but first a word about the weather: Outdoor concerts in New York are generally afflicted with mugginess or thunderstorms. Monday's clear, clean, cool night air would probably have made a quarter of singing critics sound good.
Stock prices posted their third advance in a row yesterday with gains showing in computer, defense, savings-and-loan, retail, electronic and oil-related issues.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) The Lebanese Ambassador today challenged the Soviet view of Lebanon's civil war, declaring that Palestinian troops fighting there were the aggressors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration is considering a ban on two widely used food colorings, it was learned today. One is the red used to color Maraschino cherries, the other is black used for licorice and jelly beans.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 Sweet Cherrity pie did not win. The German chocolate upside-down cake did not win. The woman who entered 50 recipes did not win. The women who had been finalists seven times did not win. And the Florida woman who entered the Pillsbury BakeOff every year since it began 27 years ago did not win.

Schools of continuing education in the New York City area are establishing new courses in health services and paralegal and gerontological studies, among others, as the manpower needs of the economy and the age composition of the population change.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 31 Ten Southern Governors sent a strongly worded telegram to President Ford today urging him to grant direct airline routes between London and five Southern cities.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 31 Israel took military steps along its border with Lebanon today amid reports that friendly Lebanese had requested Israeli help in organizing the defense of their villages against Palestinian attacks, Censorship bars any detailing of the Israeli moves.
The North American Soccer League season is over, but the New York Cosmos will be making money for another month at so. Pele and his teammates left for a tour of North America and Asia yesterday.
The Abitibi Paper Company announced yesterday that it would raise its price for newsprint sold in Canada and the United States by $20 a ton, effective Dec. 1.

DUBLIN, Aug. 31 The Irish Government moved today to increase drastically prison sentences for members of the Irish Republican Army and to impose emergency legislation to quell suspected terrorists. The proposed legislation was the most sweeping aimed at the I.R.A, in 50 years.

TRENTON, Aug. 31?Gerald J. Reilly, director of the state Medicaid program, said today, that while New Jersey had been praised for "aggressively" attacking Medicaid fraud, it might be a good idea to hire undercover agents to check for unscrupulous physicians within the program.
When the Consolidated Cigar Corporation instituted its Miss Muriel election a year ago, there was a definite marketing reason: sales of the Muriel brand had flattened out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) New factory orders fell 0.5 percent in July as a record decline in new defense bookings overshadowed a record increase in orders for nondefense capital goods, the Commerce Department said today.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 The Mexican Government tonight effectively devalued the peso by abandoning its 22-year-old fixed parity with the United States dollar and allowing the currency to float to a new level.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (UPI) Dick Siderowf, a stockbroker from Westport, Conn., kept his cool in the heat today and defeated Mike Barge, 1 up, in his opening match in the 76th United States Amateur golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Representative Wayne L. Hays, who until three months ago was one of the most powerful members of Congress, was on the verge of resig nation tonight, according to sources on Capitol Hill.
UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 31 Third-world negotiators are looking to Secretary Henry A. Kissinger to salvage some small gains from the stalemated Law of the Sea Conference.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (UPI) United Airlines today defended its use of Andy Frain Security Services personnel to screen passengers boarding planes at O'Hare International Airport.

PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 30 If he is elected President, Jimmy Carter says, he plans to dispose of his stocks, divest himself of his peanut business and divert royalties from his popular auto- biography to a philanthropic foundation.

PLAINS, Ga., Aug. 30 If he is elected President, Jimmy Carter says, he plans to dispose of his stocks, divest himself of his peanut business and divert royalties from his popular autobiography to a philanthropic foundation.
The musicians' union last night joined the Radio City Music Hall's Rockettes and stagehands in agreeing to a one-year cost-saving contract, thus averting a threatened shutdown of the theater.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. The stark, slender totem poles, painted in the familiar Southwest earthtones of brown, ocher and cream, seem very much at home in the adobe building on the edge of the airport. So do the hypnotic, rhythmic chants being piped through the room over loudspeakers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Player representatives of the 28 National Football League teams rejected the owners' latest contract offer tonight by tabling it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Washington Redskins signed Frank Grant, a wide receiver, to a one-year contract today, removing a thorn from the side of Coach George Allen.
PARIS, Aug. 31 French officials denied today charges made in the United States that France was a member of a clandestine international cartel fixing artificially high prices for uranium.

DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 31 The Ford Motor Company offered the United Automobile Workers today a wage rise of 3 percent a year over the next three years. That would raise the weekly pay of an automobile assembler to more than $7 an hour in 1979.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Ford Administration's top arms control official accused the Soviet Union today of attempting to alter the strategic nuclear weapons balance with the United States by introducing a new missile in Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) President Ford said in a statement today that he was transposing the nominations of a Republican and a Democrat to the Federal Communications Commission.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Aug. 31 Replacing a graduated starter is never easy, but Coach Bill Campbell of Columbia has an especially difficult road ahead of him in locating a replacement for Doug Jackson, the Lions' top league rusher ever and last season's Ivy League player of the year.
HAVE SOME Those attractive flowers behind the Times Square Theater Center on Duffy Square are up for grabs an orderly procedure of acquisition will take place tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Securities and Exchange Commission, adopting guidelines for financial disclosure by bank holding companies, said today the banks would be expected to provide data on questionable loans for a five-year period instead of two years as it originally proposed last October.
DUBLIN, Aug. 31 The Irish Republican Army, the target of new antiterrorist moves by the Irish Government, grew out of the Irish volunteers who rebelled against British rule in 1916.
ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (AP) A banker, a former Congressional aide aind a State Representative won Democratic nominations for Congressional posts in Georgia runoff elections today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Two New York City chiro practors who will soon begin serving five-year prison sentences for Medicaid fraud told a Senate subcommittee today how they built their Medicaid empire and why they had felt "encouraged" to cheat the Government.

The United States, with Vic Seixas and Hugh Stewart, advanced to the final of the annual Stevens Cup international senior team tennis tournament yesterday by defeating Sweden, 3-0. Canada also gained the final with a 3-0 victory over Australia. The two winners play for the cup at Tennisport today, starting at 11 A.M.

A 33-year-old Brooklyn man who the police said turned himself in was arrested yesterday in connection with a recent theft of bronze mausoleum doors in Queens. Only five days earlier a 19-year-old man was arrested in the theft of such doors from a Brooklyn cemetery. The police said the two cases were linked.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger appealed to black African leaders today not to give up hope that the United States and Britain could negotiate a formula that would end control by the white minorities in Rhodesia and South-west Africa without causing warfare.

LAMBERTVILLE, Aug. 31 New Jersey environmental officials have tentatively concluded that potential destruction from future floods on the Delaware River may not be as widespread as they had predicted earlier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today that he had been questioned by Justice Department investigators about possible misuse by him of Government services and property in his home.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) The Soviet Union refused today to play Chile, its scheduled opponent, in the interzone semifinals of the Davis Cup tennis tournament, expressing "indignation with the horrible crimes committed by the Chilean military junta."
Prices rose yesterday for the third consecutive session on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee said today he hoped the panel could issue a report before Congress adjourned on the Gulf Oil Company's contributions to members of the Senate.

POINTS-A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Aug. 31 (AP) A torrent of soot and ash from La Soufriere volcano subsided to a thin column of white vapor today and scientists said they were still uncertain whether the volcano would stage a full eruption.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31 The creases were transformed into boxing rings, and center ice became a battlefield for spearing and elbowing tonight as Team USA and the Soviet Union's national team played an exhibition match here that had little to do with hockey.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Refugees from Vietnam said today that there were severe shortages of food and of consumer and industrial products in the territory of former South Vietnam, which fell to Communist troops from North Vietnam in April 1975 and has since been merged with the North.

The First Women's Bank, which opened last October and has already replaced two of its four top officers, is preparing to announce that Madeline McWhinney, its president, is leaving, a spokesman for the bank said last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Frederick B. Dent said today that duty-free status for television picture tubes over 16 inches had been ended for Taiwan, South Korea, Brazil and Mexico.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 31 Almost every day now, Pat Hughes reads or hears he has been traded to a team to be named later.

A major reorganization of the New York City school system's adult education operation, intended to improve the program while making the best possible use of the limited finances available, has been proposed in a confidential Board of Education report.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31, William and Emily Harris were given sentences today that could mean life imprisonment for their conviction of armed robbery, kidnapping and auto theft charges stemming from a two-day trip here with Patricia Hearst in 1974.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 31 Like an explorer surveying new-found land, Peter A.A. Berle paddled down the Carmans River in a canoe today, stuck a flag in the sand at the mouth of the river and declared the area the property of New York State.

Peaceful protests by inmates in state prisons spread to a third maximum-security institution in New York State yesterday as the Correction Commission convened an inquiry in Albany into the unrest that began at the Attica Correctional Facility on Aug. 23.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI) A scientist, summing up a review of the Viking 1 landing craft's findings on the Martian surface, said today that the results of the biology experiments were "inconclusive" and not understood.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was asked here tonight how the United States could reconcile its strong support of South Korea with that Government's repressive policies, including the sentencing of 18 political opponents over the weekend.

"US," which is subtitled "The American Folk Oratorio," is, more accurately, a selection of some of the more than l25 songs that Stan Satlin has composed and organized as a celebration of man and of America for the Bicentennial.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 "This conference is really the beginning of the end of the dissension," said S.L. Shneiderman, a New Yorker who spent some days here proselytizing for the language he loves Yiddish.
Bands, balloons, bikinied models and other assorted ballyhoo were served up in Central Park yesterday as the newly refurbished $2.5 million Tavern-on-the-Green opened for business.

Dr. Paul Lazarsfeld, a Columbia University sociologist whose studies of American voting patterns and the influences of the printed and electronic press on society are classics in his field, died of cancer at New York Hospital on Monday, He was 75 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Senate Budget Committee proposed today a ceiling of $412.8 billion on Federal spending for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1, leaving a deficit of $50.8 billion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 It hasn't been easy, but Jimmy Carter and George Meany have finally agreed on a strategy for winning the Presidential election of 1976: Mr. Carter will hold the South, and Mr. Meany will use the power of the labor unions of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to deliver the electoral votes of most of the big industrial states from Massachusetts, New York and New Jersey to Pennsylvania, Ohio and Illinois.

Joan Copeland, who recently won critical praise as Vera Simpson in the Circle in the Square's revival of "Pal Joey," will be a co-star with Allen Swift in a new comedy, "Checking Out." It will open Sept. 14 at the Longacre Theater.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Soviet Union has bought an additional 275,000 metric tons of United States wheat valued at $34.6 million for delivery under a long-term agreement that takes effect this fall, the Agriculture Department said today.

Since last November, prospective buyers of individual retirement accounts marketed by banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions have been entitled to receive detailed information about the accounts before they purchase them, or, at the latest, on the day of purchase.
