It is disappointing that Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare David Mathews reacted to the disclosures about widespread Medicaid abuses with the standard brand of bureaucratic defensiveness.

A spokesman for the Roman Catholic hierarchy said yesterday after a meeting with Jimmy Carter in Washington that the Democratic Presidential nominee had continued to withhold support for a constitutional amendment to ban abortion and that the clergymen remained "disappointed" with his position.

Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin warned yesterday that New York City could be penalized up to $25 million next year by the Federal Government unless it implemented by Jan. 1 new Federal regulations to recoup child-support payments from absentee parents under the welfare program.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Black nationalist guerrillas attacked a military camp in northeastern Rhodesia yesterday and severely wounded six Rhodesian soldiers, a Government statement said today.

ALEXANDRIA, Va. Aug. 31 The first trial in what may be months or years of criminal and civil litigation stemming from the manufacture of the insecticide Kepone opened today in the Federal District Court here, just outside Washington.

As a result of growing opposition to the recent Sunday openings by four of the area's largest retailers, public hearings are planned by the state next month to hear views on whether new legislation may be needed to replace the blue laws revoked in June.

Benjamin M. McKelway, retired editor of The Washington Star and a former president of The Associated Press, died Monday of kidney failure at Sibley Hospital in the nation's capital. He was 80 years old.

A New York State Supreme Court Justice, George Postel, reserved decision yesterday on an effort by two minority stockholders of the MerrittChapman Scott Corporation to force Louis E. Wolfson to show cause why he should not be ordered to repay $1.3 million in expenses he allegedly drew illegally from the company.

WASHINGTON Aug. 31 Administration officials said today they believed the Kuwaiti Government's decision to suspend the National Assembly and to restrict the press was designed primarily to control the large Palestinian community in Kuwait.

Although the Forest Service in the United States Department of Agriculture gives lip service to the "multiple use" concept in its management of the national forests, it has in recent decades put commercial logging first and relegated the other uses wildlife habitat, outdoor recreation, wilderness to the sidelines. The ultimate expression of this contempt for the broader public interest is the increasing reliance on "clear cutting" instead of selective cutting in the management of forests.

The South Street Seaport Museum, beset by short-term financial problems, is laying off nearly a third of its full-time staff and virtually all of its part-time staff and is considering closing one day a week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (UPI) With a key report due out next week, an originator of the idea that spray-can gases endanger the earth's ozone radiation shield said today that enough is now known to start thinking about regulating the gases.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 Conservationists have mixed feelings about President Ford's proposed $1.5 billion 10-year program for improving the national parks and other Federal recreation areas that he sent to Congress today.
PHILADELPHIA The Presidential debates of 1976 will have a large influence on the November election, and on the future of America.
Nye Pharr, an artist and former advertising art director, died of cancer on Monday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 1 Strawberry Hill in Stamford.

Lured by the presence of Jimmy Carter, some exceptionally well-to-do New Yorkers pulled up in their chauffered limousines to an East 69th Street town house last night and gave money to the Democratic National Committee that the committee will, in turn, be able to give to the Carter-forPresident campaign.

The New York State Lottery, which was suspended by Governor Carey last October because of mismanagement, will resume next Wednesday with prizes ranging from a $2 return to $1,000 a week for life, with a minimum payoff of $1 million for the top prize.
Reversing a two-week trend, the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City last week rose 1.2 percent above the previous week's level, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

NEWARK, Aug. 31 Electricity customers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company will get lower bills in September because of the increased output of power from the Peach Bottom Nuclear Generating Station, the first reversal of the upward trend of electric rates since the oil embargo in 1974.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade gained nearly 5 cents a bushel today.

The city's incentive program to spur new commercial and industrial development by granting substantial real estate tax relief is running on a slow track.

TRENTON, Aug. 31 Construction of 1,001 apartments for the elderly in six New Jersey communities will begin shortly as a result of the sale of almost $66 million in bonds, the State Housing Finance Agency announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Ford Administration adamantly refused today any compromise in its opposition to use the tax laws to penalize United States companies that comply with the Arab boycott of Israel.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 31 Acting on recent experience, Manager Billy Martin ordered Sparky Lyle and Dick Tidrow to start warming up in the bull pen at the start of Oakland's half of the ninth inning tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Senate broke a filibuster today against a major antitrust bill and apparently cleared the way for the measure's enactment before Congress adjourns.
WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, Aug. 31 (AP) Delegates to a constitutional conference today shelved a resolution calling for free elections in SouthWest Africa.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Jimmy Carter has laid out his fall campaign schedule according to an arithmetic formula to make sure that each state gets just the collective attention it merits and no more.

Anatoly Karpov was dissatisfied with his play in the Torneo del Vino in Montilla, Spain, despite his easy victory without a loss. Chagrined over the many errors in his games, he shook his head ruefully and said: "After every, move, the games changed hands. I would be winning effortlessly, then make one mistake, answered by a compensating mistake by my opponent, then make another and so on. I could have been on a seesaw."

Or is Communism a radical departure from the past, an aberration whose roots lie not in Russian history but in Europe?

ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 5 (AP) In a brilliant display of driving, Bobby Unser squeezed everything he could from an underpowered car and beat Johnny Rutherford and Gordon Johncock today in the $323,000 California 500, for Indianapolis-type cars.

The Oakland A's bid to capture their sixth straight American League Western Division crown faltered badly over the weekend as they lost twice to the California Angels. The A's remain seven games behind with 27 remaining.

"Paul Whiteman Rediscovered" is the title of a concert celebrating the late "King of Jazz" of the 1920's and 30's, to take place Oct. 29 at Carnegie Hall. The Paul Whiteman Collection at Williams College is lending the arrangements to Mr. Davis and will receive a share of the proceeds of the concert.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 At a news conference in Vail, Colo., last month, President Ford announced that he and his campaign advisers had "refined the areas that we think important for this campaign to emphasize."

WASHINGTON, SEPT. 6(AP) The new school year has started with fewer teacher strikes than in 1975, the National Education Association says. But the association warns that more teacher contracts are unsettled this year, which could mean trouble ahead.

Representative Bella S. Abzug yesterday called for New York State to "take the lead in becoming the solar-energyequipment capital of the nation." She did so in a position paper that also proposed that large oil companies be broken up and that emphasis be placed on energy sources that made greater use of labor.
All four persons aboard were killed yesterday when a single-engine plane crashed less than half a mile from Zahns Airport in North Amityville, L.I., where it was apparently trying to land.

Interest rates on bonds issued by states, cities and towns have been declining all summer and have reached their lowest levels in 18 months. That is good news for local government finance officials and taxpayers but bad news for investors. If Wall Street is...

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 1 The Communist Pathet Lao, who for nine months have been firmly in control of the Government and people of Laos, are attempting to rebuild the tiny landlocked country into a self-sufficient socialist state.
Beginning with this issue, The New York Times is changing its format of eight columns on a page to one of six columns for news and nine columns for display advertising.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 With the deadline just eight days away, company and union negotiators still had the big question before them: Is there going to be a strike against the Ford Motor Company?
Two years ago, as the regular organization candidate, Leo C. Zeferetti won the Democratic primary in Brooklyn's 15th Congressional District by 62 votes out of the more than 24,000 cast.
PARIS, Sept. 6 The Vietnamese Embassy here today made public the names of 12 missing American pilots and said they had been killed in action in the war in Indo-china.

As public schools in the New York area's suburbs open throughout this week, the academic year is once again beginning against a backdrop of budget defeats, staff cutbacks and a generally continuing decline in enrollment. But this year, a record number of school districts will operate on austerity programs, and a record number of teachers may go on strike.
RUTHERFORD, Sept. 6 Thousands flocked to the downtown business district of this Bergen County community today for a "street fair" commemorating both Labor Day and the Bicentennial.

The honor of being the country's youngest-ever life master was earned earlier this year by Regina Barnes of Modesto, Calif., just before her 15th birthday. There is now another claimant to the title: Alex Weinum of New York City, who was some two months younger than Miss Barnes was when he reached life master.

Thirteen days ago the Philadelphia Phillies enjoyed a 15 -game lead over the second-place Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League's Eastern Division, and, since the three other divisional races were also one-sided, baseball fans had to look to the playoffs and the World Series for excitement.
BOONTON, Sept. 6 Trapshooting and skeet shooting appear to be growing in popularity in New Jersey.
TIJUANA, Mexico, Sept. 6 Carl Frederick sat huddled over his salty Margarita at the Caesar Hotel bar, gloomily regarding a wad of Mexican money he had been trying all day to spend.
DETROIT Edward N. Cole is scarcely an average retired auto worker.
A 4-day-old baby girl, left alone on the floor of an East Harlem apartment, was killed yesterday morning by the family's German Shepherd, which had not been fed for several days.

A Rhodesian, South African and Russian were eliminated from the United States Open tennis championships yesterday without international incident before a crowd of 16,145, the third largest in Open history.

Taiwan's presumed nuclear violation brings into question the American security guarantee. That guarantee, as in the case of Japan and South Korea, is designed to provide an American nuclear umbrella in place of national acquisition of atomic weapons.

The American intelligence report that Taiwan clandestinely has built a reprocessing facility that is extracting weapons-grade plutonium explosive from spent nuclear reactor fuel rods demands immediate investigation by the appropriate Congressional committees. Taiwan's denials have not impressed Washington insiders.

DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 6 (AP) David Pearson took the lead with 56 miles to go today as he drove his Mercury to victory in the 27th annual Southern 500 stock car race. Pearson became the second driver to win the sport's "triple crown."

The twin-jet Soviet fighter that landed in northern Japan is one of the world's fastest warplanes. It has been described in the United States as "the standard against which the efficiency of the Western defense systems must be evaluated."

LIME ROCK, Conn., Sept. 6 Bob Tullius of Herndon, Va., won the feature race today at the Sports Car Club of America's national championship. Tullius, driving a Jaguar XJE in competition for the first time, broke the lap record on the second lap as he defeated Sylvan Cornblatt of Baltimore.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 6 (AP) Prince Wan Waithayakon, former Thai Ambassador to the United States and President of the United Nations General Assembly in 1956-57, died yesterday of a heart ailment, Radio Thailand announced today. His age was 85.

An overwhelming majority of the corporation and bank executives responding to a recent New York Times inquiry believe the re-election of Gerald Ford as President would be better for the nation's economy than a victory by Jimmy Carter.
Gerald Ford's campaign may be off to a good start in the attempt to make Jimmy Carter, rather than the record of the Nixon-Ford Administrations, "the issue" of the 1976 campaign.
Property-casualty insurance companies are traditional buyers of municipal bonds for their investment portfolios. The idea is to provide tax-free income as an offset to underwriting profits.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 6 (UPI) An alliance of Communists and two other parties supporting President Makarios won all but one seat in the 35-member Greek Cypriote House of Representatives today.

Disclosures of white-collar crime have swept over the American public in steady, consecutive waves. Flagrant breaches of the law have involved politicians, corporation executives, lawyers, physicians, and operators of social services from day-care centers for infants to nursing homes for the aged. Billions of dollars have been misappropriated, diverted from their public purposes, used as political or commercial bribes, or just plain stolen. Careers have been destroyed; untold suffering has been caused.
Senator James L. Buckley, in a campaign statement yesterday, blamed the Democrats who control Congress for "savings-destroying, job-destroying, economic irresponsibility."

Jimmy Carter formally began his election campaign yesterday in Warm Springs, Ga., portraying himself as the representative of a "new generation of leadership" and his opponent, President Ford, as timid and ineffectual.
In the hours before the New York Yankees celebrated Labor Day by laboring against the Boston Red Sox last night, Gabe Paul was not celebrating the Yankees' lead in the American League East.
Sharon has outgrown her pediatrician. "I won't go back to Dr. Gordon even if I'm dying," she vows. Sharon is 13 years old and in the best of health.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 (AP) Community relations and police academy officers manned squad cars today after 60 percent of the city's patrol force staged a Labor Day sick-out to protest holiday pay cuts.
BUFFALO, Sept. 6 (AP) Teachers defied two court injunctions and voted tonight, by a 2-to-1 margin to strike.
DETROIT, Sept. 6 (UPI) Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that President Ford's way of fighting inflation was to create mass unemployment.

BARBERTON, Ohio, Sept. 6 Senator Walter F. Mondale today charged the Ford Administration with "economic mismanagement" as he moved west across the country in a Labor Day marathon campaign that began when he shook hands with airport workers and, in a definite break with tradition, shook the leg of one man before leaving Washington.
BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil (Reuters) A new gold rush is on in Brazil with all the tales of gun battles, bloody feuding and hardship that characterized the early prospecting days of the American West.

WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Sept. 6 (Reuters) The Volkswagen group may this year erase its carried-forward losses of some 960 million marks ($384 million) if the considerable improvement in first-half earnings continues, Volkswagen AG said in a letter to shareholders released today.

Game-law citations, charging illegal baiting of mourning-doves with corn, have been sent to Gov. Daniel Walker of Illinois and eight companions who hunted with him on a friend's farm last week. The State Representative Gale Schisler, a fellow Democrat and hunter, said yesterday that the Governor knew nothing about the corn and may have been set up for the violation.
Into this world of gimmicks and giveaways, promotions and powerplays, comes the voice of the announcer between halves of a football game, appealing for rooms for rookies of the New York Jets.

LONDON, Sept.6 (AP) The price of gold shot up $5 to $8 an ounce on European bullion markets today, and closed at $115.50 an ounce in London and $113.50 in Zurich. The dollar weakened slightly on most exchanges in light trading.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Claude C. Wild Jr., a former Gulf Oil Corporation lobbyist who dispensed some $4 million in legal and illegal political contributions, said today that he gave Republican VicePresidential nominee Robert J. Dole $2,000 in cash in 1970 to pass on to Republican candidates.

TELLURIDE, Colo., Sept. 6 The Cannes Film Festival is a manic treasure hunt where only steely organization and inside tips will get you through the industrial din and distraction and into some good movies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 A planned test that would link six of the nation's automated clearing houses through the telecommunications network of the Federal Reserve System has created a debate on the proper role of the Government in electronic fund transfers.

With today's issue, The New York Times adopts a new format of six columns of news and nine columns of advertising on a page, replacing the eight-column news and advertising format it has used since 1913.

Last April 14, when Senator John J. Santucci stood on the State Senate floor to denounce the Stavisky-Goodman bill as a "sham" and to vote against overriding Governor Carey's veto, he knew he was asking for trouble. Last month, he got it.
Five states will hold Congressional primaries today with few surprises expected, and North Dakota will hold a gubernatorial primary.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 6 (UPI) A commuter train crashed into the rear of a stationary Mozambique-bound express train east of Johannesburg today, killing at least 31 persons and injuring more than 70, railroad officials said.

LONDON, Sept. 6 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that after three days of crucial talks with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa, "I believe that the conditions for a negotiation exist" for black and white Africans to settle the key problems of Rhodesia and South-West Africa before violence engulfs the area.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 6 The sparsely filled seats of the Long Beach Arena, with its makeshift plywood hill, didn't look like "never-never land." In fact, the main floor of the arena, which had been roped off with plastic blue and white flags, looked rather amateurish for what was billed as the World Professional Skateboard Championship this past weekend in Long Beach.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 Two political scientists who have completed a massive statistical study of American voting registration laws said yesterday that turnouts in Presidential elections would probably grow by more than 10 percent if all states made registration much easier.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 6 On Labor Day, the Giants did not rest.

ST. IGNACE, Mich., Sept. 6 (UPI) Jerry Root and Verna Coger exchanged wedding vows today in the middle of a five-mile bridge that is open to pedestrians only on Labor Day. The ceremony was atended by 26,500 persons, including Gov. William G. Milliken.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (UPI) The Procrastinators Club of America celebrated its "Be Late for Something Day" by putting it off until next year.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5 A Federal District Judge has rejected a lawyer's demand that the judge step down because he has shown "personal bias" in a case involving allegations of the most extensive police misconduct in Montgomery in 15 years.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 6 (UPI) Five black African Presidents opened a meeting here today to discuss strategy for gaining black majority rule in southern Africa end heard reports from leaders of liberation movements in Rhodesia and South-West Africa.
Bill Hardey, a restaurateur whose name and taste survive in the Bill's Gay Nineties restaurant at 57 East 54th Street, died Saturday in his home at 400 East 57th Street. He was 82 years old.

A review by the state of competitivebidding procedures used by food distribution sponsors in the Summer Food Service Program here has found apparent irregularities in 80 of the 134 contract assignments.

Eustace Seligman, a prominent New York lawyer, civic leader and writer on international affairs, died Sunday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 87 years old, and had residences at 50 East 77th Street and in Greenwich, Conn.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 6 Speaking in whispers and avoiding what J.J. Jones would refer to as "eye contact," the Jets walked around their locker room in a slow-motion daze this morning as they learned which teammates had not made it into the regular season.

Ernie reports excellent duck hunting to be had on The Other Side where he hunts regularly with Clark Gable.

John K. Watson, a former partner in the law firm of Dorr, Hand, Whitaker Watson, died yesterday in Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 367 Ravine Drive, South Orange, N.J.

A letter mailed recently from New York City to a small community in upstate New York took six days to get there. It was properly stamped and carried a clearly typed address, including zip code.

Kenneth Brooks Appel, a Princeton University tennis star in the 1920's and a manager at American Cyanamid Company and Lederle Laboratories for 36 years until his retirement eight years ago, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

Foresaking country resorts and hammock-strung hideways, battalions of New Yorkers ended summer vacations and a long Labor Day weekend yesterday and streamed back into a city brushed by the crisp air of autumn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Ten more police officials have joined the Police Executive Research Forum, a new national organization designed to encourage debate and experimentation in methods of law enforcement.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 6 The Viking 2 lander has focused its television eyes on the eastern horizon of Mars and has disclosed in the images received here today a series of distant, flat-top hills. It has gazed more closely than before at the nearby rocks, many of which resemble weathered coral but are thought to be of volcanic origin.

The friend of a 22-year-old man who was stabbed to death just south of the Columbia University campus last Saturday night said yesterday that although he was at the scene when the incident occurred, "things happened so fast" that he was not aware that his friend had been stabbed in the heart.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 6 President Idi Amin of Uganda returned his presidential jet to its Israeli manufacturer today. The move appeared to be the first step toward implementing his pledge earlier this year to return all the aircraft he had obtained from Israel but not paid for.

BELGRADE, Sept. 6 Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, whose heart-transplant patients have lived up to six years, believes that within a fairly short span of years artificial hearts will be routinely implanted in humans.

Dr. Renee Richards said last night she had filed formal applications with the Women's Tennis Association and United States Tennis Association to play in their fall and winter women's tours as a professional.
A fire that the police called suspicious burned bolts of cloth and a rug on the seventh floor of Macy's department store on Herald Square last night.

Herman L. Weiss, a director and vice chairman of the General Electric Company, died yesterday of cancer in Memorial Hospital in New York City at the age of 60. Mr. Weiss, who lived in Greenwich, Conn., had spent 37 years with General Electric, rising from a craftsman in its lamp division to the post he held at his death.

CAIRO, Sept. 6 The Palestine Liberation Organization was granted full voting membership in the Arab League today. Meeting in regular session following Saturday's emergency conference on Lebanon, the league made the organization its 21st member.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 6 The Government of India, continuing its stepped-up program of birth control, has decided to limit the size of its employees' families to three children each.

After four years of lobbying threatening and cajoling, the chemical industry believes that, in regard to control of toxic substances, it has won the best deal possible in a bill passed by the House of Representatives last week.

Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, in an audit report, gave the city's Office of Neighborhood Services a generally good bill of health yesterday, but found instances of overstaffing, lax fiscal management and tardiness in seeking available financing.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 6 (AP) The Baltimore Colts, clearly demoralized by the sudden resignation of their head coach, Ted Marchibroda, held a players' meeting today and discussed a possible boycott. Meanwhile, assistant coaches reportedly considered resigning, and one city official warned of a possible "rebellion by the fans."

DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 6 Senator Robert J. Dole came to the Southern 500 stock car race here today to face down Jimmy Carter and prove that the Republicans intended to make the South a "battleground" in this fall's Presidential election.

AMSTERDAM, Sept 6 (Reuters) The 79 passengers and five crew members at a Dutch DC-9 airliner freed in Cyprus yesterday after being held by three Arab hijackers arrived here today to an emotional welcome.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 6 Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive announced today that the county would receive almost $148 million in Federal funds for sewer construction that would bring lower sewer taxes and an increase in employment.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 Dave Kingman doesn't know why, he says, but he seems to hit better at 60-year-old Wrigley Field than at most other National League ball parks. He couldn't explain the reasons today, but substantiating evidence was a king-sized home run and a double off the center-field wall that accounted for these runs in a 7-4 triumph for the Mets over the Chicago Cubs.

Among life's less-sought-after encounters must be included those with the Internal Revenue Service. Nevertheless, some two million of the more than 70 million individual tax returns filed each year are likely to be audited by the I.R.S.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 6 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation has entered the investigation of a predawn bomb blast today at a high school here. Despite the bombing and sporadic night-time disruptions by antibusing protesters, school officials said that classes would resume on schedule tomorrow throughout the city.

Eleventh Street between Avenues A and B was not looking its best yesterday, but that was before the East 11th Street Housing Movement and the neighborhood's Adopt-a-Building program decided to celebrate Labor Day by laboring.

KUWAIT, Sept. 6 (Reuters) The Kuwait Government has ordered the weekly newspaper Al-Risala to close for three months. The publication was the fourth to be suspended since the Government acted to control the press a week ago.

Overeaters Anonymous, an organization that fights food addiction, arrives in Paterson tonight at 7:45 for the first in a series of meetings at the Schneider branch of the Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association, 39th Street near McLean Boulevard (Route 20).

CAPE TOWN, Sept. 6 Last week's disturbances here, touched off by marches of colored schoolchildren, have alarmed white South Africa perhaps even more than the earlier rioting by blacks in cities across the country.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6 Intrepid Hero set a course record today in winning the $100,000 United Nations Handicap at the Atlantic City Race Course. The 4-year-old son of Forli ran the mile and three-sixteenth race on the grass in 1:52 3/5 and won by threequarters of a length.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 6 When Stanley Dancer sold Oil Burner early last May for $40,000, he said the 3-year-old colt "just wasn't aggressive enough" to keep in the barn. Even an expert horseman like Dancer can make an occasional mistake.

Unable to create excitement by losing enough games to manufacture a pennant race, the Yankees discovered a way to add spice to their lives last night in a 6-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium.

SWING HIGH If any proof is needed that country music has come a long way from Nashville, there's the opening tomorrow, 65 floors above Manhattan, of a whole festival of strawcircuit performers country singers, dancers and groups from Tennessee and Texas at the Rainbow Grill in Rockefeller Center. This is the first country-style roundup in the cabaret's 42-year history (with a down-home menu added to the regular fare).

GREENVILLE, S.C., Sept. 6 (UPI) Bill Peeples, the managing editor of The Greenville News, died today of an apparent heart attack while vacationing in St. Augustine, Fla., with his wife, Edith, and daughter Ann. He was 51 years old.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 7 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is expected to fly to southern Africa next week to resume attempts to negotiate solutions to the white-black conflicts in Rhodesia and South-West Africa.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and four of the five friends and associates indicted with him 10 months ago on Federal charges of mail fraud and bribery come to trial here tomorrow.

The Sucrest Corporation, one of the largest sugar refiners in the nation, asked that its stock be suspended from trading by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday because it could not meet a deadline for filing its annual report for the year ended last May 29 with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 Mayor George R. Moscone will nominate tomorrow Budget Director Rudy Nothenberg to be the city's sixth chief administrative officer, by charter the most powerful appointive position in the local government.

The sale of tickets to New York State's first instant lottery, officially scheduled to get under way today, had an embarrassingly premature, albeit successful start yesterday as several dealers in the city and upstate sold thousands of the $1 tickets.

Despite the availability of billions of dollars of aid for college students, many potential recipients may not be getting their maximum benefits because they lack the know-how to cope with the system.

CHICAGO, Sept.7 (AP) After an estimate by a private crop analyst that there would be less corn and soybeans produced this year than the Government had forecast, several commodity futures advanced the permissible daily limit on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

The Justice Department yesterday won an attempt in court to compel two special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to appear before a special grand jury investigating allegedly illegal burglaries and possible criminal violations of civil rights by them and other agents.

The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms recently advanced a proposal to inspect foreign vineyards and wineries that ship to this country. The purpose would be to insure that their wine conforms to United States standards, particularly with regard to additives.

CAPE TOWN, Sept. 7 (Reuters) At least two people were shot to death and scores were wounded here today when paramilitary policemen clashed with rioters in a fresh outbreak of racial violence, the police reported.

Representative Peter A. Peyser charged yesterday that violent crime was out of control in New York City and asked that President Ford provide emergency funds "to put more public-safety officers on the streets now to slow down and eventually stop these terrible and sickening attacks on our people."

Some securities analysts began recommending the Rucker Company, a major producer of such oil company goods as drill bits and blowout preventers, as a turnaround industry more than a year and a half ago.

FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 7 Approval for the Concorde supersonic airliner to land in New York is likely in the next two or three months, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said here today.

TORONTO, Sept. 7 Bob Gainey, playing in his first Canada Cup hockey game, scored two goals tonight as Team Canada defeated Team Sweden, 4-0. The Canadians had to overcome a ragged start performance in beating the inconsistent Swedes and, particularly in the opening period, relied heavily on the sturdy goaltending of Rogie Vachon, who stopped 28 shots.

DETROIT, Sept.7 The Ford Motor Company today introduced a 1977 model lineup that is essentially the same size and weight as last year's because, the company said, there is still a market for big cars as they have been built.
Charles McHarry, a columnist for the New York Daily News, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Peter Cooper Village.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UPI) The Regional Transportation Authority board today voted to offer $7.5 million to the bankrupt Rock Island Lines in a purchase-of-service agreement.

Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that affiliates of a major association of New York City summer food sponsors were operating $7.6 million worth of programs in four other cities, and charged that their contracts in those cities indicated collusion with two New York City caterers.

"Thames on 9" is turning out to be the most intriguing television project of the year. While WOR/Channel 9 provides Thames Television with a Monday-through-Friday showcase for its better productions, the New York metropolitan area is being afforded an invaluable glimpse of what can be found in Britain, at least occasionally, on the single commercial channel that competes with the British Broadcasting Corporation.

NL Industries Inc. and the Rucker Company of Oakland, Calif., agreed to merge in an exchange of stock amounting to between $164 million and $165 million. Discussions between the two companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange were held from Friday until Monday in California, with final approval voted by both boards of directors.

Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that affiliates of a major association of New York City summer food sponsors were operating $7.6 million worth of programs in four other cities, and charged that their contracts in those cities indicated collusion with two New York City caterers.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 An American team that was considered to have no chance in the Canada Cup '76 managed tonight to tie Czechoslovakia, 4-4, in a contest at the Spectrum.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 7 Geoffrey G. Peterson, a 30-year-old former legislative aide to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, won a surprise victory tonight in the state's only Congressional primary this year.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 7 Nine Government witnesses testified today that it was common practice to contribute 1 percent of their salaries to the Town of Hampstead Republican Finance Committee, but all of them denied that they had been coerced into doing so.

WOODBURY, L.I. Just as the etiquette books would recommend, the uninvited guest did not disturb the dozen dinner guests at a Long Island estate recently. Rather, he unobtrusively helped himself to whatever he could find in the bedroom, then slipped away into the thick woods, without a guest spilling a drop of soup in terror. This is how one commits a burglary in the better circles.

Joseph C. Berkwit Sr., who retired three years ago as a maritime executive, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Berkwit, who had residences at 799 Park Avenue and in Hollywood, Fla., was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Several of President Ford's key political advisers said today they believed the controversy over whether Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, accepted illegal political contributions from the Gulf Oil Corporation would soon "blow over," as one of them put it.

Joan Micklin Silver, the independent director whose first film, "Hester Street," scored with the critics and public alike, will start shooting her second production, "Between the Lines," in Boston on Monday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 5 The Free Speech and People's Park struggles are long gone, but Berkeley has become a mecca for a new, equally radical movement the growing numbers of handicapped people who are determined to live independent lives in the community, out of their family basements, out of the institutions that have kept them hidden for so long.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 7 A California man has been arrested for allegedly kidnapping a wealthy Kings Point, L.I., business executive 22 months ago and releasing him unharmed after the payment of a $750,000 ransom.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 7 The Suffolk County Commissioner of Aviation was indicted today for turning off the instrument landing system at Suffolk Airport as a plane was approaching in a thick fog. The action was reportedly taken to keep a principal in a hotel purchase, who was in the plane, from consummating the deal.

Partitioning of a territory is not an ideal solution to a problem of recurring violence but it is sometimes the least unsatisfactory way out of a chronically dangerous situation. So it should be with the new agreement for partitioning the joint security area at Panmunjom between the forces of North Korea and those of the American-led United Nations Command.
A Paris-based investment bank partly owned by Arab interests has purchased a nearly 10 percent stake in Reynolds Securities International, the Big Wall Street brokerage firm said yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 7 (AP) Drugs with a value estimated at $200,000 to $500,000 when sold illegally were stolen from the McKesson Robbins Drug Company warehouse here yesterday, the police and Federal officials said.
Kaunda Kenneth David Kaunda is the first and only President of Zambia since the territory that was called Northern Rhodesia gained its independence from Britain in 1964.

UMTATA, South Africa, Sept. 6 When the bull-crested banner of the Transkei is raised here on Oct. 26, signifying the independence of Africa's newest country, the band will strike up "Nkosi Sikeleli Afrika," or "God Bless Africa." But Africa, and most of the world, will be looking the other way.
AJACCIO, Corsica, Sept. 7 (Reuters) Corsican militants favoring home rule today blew up an Air France airliner parked at Ajaccio airport, police sources said.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 Jimmy Carter said today that, unlike President Ford, he would have dismissed Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for accepting gifts and personal services from members of his staff.

The credit markets advanced yesterday morning but then faltered, prices slipping back and closing little changed from their levels last Friday. The downward drift in prices in the afternoon resulted from disappointment that the Federal ...
The Boston Red Sox made their final Yankee Stadium appearance of the year last night, and not even old Luis Tiant could reverse the fortunes of baseball war that one summer had brought.

It is widely believed that there are no modest bridge players at any rate in the higher echelons of the tournament world. If there is such a player, he has so far failed to come forward and claim the honor.
Controversy over 30 seconds of radio time continued to overshadow an entire day of campaigning by the five Democratic candidates for the United States Senate from New York yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 7 An American oil-drilling vessel under contract to Egypt has been stopped twice by Israeli gunboats since Saturday from prospecting in the Gulf of Suez.

Vacations are over. This week and next, pupils across the country are entering, or returning to, school. They may go back with mixed feelings; but as they look toward a new school year, few are likely to experience the sense of gloom that seems to affect the adult view of education's present state.
Dim light has long created problems for amateur photographers who want to take candid color shots at parties or of their children opening presents at Christmas.

BOSTON Some years ago, Prof. Bruce Ames, a University of California molecular biologist, noticed a list of chemical preservatives on a bag of potato chips that his young son had asked him to open. His concern about the possible health hazards of the chemicals led to what proved to be a futile search for relevant information.
TOKYO, Sept. 7 The United States notified Japan today that it would grant political asylum to the pilot of the Soviet MIG-25 jet fighter that landed in Japan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that an investment adviser had failed to disclose the possible risk of devaluation of the Mexican peso in inducing thousands of Americans to invest in highyielding peso notes offered by the Mexican equivalent of savings and loan associations.
As a new football season begins, a few moments of reflection on how some American philosophic attitudes are both shaped and reflected by this entertainment might be appropriate.
The stock market, after some early hesitation, closed-higher yesterday, aided by strength in blue-chip, gold and electronic issues.
Capitalism is stumbling toward its end, which will come, not with a bang but with a whimper.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 United States business has revised upward its plans to invest in new plant and equipment for the final quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

The United States and allied intelligence services regard expected access to the MIG-25 that a Soviet pilot flew to northern Japan on Monday as the most important East-West coup since the Russians shot down an American U-2 spy.

Nearly 51,600 black students and white students were bused without incident yesterday from neighborhood schools in Louisville, Ky., Omaha, Dayton, Ohio, and Milwaukee for a better classroom racial balance. Boston officials hoped to continue the peaceful busing pattern today.

John McCandish King, former chairman and chief executive officer of the King Resources Company of Denver, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison after being convicted on fraud and conspiracy charges.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 4 In the late 1950's, Central High School became the world's most notorious public school. Segregationists pointed daily to the strife there to prove that white and black students in the South could not go to school together in peace.

The by now almost chronic warnings about the fiscal crisis of the nation's colleges and universities are not phony cries of "wolf"; they point to an all-too-real wolf closing in on the campuses, while the public fails to heed the warnings.

Air travelers have long been simultaneously irritated and mystified by the airlines apparent practice of overselling flights on the theory that many people with reservations do not show up. United Airlines may not have soothed its bumped passengers, but it has recently enlightened them.
A 13-year-old Bronx girl has been arrested and charged with setting 17 fires in midtown Manhattan stores in recent weeks.

The two contenders in the heated race for the Democratic nomination from the 21st Congressional District, which takes in the South Bronx, Representative Herman Badillo and Councilman Ramon S. Velez, have agreed to appear in a debate on Monday, the day before the primary.
George Harrison, the former Beatle, was found guilty yesterday of "subconsciously" plagiarizing the 1962 John Mack tune "He's So Fine" for Mr. Harrison's 1970 hit record, "My Sweet Lord."

JERSEY CITY, SEPT. 7 The Board of Education and the teachers union continued intensive bargaining tonight in an effort to head off a strike against the city's 38,000-student public school system tomorrow morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7 Capt. Robert E. Baker,75 years old, of this city, a retired naval surgeon who served for 30 years in the Navy before retirement, died Sunday, at the Naval Regional Medical Center here after a long illness.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 Jon Matlack suggested today that all the Met pitching staff needs to win any particular game is to be supported by "a halfway decent defense and four runs."

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 7 To many South Koreans, the new security arrangements agreed upon yesterday for the truce site at Panmunjom have the unhappy significance of completing the partitioning of the Korean peninsula.
SCHAGHTICOKE, N.Y., Sept. 7 A 35-year-old diesel mechanic, equipped with an ax and a soupedup chain saw, became New York State's champion lumberjack here yesterday.
TRENTON, Sept. 7 The Council of Churches of New Jersey said today that a drive by a coalition of organizations to keep casino gambling out of the state would begin Monday.
The most ambitious invasion of American television to date began Labor Day and will end at about 3 o'clock Saturday morning.

The moment of truth came at the beginning of the third set. Stanley Roger Smith, the matador of championships past, had taken the first two sets from Manuel Orantes, and the Spaniard had all but conceded the ears and the tail.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 The United States Public Health Service issued its five-year plan for health today and named as its first priority, controlling escalating health costs.

Ilie Nastase attracted a full moon and a full house last night for his match with Roscoe Tanner in the United States Open tennis championships. Despite many of the 14,418 spectators doing their best to get the fiery Rumanian angry, Nastase restrained himself en route to a thrilling 7-5, 6-7, 1-6, 7-6, 6-4 victory over the lefthanded blaster from Tennessee.

Dr. William M. Sweeney of Montvale, N.J., director of medical research at the Lederle Laboratories Division of American Cyanamid Company. Pearl River, N.Y., died Monday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J., after a long illness. His age was 55.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) The price of gold fell on major European bullion markets today in a wave of profit taking after yesterday's sharp rise, but it remained well above Friday's levels. The United States dollar held steady in most foreign exchanges.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 7 (Reuters) Princess Grace of Monaco, the former film star Grace Kelly of Philadelphia, made a triumphant return to the entertainment world at the Edinburgh International Festival last night.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 7 Some of the most powerful union leaders in Britain were jeered and heckled here today by demonstrators protesting the country's rising unemployment rate and what they regard as the labor movement's failure to demand stronger action from the Government.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 7 Keystone Pioneer, driven by Bill Haughton, won the $50,000 Hiram Woodruff free-for-all trot tonight at The Meadowlands, but another entrant stood in the spotlight following the race.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 A House subcommittee accused the Commerce Department today of fostering compliance of American business concerns with the Arab boycott of companies involved with Israel.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 7 (UPI) Flood waters broke through a 442-foothigh dam and inundated more than 5,000 square miles of Baluchistan Province, the Government said today. Entire villages were washed away, officials said.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 Jimmy Carter said today that, unlike President Ford, he would have dismissed Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for accepting gifts and personal services from members of his staff.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 7 A Bergen County grand jury indicted lawyers in New York, Illinois and Michigan today on charges of conspiring with a New Jersey lawyer to sell babies for as much as $8,000 to childless New Jersey couples.
John J. Clark, executive vice president and secretary of Boyd, Weir Sewell, Inc., steamship brokers, died Sunday in his home in Short Hills, N.J., after a short illness. He was 68 Years old.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 7 The Presidents of five black African coun- tries ended two days of talks here today without achieving their objective of reconciling the feuding factions of Rhodesia's black nationalist movement.

LONDON, Sept. 7 Jon Swain, a British newsman who was held for nearly three months by Ethiopian guerrillas, returned home today and said that a kidnapped British family of four was alive but under heavy strain.
PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 7 (UPI) Viking 2's vital biology instruments have passed their first test and appeared ready today to begin man's second attempt to search for life on Mars Saturday.
WASHINGTON As America's children return to school, many conscientious parents are genuinely uncertain whether they may be delivering their children into enemy territory.

"Can you tell if an extra sardine comes into a can?" This was Sam Osman's way of trying to estimate if the city's mammoth Bicentennial celebration in July, which brought millions of persons downtown for Op-Sail and fireworks, has had any enduring influence on business for him, or for the area.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 Plans for a new international citizens action organization, sponsored by a group of prominent figures in many fields and aimed at expediting solutions to a wide array of human problems, were disclosed today.

CAMERA MAN Some photographers would be famous if they only survived six plane crashes, a battlefield explosion and a beating by six men during a demonatration. But W. Eugene Smith, now in his late 50's, and who has been through all that, is famous because of the photographs he made in 19 years at Life magazine and since.

Calvin Simmons, a black conductor associated with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, made his New York debut Sunday night with the American Symphony in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park, Very lanky, very spry, he is only 25 years old, and looks it. But he led the orchestra with plenty of confidence and authority.

It may come as a surprise to many people to learn that food cooperatives may purchase articles from brand-name processors as well as from wholesale produce and meat dealers whose willingness to deal with co-ops is widely known.

PARIS, Sept. 7 Intelligence information reaching Paris today said that President Idi Amin of Uganda has planned a "revenge operation" against Kenya.

Jimmy Carter said yesterday that, if he is elected President, he would try to persuade business and industrial leaders not to move their headquarters from New York, thus arresting a deteriorating economic situation that he said "is feeding on itself."

This is how one commits a burglary in the better circles.

Steel production for the week ended Sept. 4 fell to its lowest level since the week ended last Feb. 28, when 2.46 million tons of raw steel were poured and the production capability level stood at 82.3 percent.

Instant lotteries, such as the offer for immediate payoffs in the gambling game on which New York State starts selling tickets today, have met with success and popularity, according to reports from other states.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 How embarrassing. Before a distinguished audience of diplomats, legislators, musicians, critics (some 60 are in Washington for the Music Critics Association meeting) and other well-wishers, American technology failed.

Abraham Hirschfeld, who is generally believed to be trailing in the five-way race for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senator from New York State has already spent at least $465,000 of his own money on his campaign more than most of his opponents have raised for their entire campaign.

Although Dom Anile, the C.W. Post football coach, knew his teams had won 39 games and lost only 11 for a .780 percentage over the last five years, he did not know this placed the pioneers fifth in the nation among Division III small-college teams for that period. He did not even know that his own coaching record of 59-22 in eight seasons at Post was 11th best among Division III coaches.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 7 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is expected to fly to southern Africa next week to resume attempts to negotiate solutions to the white-black conflicts in Rhodesia and South-West Africa.

A total of 40 percent of the welfare cases accepted in one month by a frequently-criticized Upper East Side center were ineligible for public support, state investigators said yesterday. They recommended that administration of the center be taken out of the city's hands.

After all the laborious effort that has gone into amending the Clean Air Act of 1970, there is an acute danger that heavy pressures from both the automobile industry and the utilities, coupled with remarkably inept scheduling, will scuttle the entire legislation.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 7 A Bergen County grand jury indicted lawyers in New York, Illinois and Michigan today on charges of conspiring with a New Jersey lawyer to sell babies for as much as $8,000 to childless New Jersey couples.

ROME, Sept. 7 Two neo-Fascists charged with bombing a Milan bank seven years ago were sent today to forced residence on a tiny island off the Tuscan coast after having been released from jail last week. Sixteen people died in the bombing.
WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 7 (AP) Harvey H. Olson, a long-time Hartfordarea broadcaster and news official, died at home yesterday. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 President Ford and Governor Carter are now charging one another with "flip flopping" on the Presidential campaign issues, but the voters should not be deceived. For this is obviously a contest between Mr. Flip and Mr. Flop.

General Electric, in a negotiated settlement with the Department of Environmental Conservation, has agreed to pay $3 million toward cleansing the Hudson River of highly toxic PCB's that it dumped there. The company has also agreed to pay $1 million for research on ending the problem.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 7 Henry A. Kissinger was asked the other day aboard his Air Force jet whether time was not running out on his African peacemaking mission. The questioner had in mind the American election and the good chance that no matter who wins in November, there will be a new Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 President Ford, establishing a pattern for a back porch campaign, used the White House today as a setting to demand an accounting of Americans still missing in Vietnam, for the most part, in the White House. to display compassion for flood victims and to further his thesis that vetoes are a vital tool of government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Milan's renowned La Scala Opera made its historic debut in America here tonight before an audience that was both glittering and demanding.

Representative Robert L.F. Sikes, reprimanded by the House of Representatives for his financial dealings, won renomination today in his northern Florida district and virtually guaranteed himself a 19th term in Congress.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 (UPI) The Communist Party filed petitions with the State Board of Elections today to put candidates for President, Vice President and United States Senator on the statewide ballot in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 The Senate blocked today a scheduled cost-of-living pay increase for members of Congress but agreed to allow the raise for Federal judges and top-level officials of the executive branch.

Deep in the belly of the clubhouse at the West Side Tennis Club, in an underground office paneled with wood and tiled with linoleum the color of fresh green beans, the busiest man in the borough of Queens is chain smoking and answering the telephone. His office most closely resembles those of insurance salesmen who rent business space near railroad stations.
LONG BRANCH, Sept. 7 For a week, despite a major break in its midsection, a concrete "sandgrabber" was overcoming beach erosion by building up sand on a test beach at Matilda Terrace.

When Joanne Bashold telephoned her parents last week to tell them she had given birth to a baby daughter, she sounded "terribly happy," her mother recalled yesterday, and she asked for $23 to buy a crib.

TEL AVIV. Sept 7 New Yorkers crowded out of congested medical schools at home will be helped to become physicians by the State of New York in a four-year study program at Tel Aviv University.
JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 7 Prime Minister John Vorster returned to South Africa today and immediately briefed his Cabinet on the outcome of his weekend talks in Zurich with Secretary Kissinger.

By BOYCE Studies of ancient and modern teeth from Japan and China have led an American anthropologist to conclude that the Japanese people of today are descendants of a colony of Chinese people who sailed to Japan about 2,200 years ago and displaced a culturally more primitive people who had been living there for thousands of years.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7 Finance Minister Donald S. MacDonald announced today that limits on company profits, enforced under the Government's anti-inflation program, would be relaxed slightly to encourage lagging investments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 A prominent nuclear energy expert has concluded that the 75 million gallons of high-level radioactive waste and the 51 million cubic feet of low-level waste now stored at nine scattered locations in the United States represent a major health hazard.

PARIS, Sept. 7 Western Europe's recovery from its most devastating postwar economic recession has slowed, and experts here are unsure whether the economy has merely entered a "pause" as the current softening in the United States is being characterized or whether the problem is more severe.
Dr. Milton W. Willenson, owner of the Germain School of Photography, died Sept. 1 at his office in Manhattan following a heart attack. He was 60 years old.
Lester S. LaPierre, a retired architect, died Sunday at his home in Sea Cliff, L.I. He was 85 years old.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 3 A new con- flict between Brazilian Indians and whites in which two settlers have been killed has been provoked in the Amazon in re- cent weeks as 5,000 poor white squatters have invaded land set aside for the Surui tribe.

PULASKI, N.Y. Thousands of salmon many of them believed to be seriously contaminated by Mirex, PCB's and other toxic chemical compounds have begun to leave Lake Ontario to begin their annual spawning run in the rivers and streams that flow into the lake.

Fifteen hundred handicapped children who are taught in their homes will have the time they spend with teachers cut in half this year as a result of a New York City Board of Education action eliminating 60 percent of the teaching jobs in education of the homebound.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)--Renewing his criticism of Secretary of State Kissinger Senator Jesse Helms said today that Mr. Kissinger should either embrace the Republican Party platform or "resign immediately."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--Daniel Schorr sought today to define the issues in next week's confrontation between Congress and the press by requesting that the House Ethics Committee specify how national security was violated by the publication six months ago of portions of the Pike intelligence committee report.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8--Ronald Reagan, now vacationing in Mexico, is willing to campaign for the Ford-Dole ticket this fall, his aides said today, but so far the White House has been slow to provide him with a speaking schedule.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--A former Gulf Oil Corporation lobbyist, Claude C. Wild Jr., said today that he was "confident" he had been "in error" when he said that in 1970 he gave $2,000 to Senator Robert J. Dole, now the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--Americans should be offered fewer and more powerful ingredients in nonprescription cough, cold, asthma and allergy medicines, for which they spend $735 million a year, a panel of experts has advised the Food and Drug Administration after a major three-and a-half-year study.

Ara Fitzgerald's dances are quick sketches with the advantage of snapshot observation but without any deep elaboration. Miss Fitzgerald tantalizes the eye by drawing some startling props and gestures together and then passes on to another intriguing situation. Assisted by Kathy Kramer and Joan Durkee, she presented a program of works Tuesday evening at the American Theater Laboratory.
Four varsity sports that were dropped from the city's Public Schools Athletic League boys' program last year because of budget cuts have been reinstated for the 1976-77 school year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)--Government scientists have developed a new nuclear device that can be used to detect and measure uranium in a drill hole, the United States Geological Survey said today.
Margaret Philbrook Zug, managing editor at Grosset Dunlap, book publishers, died of cancer yesterday at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital, Hanover, N.H. She was 31 years old.

The Paris Opera made its American debut last night at the Metropolitan Opera House before an audience as large as New York's entire population in 1669, when the French opera company was created and New York was only a small, young, English colony.
Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, will construct a new plant on a 30-acre site in Suffolk County, it was announced yesterday by William Attwood, its publisher.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)--Star Trek fans have apparently balked the space agency's choice of name for the country's new seven-passenger space shuttle, which is to make its first orbital flight in 1979.
JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 8--Interests close to the South African Government launched an English-language newspaper here yesterday, posing a strong threat to the usually anti-Government Rand Daily Mail.

Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who held a major interest in the Franklin National Bank when it failed in 1974, surrendered here yesterday on a warrant for his extradition to Italy to face fraud charges there.
QUITO, Ecuador, Sept. 8 (Reuters)-- Ecuador threatened today to confiscate the Gulf Oil Company's assets here unless the company paid its debts to the Government.

Mayor Beame and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin unveiled plans yesterday for a new city agency and an elaborate "failsafe" mechanism to eliminate the possibility of hidden deficits in future municipal budgets.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8--One of the more persistent questions raised about Soviet foreign policy is why the Soviet Union has built up its military strength while pledging its commitment to detente with the West.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Sept. 8--The Suffolk County Legislature, in what was believed to be the first action of its kind by any local government in the country, agreed today to begin buying $21 million in development rights to eastern Long Island farmland to keep it out of the hands of real estate developers.

BLOOMFIELD, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP)--Like a shimmering white velvet snake, the 24-mile-long curtain of the artist Christo Javacheff began winding its way across the northern California countryside to the sea today.

TOKYO, Sept. 8--A group of 20 Japanese specialists on military equipment, headed by Gen. Yasuo Matsui of the Air Force, participated today in a joint examination by Government officials of the Soviet MIG-25 that was flown to Japan on Monday.
The recent turbulence in Europe's money markets, which undoubtedly has abated only temporarily, reflects the strain between economic reality and political aims.
The tricentennial is fast upon us, at least at the Treasury Department where Secretary William E. Simon dedicated a time capsule yesterday to be opened 100 years from now.
New York City's Police Department will substantially increase the number of officers assigned to midnight-to-8 A.M. patrol duty under work schedules to go into effect soon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)--New standards to protect the quality of the air in areas where it is clean now were tentatively approved today by the House.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 8--The faculty of Adelphi University went on strike this morning after five months of negotiations failed to achieve a new contract.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8--Although the United States has been portrayed by some candidates in the American election campaign as losing ground to the Soviet Union, Moscow has been experiencing as many setbacks as successes in trying to advance its foreign-policy goals.
TRENTON, Sept. 8--Governor Byrne signed a bill today repealing the state income tax as of June 30, 1978, but he warned that the Legislature would have to re-enact it or some other major tax.

The Kennedy Center will use a theater not on its own premises to offer the American premiere of Tom Stoppard's double bill, "Dirty Linen New-Found-Land." It has rented for six weeks the West End Theater in Washington and will offer the British playwright's new work there starting Wednesday, Oct. 6.

The mayor contractor for the newly reopened Tavern-on-the-Green led a group of pickets in front of the fashionable restaurant yesterday, protesting what he called the failure of the proprietor to pay for $194,596 worth of work done on the building.
The stock market encountered profit taking pressures yesterday after its recent strong advance and closed mixed in accelerated trading.

A capable cast gave a comfortable glow to the first "Marriage of Figaro" of the young New York City Opera season. Production values were in good order at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night, the ensemble numbers came off with reasonable precision, and while the performances never really caught fire, they stated Mozart's case with gentle charm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--No Federal estate tax was paid on a collection of memorandums and correspondence belonging to J. Edgar Hoover, the late Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ,that has been characterized by Mr. Hoover's longtime secretary as his personal property, a House subcommittee has learned.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 8 (UPI)--The United Rubbers Workers strike against the last of the four major rubber companies, B.F. Goodrich, ended tonight with unanimous ratification, of a new contract by the six local unions representing Goodrich workers.
PHOENIX, Sept. 8--Representative Sam Steiger defeated Representative John B. Conlan yesterday in a bitterly fought contest for the Republican nomination for the Senate.

SAN ANTONIO, Sept. 8--A week after effectively devaluing its currency by almost 40 percent, Mexico has begun an offensive to increase its exports to the United States by holding its largest-ever trade fair in this southwestern American city.

TORONTO, Sept. 8. (Reuters)--Thousands of people who put their money into Bernard Cornfeld's Investors Overseas Service (IOS) in the 1960's only to see the financial empire crumble will get some of their money back.
The new New York State instant lottery opened yesterday with long lines of buyers mobbing newsstands, supermarket counters and candy stores throughout the state.

Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, who said he was "forced to decide between two valued friends," yesterday endorsed Representativ Shirley Chisholm for re-election in Brooklyn's 12th Congressional District.

Scott Christianson, chief of a State Commission of Correction team--who reported in July that conditions at Attica Prison were "just as bad, perhaps worse" than before the bloody inmate rebellion that began five years ago today--has been dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--Jimmy Carter suggested today that United States foreign policy could be more effectively used as a lever to advance human rights in Communist nations and in repressive regimes that are friendly to America. But he proposed few specific steps to reach the goal.
The city's eight brand new doubledecker buses are proving to be a tight fit. They are too tall for some of the traffic lights, wires, lamp posts and old tree limbs along their new routes.
The Cincinnati Reds are not making much progress in contract talks with Don Gullett, their 25-year-old lefthanded pitcher.

ST. HELENA, Calif., Sept. 8--Neil MacVeagh is a widow who owns a ranch here at the upper end of the Napa Valley, in the grape country north of San Francisco Bay. She is a Democrat. But if she had to vote right now, she would vote for President Ford.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 8--Jersey City teachers joined clerks and secretaries on the picket line today and effectively blocked the scheduled opening of schools for 38,000 students.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--Sworn statements by 65 cadets accused of cheating at the United States Military Academy at West Point assert that nearly 700 of their colleagues, including highranking students and captains of athletic teams, engaged in such practices as cheating in academic courses, lying to officers and even "fixing" student honor boards to obtain not-guilty verdicts.
The Sorg printing Company, a large financial and corporate printer, has decided to remain in New York City and consolidate its operation in a single new site in lower Manhattan.

New York is one of only three states-- along with Florida and Montana--that lost jobs, during the year ended last June, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics reports yesterday. The 47 others showed gains.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 8--Prime Minister John Vorster, speaking tonight at a rally of the ruling National party, said that he would meet early next week with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia. The meeting, in Pretoria, the South African capital, will be the first between the two men since South Africa publicly committed itself to support moves toward black majority rule in Rhodesia.

BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 8--Britain's effort to rebuild its economy through a policy of severe wage restraint received a potentially crippling blow today when the National Seamens Union called a nationwide strike over a wage dispute.
FANJEAUX, France, Sept. 8 (AP)-- Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre reiterated his defiance of Pope Paul VI today at a ceremony at a convent of dissident traditionalist nuns.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept.--8 President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania arrived in Yugoslavia today for four days of talks with President Tito at a mountain retreat.
Q. What are the most vulnerable aspects of the program and the background of your Democratic opponents that the Republican candidate could most successfully attack?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--A proposal that B'nai B'rith support state aid to religion-sponsored schools "for services and activities that are wholly secular in nature" prompted spirited debate, but was rejected in committee here today at the B'nai B'rith biennial convention at the Washington Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--Despite the fabled curse of King Tut's tomb, everything went smoothly today at a news conference held by the National Gallery of Art and preview of the "Treasures of Tutankhamen" exhibition sent here by the Egyptian Government.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 8 (UPI)--Jimmy Carter's wife said today that her husband was not likely to change his position on abortion.
BOSTON, Sept. 8--Public schools opened quietly here today for the third year of court-ordered busing for school desegregation.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 8--The Ford Motor Company plans to raise prices on its 1977 models by almost but not quite, as much as the General Motors Corporation's 5.9 percent increase, Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the company, said today.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Sept. 6--The walls of David J. McDonald's retirement home are lined with pictures of his glory days as president of the United Steelworkers of America, pictures with Harry S. Truman, James A. Farley, Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Zsa Zsa Gabor. There are trophies and plaques and a framed picture of him on the cover of Time magazine.

PARIS, Sept. 8--With a newly sprouted beard and wearing blue jeans, the oncetrusted middle-aged chief accountant who vanished two months ago with $1.6 million belonging to the giant DassaultBreguet company returned to France today without the cash.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI)--A Federal judge struck down the National Football League's annual draft of college players today on grounds it violated Federal antitrust laws.
Marc F. Weil, former president of the Patrician Paper Company in Glens Falls, N.Y., died last night at Beth Israel Hospital after a brief illness. He was 65 years old and Lived in New York City.

Although more women will be working as school bus drivers, bank officials and medical technicians 10 years from now, the vast majority of working women will still be employed in traditionally "female," low-paying jobs, according to an analysis released yesterday by The Conference Board.

IRISH Brendan Behan's "The Hostage" has been tackled before in New York since it was first produced in London 18 years ago. The results have been somewhat uneven. The Unification Church, founded and headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, yesterday announced the signing of an agreement to purchase the 70-year-old Manhattan Center, at 311 West 34th Street, just west of Eighth Avenue, for "more than $2 miilion."

Four young men and a young woman were shot last night in Chinatown in what the police believed was a flare-up between members of rival youth gangs. None of the victims was seriously wounded, it was reported.

Dorothy Davis Balding of Upper Brookville, L.I., and Aiken, S.C., was married yesterday morning to William Congreve Jackson Jr. of Aiken, where the bridegroom heads his own petroleum distribution company. The Rev. John Hascup performed the ceremony in the Upper Brookville Reformed Church.
Ed Figueroa carried out his pregame plan perfectly last night, quickly dispatching the Milwaukee Brewers with a three-hitter so he could get to Puerto Rico in time for the birth of his second child.

The announced layoff of 308 New York City school supervisors has been averted, at least for the present, as the result of the Board of Education's acceptance of an offer by the supervisors' union to exchange salary adjustments for jobs.
The new New York State instant lottery opened yesterday with long lines of buyers mobbing newsstands, supermarket counters and candy stores throughout the state.
CHEMPSTEAD L.I., Sept. 8--With the force, and broad pattern, of a shotgun blast, sweeping changes were made in the Jets' lineup today four days before they open their regular season.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 (UPI)--Eugene J. McCarthy, who is running an independent campaign for the Presidency, will not have his name listed on California's ballot in November because he failed to obtain enough signatures on his petitions, a judge ruled today.

LAFAYETTE, Ore., Sept. 8 (AP)--A Southern Pacific engine and caboose struck a school bus carrying 50 persons today on the second day of schcol. The state police said that at least two persons were killed and many were injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's secondlargest company after the British Petroleum Company, has admitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission it had made $2.4 million in questionable payments since 1972, according to a document filed here late last week and made available by a commission official today. None was made in the United States.
ROME, Sept. 8 (AP)--Ugo Cardinal Poletti, the Pope's vicar in Rome, celebrated mass today in the presence of Mayor Carlo Giulio Argan, an independent allied with the Communist Party.

Help in the form of free shelter, food, parental guidance and rehabilitative work is available to children and their families at the New York Foundling Hospital Center for Parent and Child Development, but few families are using the free services, according to the hospital's director.
