The executive hierarchy at the Johns-Manville Corporation shifted quickly yesterday as John A. McKinney, president, announced a realignment of top officers in the wake of the resignation last Friday of W.R. Goodwin, the man whose management style displeased the company's directors.

Insofar as issues determine how people cast their votes for President, Gerald R. Ford's fate in November may well turn largely on how well he handles two unwanted issues he inherited from his discredited predecessor the uncertain economy and the Watergate scandal.

A check of the linen and bedspread departments in stores this fall will find murals popular as design themes. Inspired by antique patchwork and appliqued quilts, designers have picked up the charm and pictorial whimsy of the 100-year-old quilts and adapted them to new designs for pillows, bedspreads, comforters, wall hangings and even shower curtains.
The Liberal Party set the stage last night for an endorsement of the Demo cratic Presidential ticket at its convention tomorrow.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 The recent selection of an executive editor by the nation's largest afternoon daily newspaper, The Detroit News, has set the stage for a long and difficult struggle by The News to reverse its diminishing circulation lead over its fierce competitor, The Detroit Free Press, the state's only mornng daily newspaper.
HONG KONG, Sept. 9 Today's lengthy death notice on Chairman Mao left a puzzle unresolved-the cause of his death.
TOKYO, Sept. 9 (Reuters) Prime Minister Takeo Miki of Japan sent a message of condolence to the Chinese Government on the death of Mao Tse-tung, the Foreign Ministry reported.

A flare-up between two rival youth gangs in Chinatown late Wednesday night left five young people injured and gave police in the area reason to fear retaliations and a new wave of street fighting after a one-month respite.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on all provisions of the sweeping tax revision bill after adopting the first major reform of the nation's system of estate taxes in 35 years.

Washington Square Park was as quiet as a Pacific island in the wake of a typhoon yesterday, a day after baseball-bat-swinging white youths rampaged through the grounds and injured 14 black and Hispanic men.
PEKING, Sept. 9 Mao Tse-tung, the pre-eminent figure of the Chinese Communist revolution and the leader of his country since 1949, died today at the age of 82.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 The Economic Development Authority approved today the first inner-city industrial parks in the country to be sponsored by a state agency. The parks, in Newark and Jersey City, could result in more than 1,000 new jobs, officials said.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 Two hearing examiners of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners disagreed sharply today over how much of a rate increase Public Service Electric and Gas Company should be allowed.
PEKING, Sept. 9 Mao Tse-tung, the pre-eminent figure of the Chinese Communist revolution and the leader of his country since 1949, died today at the age of 82.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The Agriculture Department today raised its estimate of 1976 Soviet, grain production to 205 million metric tons, up 10 million tons from previous forecasts and 46 percent above last year's disastrous 140-million-ton harvest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 President Ford said today that Jimmy Carter's plans to reduce Pentagon spending and troop levels overseas would make it "impossible to have a defense adequate to maintain our freedom and the freedom of our friends."

For six years the 21st Congressional District in the South Bronx has enjoyed the services of a superior Representative. In return there is no reason to doubt that the overwhelmingly Democratic district will re-elect Herman Badillo in November if it has the opportunity. But it will not have that opportunity unless voters turn out in large numbers in next week's primary to choose him as the Democratic candidate.

Bellevue Hospital has filed a complaint against Dr. Michael M. Baden, deputy chief medical examiner for New York City, for allegedly discussing with his wife confidential information regarding the death of a 5-day-old baby earlier this week, according to Madeline Bohman, the hospital's deputy executive director.

The nation's money supply declined for the second consecutive week, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. The narrowly defined money supply demand deposits and currency, and known as M-1 declined $300 million in the week ended Sept. 1, compared with a revised $900million decline the previous week.

Western intelligence experts are understandably elated over the delivery of a Soviet supersonic MIG-25 fighter plane, the most advanced of its type, which was landed in Japan by a defecting pilot, Lieut. Viktor I. Belenko. Even more noteworthy than the military's access to this remarkable plane's engines, electronic gear and other equipment, however, may be the lieutenant's credo.

Like John James Audubon, the 20 bird carvers who will be showing their work this weekend at the Connecticut Audubon Society in Fairfield are artists as much as naturalists. They have had to match their craft against the subject's swiftness and its peculiarities: how it holds its head, the angles at which it stands or bends.

THE ingredients are familiar in Steve Gooch's play, "Female Transport," which opened at the Performing Garage on Wednesday and will run Thursdays through Sundays until Sept. 26. Familiar, surely, to readers of historical fiction and watchers of costume films on the late show.

Three decades and half a world away from the China he left in 1941, Fai-Ching, a chef in a Chinese restaurant, sat, stunned, in a dimly lit Chinatown bookshop yesterday and spoke of the death of Chairman Mao Tse-tung.

American astronomers who have obtained the first detailed radar images of a large portion of the surface of Venus say they reveal a possible lava flow the size of Oklahoma, an impact basin much like those on the moon and evidence of mountain-building processes similar to those that have shaped the Earth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he did not think Mao Tse-tung's death would set back Chinese-American relations, but he cautioned that "when any historical figure disappears it is extremely difficult to predict everything his successor will do."

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 The death of Mao Tse-tung has raised a possibility for the Soviet Union to relax, but not eliminate, its tensions with China, a development that could ultimately affect Moscow's relationship with Washington, according to some analysts of China here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic national chairman, conceded today that the independent Presidential candidacy of Eugene J. McCarthy was causing "some concern" for his party's national ticket by its current strength in the polls.

President Ford is playing a dangerous and highly political game in his support for a constitutional amendment that would permit the states to ban abortion. His repetition of that support at a White House news conference left little doubt that he intends to press this issue.

In rapid-fire order, the player wearing the purple jersey designating Post Position 8 mowed down the opposition. First, he broke through Churruca's service, picking up a point. Then, with points doubling for the second round of the 7-point singles match, he polished off Elu, Lecube and Aramayo.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 4 United States experts in seabed mining estimate it will take five to six years to set up a so-called International Enterprise to undertake profitable extraction of minerals from the ocean floor by 1983 the date on which private companies are expected to be in full-scale commercial operations.

R.H. Macy Company, the largest retailer in the New York area, reported yesterday a drop of 17.6 percent in earnings for its' fiscal fourth quarter, but a 58.4 percent rise for its fiscal year ended July 31. Sales were higher in both periods.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 9 (Reuters) The European Economic Community will have to import extra food and animal fodder this year to make up losses from Europe's worst drought in decades, E.E.C. Farm Commissioner Pierre Lardinois warned today.
LONDON, Sept. 9 The effects of inflation, which has been hitting the wealthier Britons for a decade, caught up with the working population in 1975, according to official statistics published today.
BELGRADE, Sept. 9 The clerk at a Belgrade department store took the new light bulb a customer had handed him, plugged it into a test socket, and when it failed to light, tossed it away with a shrug.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Congress, nearing the end of the critical phase of its budget-making process, voted today to limit Federal spending to about $413 billion, some $13 billion more than President Ford has projected, in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1.

PORT GIBSON, Miss., Sept. 9 "We're not getting any colored trade," said George Hudson as he closed up his Piggly Wiggly grocery here one night and began checking the cash register. Normally, blacks account for one-half of his customers.

ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 9 The newly formed National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives urged today that all American high schools offer courses in criminal and social justice and that the nation establish, equitable and uniform penalties for convicted criminals.

Representative Henman Badillo, who is fighting Councilman Ramon S. Velez for the Democratic nomination for the 21st Congressional District seat in the South Bronx, has been removed from the Republican line on the ballot in the general election because of "gross irregularities and fraudulent practices."

A British-American expedition believes it has found the wreck of the Bonhomme Richard, flagship of John Paul Jones, in 180 feet of water, where it sank after defeating the more heavily armed British warship Serapis in 1779.

The Anaconda Company announced yesterday that it would increase prices 1 to 5 cents a pound on all standard-size brass mill products, effective Sept. 20. Prices on extra sizes will be raised an additional 5 percent. The increases do not affect Standard stock sizes of sheet and roll copper and copper water tube and related items.

Ludwig van Beethoven, of all composers, would seem to be least in need of a society to preserve, promulgate and perpetuate his music. But he has one all the same. The Beethoven Society is now growing to the point where it bids fair to make a potent impact on the Metropolitan New York cultural scene.

American astronomers who have obtained the first detailed radar images of a large portion of the surface of Venus say they reveal a possible lava flow the size of Oklahoma, an impact basin much like those on the moon and evidence of mountain-building processes similar to those that have shaped the Earth.

Although oil, natural gas and coal are the basic fuels used to energize most of the nation's factories and heat and cool commercial buildings and probably will be for many years increasing attention is being paid to alternate energy sources.

President Ford is trailing Jimmy Carter among self-described independents and moderates, the two elements of the electorate without whose strong support Republican nominees have been unable to win Presidential elections in the postWorld War II era.

HONOLULU, Sept. 9 Three Honolulu men working on an environmental impact study were being treated today for burns apparently caused by mustard gas, a chemical warfare agent that was last used by the United States in World War I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Shortly after becoming acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1972, L. Patrick Gray 3d was advised of a number of improprieties and irregularities in the bureau's operations including the misappropriation of "thousands of dollars of public funds" by its exhibits section, according to published bureau documents.

To collectors of status symbols, owning a Cartier "Santos" watch or its later variation, the tank watch is a must. Louis Cartier first made the watch in Paris in 1907 and named it for a French aviator, Santos Dumont. It started a fad for wristwatches among the international smart set and continues to be a way an "in" person recognizes a brother in taste.
The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was planning to start trading next year in options contracts for gold and silver bullion, subject to Government approval.

Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, met yesterday with representatives of the city, the teachers and the Board of Education in a new effort to work out a pay deferral agreement acceptable to them and the the Emergency Financial Control Board.
Concern over a possible increase in inflation sent stock prices lower yesterday in slower trading, The Dow Jones industrial average was off 6.07 points to 986.87, near its low for the session.

You don't have to ponder it very long to begin to suspect that too many children are being labeled "learning disabled" these days. One widely heard estimate is that 10 to 20 percent of the nation's children suffer from such learning disabilities as subtle perception disorders and hyperactivity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on all provisions of the sweeping tax revision bill after adopting the first major reform of the nation's system of estate taxes in 35 years.

CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL is normally the scene of nervous singers and instrumentalists undergoing that most cruel of rituals, the New York debut recital. But it was filled with something quite special the other day.

PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 9 (AP) Bob Smith, often a challenger but not yet a winner on the pro tour, one-putted 12 times on his way to a six-under-par 65 today that tied him with Tom Watson and George Burns for the firstround lead in the $200,000 World open golf tournament.

Werner Lieb, a horticulturist who had owned Lieb's greenhouses in New Rochelle, N.Y., from 1922 until his retirement in 1957, died Tuesday in a nursing, home in South Yarmouth, Mass. He was 93 years old and lived in Truro on Cape Cod.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 9 (AP) Without fanfare or protests from its neighbors, Libya has issued new official maps expanding its southern border to take more than 52,000 square miles of territory from Algeria, Chad and Niger.

LONDON, Sept. 9,(Reuters) Britain and the United States embarked on aviation talks today with the British side giving notice that it wanted to break what it called American domination of world airline markets.

ARA Services Inc., large food-service company, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to buy that it must divest itself by Dec. 31 of its domestic rental operation because of a Federal antitrust consent decree. The Rental Services division, through laundries and depots in this country and Canada, rents, cleans and repairs work clothes, service apparel and linens. It had revenues last year of $75 million.

THE FIRST MAJOR institutional show of the fall season is "Shinto Arts" at the Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street. None of the objects on view there have been seen in this country before, and many are virtually invisi ble in Japan itself. They belong to the innermost sanctum of the Shinto shrine; to that sanctum neither the parishoner nor even the most qualified and dedicated scholar can normally hope to penetrate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, hinted today that he thought President Ford would be making a mistake by spending too much time in the White House during this fall's election campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 China without Mao Tse-tung is likely to become a more coercive and bureaucratic state, heavily committed to the modernization of its economy but less intent on arousing the rural masses to take part in the country's political life.

THE Israel Philharmonic Orches tra, which was last here in 1974, is back for another American tour, and it played the first of two Carnegie Hall concerts on Wednesday night, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, its music adviser and conductor and the music director-elect of the New York Philharmonic.

From 2 to 4 on Sunday afternoon, portions of Fifth Avenue will be closed to traffic in front of Brentano's bookstore, and the Amazing Randi and Bill Noble, magicians both, will offer a number of tricks; Denise Carcel and David Makoff, memory experts, will perform marvels of memory; John Towsen, a clown, will provide a comic interlude.

An old-fashioned tented circus the kind boys used to dream of running off with, the kind not seen in New York in 40 years is coming to town this weekend. Bears and elephants, trapeze artists and jugglers, clowns and fire eaters will be entertaining children of all ages, starting tomorrow afternoon, when the traveling show pitches its canvas big top in an empty lot on Second Avenue and 100th Street.

A bill to prohibit kickbacks by clinical laboratories to physicians was approved by the Legislature in Albany last June, then withdrawn, amended slightly and repassed. The slight amendment, city health authorities now believe, legalized kickbacks.

Good Housekeeping will raise its newsstand price of 95 cents a copy in October from its present 75 cents buoyed by indications that its circulation revenues in 1976 will exceed advertising revenues for the first time in memory.

A STREET CAN sometimes say as much about a city as a neighborhood does indeed, a city's great streets define its char acter as surely as its neighborhoods do. A great street, even though it is stretched out and symbolizes movement, is a place unto itself, and as vital to a sense of a city as any of its great squares, parks or monuments.

The New York State Commission of Correction will conduct hearings into an incident earlier this year in which eight guards and one inmate were injured at the Attica State Correctional Facility, Stephen J. Chinlund, chairman of the commission, said yesterday.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 9 In the confusion of the Jets' locker room, players marched in and out today like recruits at induction center.

The Knicks purchased Jim McMillian from the Buffalo Braves yesterday and the Nets were close to a deal for Nate Archibald of the Kansas City Kings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Secretary of the Army Martin R. Hoffmann once again pledged here today to investigate any new reports of Honor Code violations by West Point cadets, and he urged lawyers representing students accused of cheating at the Uniited States military Academy to give the Army such reports "without condition."

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 Jimmy Carter said today the sensitive abortion issue was a "very serious problem" for him but that it might backfire on any Presidential candidate who tried to exploit it politically. Presumably, he meant his Republican opponent, President Ford.

MOST OF THE BIGGEST merchants in the tiniest antiques will be on hand Sunday for this town's most important show of miniatures, dollhouses, toys and such. The exhibition and sale, now in its fourth year and enlarged, benefits the Hudson Guild Counseling Service, a mental health clinic of the Chelsea Settlement House. The admission charge of $2 is turned over to this charity.

The Interstate Sanitation Commission was reported yesterday to be completing a series of recommendations for eliminating the dumping of treated sewage sludge into the Atlantic Ocean just outside of New York Harbor.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) Most farm commodity-futures prices improved today, led by a late rally in soybeans.

BOSTON In 1974, Air New England, a bustling commuter airline serving the hamlets of the Northeast, managed to produce a modest profit of $78,553. Just a year later, despite a $3.2 million transfusion from the Federal Government and healthy revenues of $13.4 million, the line posted a loss of more than a million dollars.

An 11-member task force headed by Arthur R. Taylor, the president of CBS, has been named by Mayor Beame to recommend a future course for the cityowned Municipal Broadcasting System, whose budget has been cut by a third in the city's fiscal crisis.

BEDMINSTER, Sept. 9 Senators James L. Buckley, Conservative-Republican of New York, and Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, faced each other today in the first of a planned series of "dialogues" on the nation's economy by conservative and liberal spokesmen. They squared off before more than 200 business leaders from the two states.

BEIRUT, Sept. 9 Reacting with surprise to Soviet criticism of "ultraleftists" in Lebanon, the Lebanese alliance of Moslems and leftists sent a delegation to the Soviet Embassy here today to ask if there had been a change of policy.

Linda Carol Robins, associate Professor of French at the Bergen Community College in Paramus, N. J., was married last evening to Stuart Darling Shaw, who is on the business-administration faculty of the college. Rabbi Roy Armand Rosenberg perfomed the ceremony in the chapel of the Crystal Plaza, caterers, in Livingston, N.J.

TEMPE, Ariz., Sept. 9 (AP) Jeff Dankworth, the quarterback, rushed for 155 yards and scored two touchdowns, and Theotis Brown, halfback, scampered for 127 yards and two more scores to lead the University of California, Los Angeles, to a 28-10 upset of Arizona State in a nationally televised football game tonight.

LONDON Sept. 9 The Government and its allies in the labor movement held urgent meetings today in an effort to avert a strike that could damage Britain's economic strategy and bring acute political embarrassment to Prime Minister James Callaghan.

The room, which normally offers singer and comedians with a distinctly urban orientation, is featuring country music this weekend and for the next two weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 The "noname" United States hockey team became a no-goal team tonight as it was essily defeated, 5-0, by the Soviet Union squad. The Americans thus became the only team in the Canada Cup tournament with no victories.

The police said yesterday that they now believe that a 22-year-old man who was killed near Columbia University on Saturday night was murdered because he had damaged a small, spiral-bound notebook his assailant was carrying.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Amid a gathering squall of Congressional protest, West Germany delivered today a new main battle tank to be judged against tanks being developed by the United States Army.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 9 Militant auto workers remained on strike today for higher pay in defiance of arrests and threats of strong reprisals against organizers of the strike by Argentina's military Government.

Representative Herman Badillo and Councilman Ramon S. Velez traded a wide range of charges as they met in a debate yesterday for the first time in their heated Congressional primary race. The candidates for the Democratic nomination for the 21st District seat in the South Bronx accused each other of being backed by "bosses" attributed part of the grinding problems of the area to poor leadership by a "bad" Congressman or Councilman.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 10 The disclosure this week that many of Gov. George C. Wallace's bedroom telephone conversations had been surreptitiously recorded, apparently by his wife, has raised questions about the stability of the Governor's marriage.

Another development in the lengthy litigation between the heirs of Mark Rothko, the late abstract-expressionist painter, and the Marlborough Gallery in New York took place yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
MANILA, Sept.10 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who has ruled by martial-law decree for four years, today created an appointed council that he said would share his legislative powers.

HONG KONG, Sept. 10 The Hong Kong stock market plunged sharply today following the announcement of Chairman Mao Tse-tung's death, but otherwise this prosperous British colony, whose future depends on China's good will, displayed little outward reaction.

REPEATING HISTORY Another episode from this nation's revolutionary beginnings will be re-enacted today exactly 200 years after it first occurred on that Tory hotbed, Staten Island, in colorful daylong activities.

Life along the klongs, the charming odoriferous Venice-like canals of Bangkok, undoubtedly exercises a profound attraction on Thai exiles. But it is doubtful whether it was this that brought the recent sudden secret return from Taiwan of the strongman of the military regime ousted by a student revolt in 1973, Field Marshal Praphas Charusathien. Nor is it likely, as he claimed when discovered, that he came for a medical checkup. There are better doctors elsewhere.

The Federal Government has rejected a novel plan for New York City to finance construction of large sewage-treatment plants in Brooklyn and Staten Island by selling bonds to the contractors who successfully bid for the jobs.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 10 After more than two decades as a member and teacher of the men's Sunday School class at the Plains Ga., Baptist Church, Jimmy Carter brings some of the mannerisms and methods of a Sunday School teacher to the 1976 Presidential campaign.

A civil-rights group is charging that the tenant-management group that recently took over the giant Co-op City housing project in the Bronx has instituted "blatant discriminatory practices" against black applicants in filling vacant apartments. It has demanded that Governor Carey intervene.
PARIS, Sept. 10 After two months of quiet and apparently effective diplomacy, rich and poor countries are ready to resume their deadlocked talks on ways to improve distribution of the world's wealth.
Nate Archibald and Jim McMillian, a pair of New Yorkers, officially came home yesterday and Bill Bradley confirmed that he would retire after next season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Starting Wednesday morning, Aug. 25, and end ing Thursday evening, Sept. 9, with a brief Labor Day recess, an unprecedented event took place in Congress. For the firs time, the final provisions of a major tax bill were written in public.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 Ten busloads of demonstrators from an activist church in a depressed district here will picket the Fresno County Courthouse around the clock this weekend to protest the jailing of four newsmen on contempt of court charges.

What with five Democrats seeking the nomination for United States Senator from New York next Tuesday, very little attention is being paid to a Democratic primary fight in the North Bronx, though this is the only case where the Bronx Democratic organization is trying to unseat a Democratic Assemblyman.

Nickel carbonyl, one of several possible causes suggested for the Philadelphia mystery disease, has emerged as the subject of not only one of the most tantalizing hyptoheses but also in some ways one of the most improbable.

A collection of 21 tapestries depicting historic New York events, the work of the late American muralist, Albert Herter, has been offered to New York City by an Armenian school in Pennsylvania as a "Bicentennial thank you gift."
WASHINGTON, Sept.10 (AP) Retail sales rose 2.2 percent during the month, the Commerce Department reported today.

PEKING, Saturday, Sept. 11 A journey of 1,500 miles through China yesterday from Hong Kong to Canton, to Shanghai and finally to this capital found the Chinese people subdued and pensive rather than shocked and distraught after the death of Chairman Mao Tse-tung.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 10 With a strike deadline four days off, the Ford Motor Company moved closer today to the United Automobile Workers' position on two key contract issues: wages and layoff benefits.
LONDON, Sept. 10 Prime Minister James Callaghan, in a surprise move, reshuffled his Cabinet tonight.

Dyan Cannon will be there as a film director, not a movie star. So will 70 other women directors from around the world, and even Jeanne Moreau, thanks to a last minute $1,500 donation yesterday from the Celanese Corporation, which will be used to pay for the first-class airplane ticket from Paris that the actress had insisted upon.

The continuing investigations of the cheating charges at West Point have raised questions about the manner in which the Military Academy's honor code is enforced. Defenders of West Point traditions are angered by any suggestion that the code's rigidity may have contributed to the moral as well as pedagogical confusion which in turn has led to the allegation of cheating by at least 200 members of last year's junior class.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Saturday, Sept. 11 (AP) The Police staged a commando-type raid early today to capture a half-dozen hijackers and free seven crew members of an Indian Airlines jet, Foreign Ministry officials reported.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 Two airliners, one British and the other Yugoslav, crashed head on today at 33,000 feet near Zagreb, killing 176 persons in aviation's worst collision. There were no survivors.

CARDIFF, Wales, Sept. 8 The great European drought, the worst in at least 250 years, has drained Britain more than any other country and the area surrounding the Welsh capital of Cardiff more than any other in Britain. The southeast of Wales, where a million of the 2.8 million Welsh live, has gone nearly bone dry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) A General Accounting Office audit of the Nixon White House books shows a "total lack of accountability of public funds" including the disappearance of 58 typewriters worth $18,000, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 R.J. Reynolds Industries reported today that it had made more than $25 million in questionable corporate payments in the United States and overseas since 1968 to promote its business and political interests.

HONG KONG, Sept. 10 The official list of the committee for Mao Tse-tung's funeral, which was published yesterday, suggests that three senior Chinese officials, the Minister of Education, the Minister of Railways and the director of the official press agency, Hsinhua, may have lost their posts as a result of this year's antirightist campaign.

PARIS, Sept. 10 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing has put off a state visit to Yugoslavia next week because President Tito's physicians have "asked him to interrupt all his activities temporarily," Elysee Palace announced today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) A Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction today against interim regulations of the Department of Agriculture that would permit bone bits to be included in meat.
Parishioners more often comment to the Rev. Sue Ellis Mellrose on how well her voice carried rather than on what she said in her sermon.

CAVENDISH, Vt., Sept. 10 Behind a locked, chain-link gate, two and a half miles up a steep, winding dirt road that a wolf wouldn't chase a troika over, lies the American hideaway of exiled, dissident Russian author Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn.
VIENTIANE, Laos Six months ago eight letters arrived at the New Viengratri Restaurant, one of the few "people's nightclubs" left in Vientiane.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 A year ago, the Trenton Psychiatric Hospital, a state institution, lost its accreditation after the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals reported an inadequate fire-prevention program, rundown buildings and equipment, and the use of nonqualified personnel.

Repaying one's political debts is the cement that binds politicians together, and yesterday Governor Carey repaid his debt to a Democratic State Senator from Queens who had stood by him on one of the most trying days of his governorship.
WOODSTOCK, N.Y. This town has finally closed its welfare office and just refuses to pay its relief clients.

DALLAS, Sept. 10 Senator Robert J. Dole, in his first visit to Texas as the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, walked tall and talked tough today about his Democratic rivals as he did his best to turn this crucial state into an election battleground.

David Crosby and Graham Nash have attracted neither the publicity nor the public adulation accorded Stephen Stills and Neil Young, their partners in the onagain-off-again Crosby, Stills, Nast and Young super-group. But while they are not as spectacular on stage as Mr. Stills, nor as enigmatic, and therefore intriguing, as Mr. Young, they have staying power.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Secretary of the Army Martin R. Hoffmann said today that he believed "the overwhelming majority of violators" in the West Point cheating scandal had been detected and punished.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 Dalton Trumbo, the Hollywood screen writer who was perhaps the most famous member of the blacklisted film industry authors called "the Hollywood Ten," died of a heart attack early today at his home here. He was 70 years old.

The advertising consultants to both President Ford and Jimmy Carter endorsed the short television commercial as the best means of reaching the voter and asserted that the issues in the campaign would matter less on election day than the viewers' perception of the candidates' character.

Clifford J. Nuttall Sr., former manager of antiques shows and other exhibitions in metropolitan New York, died Sept. 3 at Mercy Regional Center, Vicksburg, Miss. He was 77 years old and a resident of Vicksburg.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10 Two airliners, one British and the other Yugoslav, crashed head on today at 33,000 feet near Zagreb, killing 176 persons in aviation's worst collision. There were no survivors.

Senator James L. Buckley said yesterday that the United States was pursuing objectives in its schools that had nothing to do with providing educational opportunities, and that the worst example of this was "forced busing to achieve arbitrary racial balance."

MONTREAL, Sept. 10 Six persons hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner carrying 92 people on a New York-to Chicago flight tonight, diverted it to Montreal and said they wanted to go to Europe, officials said.
With only four days remaining before the primary, several of the candidates for the Democratic Senatorial nomination and their supporters attacked each other in increasingly acerbic terms yesterday.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 10 (UPI) Consuelo Northrup Bailey, the only woman to ever serve as Lieutenant Governor in Vermont and the first woman admitted to practice law before the United States Supreme Court, died yesterday after a long illness. She was 76 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Agriculture Department reported today that hot and dry weather in large parts of major producing states during August caused continued deterioration of the country's important corn crop, although it predicted the total harvest would still set a record.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Justice Department lawyers investigating recent burglaries by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have apparently decided to forgo wholesale prosecutions of the agents in favor of focusing on those F.B.I. officials who knew of or approved the break-ins.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Spokesmen for the Roman Catholic hierarchy said today that they were "encouraged" but not "totally satisfied" by President Ford's support of a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit states to regulate abortions.

The Trans World Airlines jet commandeered on a New York-to-Chicago flight made a refueling stop at Montreal last night and flew to Gander, Newfoundland, early today amid reports that the hijackers were headed for Europe.

To lovers of fresh fruits and vegetables, this might well seem to be the time for celebration. For in spite of poor weather that has kept this year's harvest from being as plentiful as had been expected, we are in the midst of the season that offers the greatest variety of locally grown products at their peak of perfection.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 A Federal Environmental Protection Agency official told a state legislative commission today that the presence of cancer-causing agents in the air over sections of New Jersey "is a cause of great concern and something should be done about it."

St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Helen Ellis Paine to Jonathan Chilton Keith. The bride is a daughter of Augustus G. Paine of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Iris S. Russell of Locust Valley and a descendant of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. The bridegroom's parents are Norman C. Keith of Locust Valley and Jocelyn Sullivan Freer Keith of Chevy Chase, Md.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 10 Senator Walter F. Mondale said today that he did not want Jimmy Carter to be held sus pect by some voters because of "region, accent, religion," as he said John F. Ken nedy had been in 1960.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 A technical legislative measure now pending before a House committee could prepare the way for a payment of more than $100 million to 60,000 Sioux Indians for lands taken from them a century ago, according to testimony at a hearing today.
Charles H. Sheldon, an attorney and first president of the Infant and Juvenile Manufacturers Association in Manhattan in 1940, died of cancer Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) Farm commodity futures declined sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade today because of speculative liquidation in the major pits at the close. The opening had been relatively strong.

The marriage of Mary Ellen Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Murray Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Blooming Grove, Pa., to James Talcott Kelsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Kelsey Jr. of Rye, N.Y., took place in Princeton last evening.

Declaring that "a fair trial is not possible in Passaic County" for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis because of prejudicial pretrial publicity, a New Jersey judge yesterday moved their new triple-murder trial from Paterson to Jersey City in Hudson County.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 After five starting appearances without a victory, Mickey Lolich finally triumphed tonight at Busch Memorial Stadium. But he was not around at the end of a wild 4-3 victory by the Mets over the Cardinals before a crowd of 14,935 that saw some exceptionally shoddy baseball.

State and local policemen in southwestern Connecticut have disclosed details of a bizarre case involving the theft and slaughter of a $100,000 high pedigree Holstein calf and the murder of a young man on a wooded hilltop.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The production of Rossini's "La Cenerentola" that the Teatro alla Scala offered at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts last night might have seemed to have all the ingredients for success. But although it should be reported that many in the audience seemed to enjoy the results, this observer left the scene disgruntled. The ingredients stubbornly refused to blend, and the blame can be apportioned pretty equally all around.

This sensitive office has been a center of patronage that favors politically connected lawyers and is a burden on the estates of decedents and their families. The Surrogate's Court urgently requires reform through state legislation.

PINEHURST, N.C., Sept. 10 (AP) Jack Nicklaus, a winner last week in the World Series of Golf, hit one shot into a woman's purse, missed the cut for the first time in six years and George Burns stormed into a two-stroke lead today in the rain-interrupted second round of the $200,000 World open golf tournament.

The director of New York State's new and highly successful instant lottery said yesterday that some lottery vendors were suspected of cheating buyers by keeping tickets they had found to be winners and by selling those that they knew were worthless.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 A group of senior military officers told a Senate subcommittee today that the Pentagon did not learn until mid-1975 that the Grumman Aircraft Corporation had retained foreign agents two years earlier to help negotiate Iran's purchase of 80 F-14 aircraft.
"You Tarzan, me Abe." Thus spoke Mayor Beame yesterday as he looked up wistfully at two towering erstwhile movie Tarzans of another day, Johnny Weissmuller and Buster Crabbe.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 10 A lot of Pittsburgh linemen are going to fall and take their lumps trying to assist Tony Dorsett in his quest for the Heisman Trophy. But they apparently don't mind it a bit. They feel they have a share in the action.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Sept. 10 A 16-yearold youth was arrested today at his home in this Bergen County suburb and charged with the abduction, rape and murder of Kim Montelaro, a 20-year-old college student from New Milford whose body was discovered in a secluded field in nearby Washington Township last week.
COPENHAGEN, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Italy secured the backing of its European Common Market partners today for its call to the International Monetary Fund to slow down its rate of gold sales.
It is disappointing to hear that the Ford-Carter debates will be historic. One had hoped for more. Almost everything is historic these days, except for speeches, which all seem to be major.

The BankAmericard is headed for extinction at least in name. Starting some time next year, according to Na tional BankAmericard Inc., the name of this credit card will be changed all over the world to Visa, a word expected to be universally acceptable.

DALLAS Design and manufacturing know-how lie at the foundation of America's world position, both military and economic. The Soviet Union is richer in untapped resources, Europe has prolific scientists, and Asia has a billion workers. But in just 200 years we've outdistanced them all, through the peculiar genius of Americans to turn laboratory dreams into realities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 A Government-appointed commission recommended today that the controversial brain operation called psychosurgery be permitted to continue on a research basis with strict safeguards for the rights and welfare of the patients.
At 75 years of age, Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, still displays some of the vigor enthusiasm, and determination of his youth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill to ban increases in postal rates through next March 15 and to bail the Postal Service out of $1 billion of its debts.

MADRID, Sept. 10-Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez Gonzales promised the Spanish people tonight that by next June they would be able to elect a new two-house Parliament that would have the power to change the Constitution.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10 "Beautiful." "Slick as a whistle." "Never better." Those are some of the words members of the human relations team for the Jefferson County Public Schools system used to describe the atmosphere inside some of the city's public schools this term.

In the First District, Stanley L. Sklar, an attorney, is opposed by John Picariello, chief adoption clerk of the Manhattan Surrogate's Court. Because of his broad experience in Civil Court litigation, we recommend Stanley L. Sklar.
A new era with an old gimmick starts for the University of Southern California tonight when it opens its 1976 football season against Missouri in the Los Angeles Coliseum.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (UPI) Rick Reuschel, who always seems to be at his best against Philadelphia, beat the Phillies for the ninth time in 10 career decisions tonight as the Chicago Cubs triumphed, 3-2. The loss was the Phillies' 12th in their last 14 games.
CAPE TOWN, Sept. 10 (Reuters) Sporadic rioting flared again in townships around Cape Town today while the Government was announcing concessions to the mixed-race community.

John L. Shover, a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania, the first United States citizen to teach United States history in a Soviet university, died Sept. 4 at his home in Philadelphia, Pa. He was 49 years old.
Six persons hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner carrying 92 people on a New York-to-Chicago flight last night and forced it to fly to Montreal.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 10 Two days to go and the Giants are talking less about how much they dislike the Washington Redskins and more about how much they like themselves.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 10 Pathologists who met to study specimens of organs from victims of a mysterious disease that has killed 29 people in Pennsylvania agreed that the victims' lungs were damaged in a characteristic pattern, the head of the expert committee said in an interview tonight.
Edwin C. Kennedy, a retired Hearst Publications executive, died Thursday at his Exeter, N.H., home. He was 77 years old.

Helen R. Bryan, who had been executive secretary of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee in New York City in the 1940's and who had been sent to prison in 1950 for contempt of Congress after a long court fight, died Thursday in Medford Lakes, N.J., at the age of 82.

Buckley, whose one term in office has been largely negative and undistinguished, but to Representative Peter A. Peyser.

A "heavy influx" of steel imports from Japan 4.62 million tons in the first seven months of this year was reported today by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The association said the total so far this year was 20 percent more than in the comparable period a year ago.

The White Motor Corporation is holding discussions on the possible sale of additional assets, Semon E. Knudsen, chairman, announced. In recent months the company sold its White Superior Engine operation and has signed agreements in principle for the sale of its White Industrial Power Inc. (Alco) and White Engines Inc. (Hercules) businesses.
Burke Hedges, an American-born businessman who served as Cuba's ambassador to Brazil before Fidel Castro came to power, died in Houston, Texas, yesterday after a lone illness. He was 65.

Stock prices moved in a narrow range yesterday throughout the session and ended slightly higher in moderate trading.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10 Argentina's striking automobile workers returned to their jobs today. The strike, which involved 20,000 workers at its height, was the most serious that the ruling military junta has faced since it took power in March. The labor action was met by a decree threatening the strike's organizers with as many as 10 years in prison.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 (Reuters) Four Yugoslav air traffic controllers will remain in custody on suspicion of responsibility for the plane collision on Friday in which 176 people died, a judge said here today.

Inmates at the Bronx House of Detention began a peaceful strike yesterday, protesting visiting restrictions, what they termed excessive bail and the lack of speedy trials and other phases of the criminal justice system.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 (Reuters) President Tito called off a visit by a foreign head of state for the second time in a week today. Doctors have been treating the 84-year-old leader for acute liver trouble.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) The Government, far behind schedule in its mass vaccination program, signed tentative contracts today with three companies to buy all the swine flu vaccine they can produce for immunizing adults by Christmas.

The acting Federal Insurance Administrator said yesterday that automobile insurance premiums nationally were unnecessarily inflated, and he predicted that the insurance industry was headed for record profits in 1978.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 Rolling Stone magazine was born here in 1967 as a balladier sang about going to San Francisco with "flowers in your hair" and tens of thousands of young people responded with an influx that was named "the summer of love."

WASHINGTON,Sept. 13 Some uses of fluorocarbon gases the propellants commonly used in aerosol spray cans will almost certainly have to be curtailed because the gases weaken the atmosphere's protective ozone layer, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences reported today.

Tire Shadow Open Market Committee, a group of business and academic economists who meet semiannually to criticize Federal Reserve policy, issued yesterday a policy statement calling for continued moderate growth in the nation's money supply currency and demand deposits.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I. When John and Carol Muller returned to their house at the end of the summer season, they went immediately into the library and said a prayer for, among other blessings, having their house returned to them in good order.

An affiliate of the B'nai Torah Institute, an organization that has been frequently assailed for its activities in the federally financed summer lunch program for children, filed a $6 million libel and slander suit yesterday against a critic, Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, Democrat of Manhattan.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept.13 (AP) Mike Schmidt slammed two home runs and drove in four runs as the reawakening Philadelphia Phillies beat the Montreal Expos, 7-2, tonight, winning two games in row for the first time since Aug. 23-24.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 (UPI) The Argentine Government today closed a publishing house producing pro-Nazi and other anti-Semitic literature and banned, six of its publications.
The expeditions to Mars of Viking 1 and 2 have aroused worldwide interest in the possibility of finding some form of life on that planet.

The investment return on 10-year notes sold by banks fell below 8 percent yesterday as the Northwest Bancorporation, a well-regarded Minneapolis-based company that owns 81 banks in seven states, agreed to terms of $75 million of ...

ALBANY, Sept. 13-Public schools in the state, in the wake of Watergate and other concerns with lapses in morals, will soon begin to stress respect for the law, State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist said today.
Fears of a strike against the Ford Motor Company sent the stock market moderately lower yesterday in continued slow trading.
Twelve states conduct primary elections today in the year's biggest day of selection for Congressional and state offices.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People avoided a major internal strugle yesterday when its board of directors agreed to allow Roy Wilkins to remain as executive director through July 31, 1977.

The end of the deduction for the part time use of a home as an office is at hand if the Tax Reform Act of 1976 becomes law. This deduction a favorite of part-time, writers, teachers and many others would be ended for most taxpayers under provisions agreed upon by members of the HouseSenate Conference Committee that ironed out the differences in the bills passed by each chamber.

The American Bank and Trust Company, a New York institution under study by bank examiners concerned about its financial stability, declined yesterday to comment on reports flat it had millions of dollars in problem loans coupled with declining deposits.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 President Ford signed into law today the "Government in Sunshine Act" requiring many Federal agencies to open their meetings and their records to the public.
ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (UPI) A Clark College basketball player was shot and killed early this morning as he tried to rescue two women students from a man who had abducted them.

Violette Verdy, one of the New York City Ballet's most popular principal dancers, will become director of the Paris Opera Ballet next year. Rolf Liebermann, general director of the Opera, announced in New York yesterday that the French-born ballerina would assume her post in Paris after the contract of Raymond Franchetti, the current director, expired Aug. 31, 1977.

BELGRADE, Sept. 13 Yugoslavia, which has demanded American action against Yugoslav dissidents living in the United States, charged through its controlled press and broadcasts today that American "elements" were involved in the Croatian hijacking of an American airliner Friday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 In refusing to disclose how he obtained the Pike committee's intelligence report, Daniel Schorr will charge before the House ethics committee Wednesday that the investigation is irrelevant, since most of the document was published by The New York Times before it appeared in The Village Voice.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 13 (Reuters) A six-floor apartment building collapsed here early today and at least 80 people were killed and 48 hurt as they slept. The police said the final death toll could be 100.

Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, one of the "finalists" whom President Ford did not pick as his Vice-Presidential running mate, and Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, were among the 10member delegation named by Mr. Ford yesterday for the United Nations General Assembly session beginning Sept. 21.

In a rare move, Emprise Corporation has applied for pardon from the Federal felony conviction it received in 1972. Emprise, the family-owned sports and concessions conglomerate, reportedly earns $600 million annually through its various holdings in the United States, Canada, Puerto Rico and England.

TRENTON, Sept. 13 A coalition of religious groups opened a drive today to defeat a proposed constitutional amed- ment that would authorize casino gambling at Atlantic City, and said it would file suit in Superior Court here to prevent the proposal from appearing on the ballot on Nov. 2.
Jimmy Connors collected $30,000 for beating Bjorn Borg in a 3-hour-10-minute men's singles final at the United States Open tennis championships on Sunday.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 13 The South African police fired birdshot and tear gas today at crowds of black demonstrators who were attempting to enforce a work boycott among black commuters from the suburb of Soweto. The demonstrators succeeded in persuading about half of the 320,000 commuters not to go to work.
DEAUVILLE, France, Sept. 13 (UPI) Four masked gunmer broke into the Deauville casino at closing time early today and took $600,000 from customers, croupiers and an open said.

HONG KONG, Sept. 13 The Chinese armed forces are suddenly being given heightened public attention and could play a key role in any struggle for leadership of China following the death of Chairman Mao Tse-tung, analysts here believe.
HARTFORD, Sept. 13 (AP) An apartment building owner, beaten by tenants as he watched a fire damage his building last night, was arrested on arson charges today, the police said.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 13 It appeared all but certain today that the United Automobile Workers would strike the Ford Motor Company at midnight tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 Describing his performance by saying, "I couldn't throw any better than that," Tom Seaver tonight slowed the Pittsburgh Pirates' pursuit of the Philadelphia Phillies, allowing just five hits in a 5-0 victory for the Mets at Three Rivers Stadium.

Four men and a woman who staged a 30-hour traps-Atlantic airliner hijacking to promote Croatian independence were held yesterday in New York in $1 million bail each on Federal air piracy charges and also were confronted with murder charges.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 13 A tentative contract agreement was reached today on the fifth day of a strike by 2,000 teachers here. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed pending a ratification vote by union members tonight and tomorrow.

WEST POINT, Sept. 13-Affidavits implicating 700 West Point cadets or recent cadets in new honor code violations will be released for investigation and prosecution here this week, opening another chapter in the dispute over training and discipline at the United States Military Academy.

"The same old Grants." "The season is over." Some Giant fans were quick to bury their team after the opening-game lastminute loss to the Redskins on Sunday. No way. As the ancient grammarian might have said, "The Giants isn't dead." Sure, they will carry the pain of the 19-17 loss to the hated Redskins for a while.

Cocoa futures prices on the New York Cocoa Exchange moved yesterday to a record high of $1.20 a pound in terms of the September delivery, a gain of about 2 cents over Friday's price. The contract low, by contrast, was 43.46 cents a pound in June 1975.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP) Tropical storm Kathleen, which struck during the weekend, left at least 14 dead in the United States and northwestern Mexico and damaged estimated at $100 million, the authorities said today.

OTTAWA, Sept. 13 (AP) The leader of the governing party in the House of Commons, Mitchell Sharp, has delivered his resignation to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and says he wilt not seek re-election to the House in 1978.

Although "Equus" closed its long Broadway engagement last Saturday, Peter Shaffer's hit drama is already set to return. It will reopen Oct. 5 at the Helen Hayes Theater, with Anthony Perkins again playing the starring role of Dr. Martin Dysart.

Four men and a woman who staged a 30-hour trans-Atlantic airliner hijacking to promote Croatian independence were held yesterday in New York in $1 million bail each on Federal air piracy charges and also were confronted with murder charges.
NEWARK, Sept. 13 (AP) United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein says that the once heavy backlog of criminal cases in New Jersey's Federal courts has been cleared up.
WINDHOEK, South-West Africa, Sept. 10 This vast territory, twice the size of California but with a population of 900,000, is southern Africa's most serious problem after Rhodesia.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 13 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Yigal Allon denounced as "a miserable document" today a report by a Government official who recommended curbs on Arab poputation growth in Galilee.

The acting Federal Insurance Administrator said yesterday that automobile insurance premiums nationally were unnecessarily inflated, and he predicted that the insurance industry was headed for record profits in 1978.

In the contest for United States Senator in today's New York primary election, The New York Times has endorsed Daniel Patrick Moynihan for the Democratic nomination and Representative Peter A. Peyser for the Republican nomination.
New York State will repay today $250 million of 8.70 percent one-year notes, the highest-yielding publicly offered one-year issue ever sold by the state, the controller's office said yesterday.
When it became apparent in late 1974 that New York City could not redeem $1.6 billion in one-year notes, the repercussions were felt in households throughout the city.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 13 Prime Minister John Vorster, speaking on the eve of a meeting with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia, said today that he would not force Rhodesia into handing over power to the country's black majority against the white government's will.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Some uses of fluorocarbon gases the propellants commonly used in aerosol spray cans will almost certainly have to be curtailed because the gases weaken the atmosphere's protective ozone layer, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences reported today.

FAIRFIELD, Sept. 13-The Essex County Improvement Authority expects to close title this week on the Caldwell-Wright Airport here as part of its continuing effort to gain revenue for a county burdened by heavy taxes.

Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894, remarked that if you want to refute a gambit, you have to accept it. He was right, in general, although in the case of such a formidable, weapon of counterattack as the Marshall gambit, one may well give up the idea of a refutation and search for a reasonable way to decline it and stay out of trouble.
Edward C. Maguire, a labor lawyer and adviser to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died yesterday at his home, 130 East 39th Street. He was 77 years old.
A 22-year-old man who was clubbed in the head last Wednesday night during a gang attack on blacks and Hispanic people in Washington Square Park died Sunday night without regaining consciousness.

Settlement of the action brought by the State Department of Environmental Conservation against the General Electric Company is a promising advance in an extremely murky area. Whether it is a landmark agreement, as some environmentalists say it is, or a tentative and partial step forward, as others see it, there is no question that what has happened is good and may well turn out to be historic.

CHOWCHILLA, Calif., Sept. 13 Surrounded by reporters, photographers and television crews, Frank Edward Ray drove his school bus today for the first time officially since July 15, when it was stopped on a country road near here and he and 26 children aboard the bus were kidnapped.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 Ed Sadlowski, the 38-year-old insurgent steelworker from Chicago's South Side, formally announced today his candidacy for the presidency of the United Steelworkers of America, the largest industrial union in the country.

The head of the New York City Police Department's bomb section said yesterday that he had started a "painstaking evaluation" of the explosion of a bomb last Saturday in which one of his demolition experts was killed instantly and three other policemen were seriously injured.

F. Kenneth Harder, founder and chief executive officer of Harder Services Inc., a pest control and tree-service concern in Hempstead, L.I., died Sunday night in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I., after a short illness. He lived at 89 Jerusalem Avenue, Hempstead, and was 80 years old.
BLUE POINT, L.I., Sept. 13 The Suffolk County Republican committee chairman, Edwin M. Schwenk, declared today he would resign his party job in January. He has served for the last eight years.

The F.W. Woolworth Company announced plans yesterday for the sale of about $175 million in customer accounts receivable of its Woolco and Woolworth department store operations in this country to the General Electric Credit Corporation.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 13 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and the United States Ambassador, Malcolm Toon, met here today for the third time in six days to discuss a dispute concerning oil-prospecting rights in the Israeli-controlled half of the Gulf of Suez.

MANCHAC, La., Sept. 13 (UPI) A barge loaded with tons of thumbnailsized white sea shells rammed a bridge over a narrow pass between two south Louisiana lakes today, sending a truck and at least one car tumbling off the 60-foot-high span.
UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 13 The Nets began marketing the combination of Nate Archibald and Julius Erving today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a bill that would triple Federal funds to acquire land for national parks and recreation areas.

ZURICH, Sept. 13 President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania was reported today to prefer that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger give priority to resolving the question of independence for South-West Africa rather than black majority rule in Rhodesia during Mr. Kissinger's African trip.

CITY OF OPPORTUNITY Outlanders often accuse New Yorkers of being know-it-alls. It can't be helped. Living here has some drawbacks, but there is just so much going on that those who take advantage of the city have to be better informed. An example of this is the extraordinary "African Woman/African Art" exhibition that opens today at the African-American Institute.

The weekend hijacking to Paris of a New York-to-Chicago airliner has accelerated a process of official rethinking on how to deal with terrorists while the lives of hostages are regarded to be in jeopardy.

Earnings of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in the third quarter of this year will show improvement over this year's second quarter and over the third quarter of 1975. Gabriel Hauge, the company's chairman, predicted yesterday. Mr. Hauge provided no dollar estimates, but he made it clear that he expected improvement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Warnaco Inc., has made what is believed to be the first admission by a company that it was on the receiving end of questionable payments, according to a document made available by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 13 Fierce fighting reportedly broke out here today along the line between the city's Christian and Moslem quarters only hours after agreement had been announced on a new truce in the area.

LONDON, Sept. 13 The Monsanto Company started drilling for water today in the dusty earth around its factories in southeastern Wales. It also reserved 36 railroad tank cars to haul water into the plants if necessary.

Guaranteed profits and tax shelters available from ownership of day-care centers have spawned closely knit syndicates that share leases and "churn" them among themselves, according to auditors in the office of the New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Yields were mixed on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

Acting on the premise than an unregistered voter is a Democrat who got away, the New York State's top Democrats yesterday opened a drive to register 2.1 million voters in the three weeks left before registration closes for the Nov. 2 general election.

ATLANTA, Sept. 10 It happens to almost everyone sooner or later. It's late, the electric clock has stopped, you forgot to wind your Bulova and your chic $150 Mickey Mouse watch fell down the garbage disposal a week ago.

The independent Presidential campaign of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy met its deadline yesterday and filed what its coordinators believe were petitions containing enough signatures to get their candidate on the ballot in New York State.
The expeditions to Mars of Viking 1 and 2 have aroused worldwide interest in the possibility of finding some form of life on that planet.

Alan Greenspan, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that new evidence of increased consumer spending and capital expenditure commitments by industry showed that a "re-acceleration" of the current economic recovery was in process of gettine under way.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The Federal Government's oldest prisoner, Vicente Sanza, has died at 83 after half a century behind bars.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI) Federal officials said today that an investigation is underway into disclosures that a South Side contracting concern brought up scores of abandoned houses from the Federal Government, performed cheap repairs and sold them for large profits.

ORCHARD PARK, N.Y., Sept 13 O.J. Simpson's reappearance in the Buffalo lineup was a matter of cool indifference to the Miami team tonight as the Dolphins defeated the Bills, 30-21, before a crowd of 77,683 that filled almost every seat in Rich Stadium. The Dolphins displayed a precise and methodical offense that scored 13 points in the second half to bring Miami its 13th straight victory over Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 President Ford is preparing to make a comprehensive statement soon setting national and international guidelines for United States nuclear policy, three high-ranking Administration officials reported today.
Voters confused about the whereabouts of their polling places in New York City may telephone a special number 267-9800 for information, the Board of Elections said yesterday.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as a matter of national policy, recommends that its member companies release unlisted telephone numbers to law enforcement agencies or other governmental units that have subpoena power. The policy does not require that affiliates insist on subpoenas.

The Arab boycott against Israel raises difficult political, economic, legal and moral issues for the United states. The boycott is repugnant. It violates American principles and laws when it requires American companies, as a condition for doing business with Arab countries, to discriminate against American citizens because of their religion. It unfairly imposes secondary boycotts against American companies that hire Jewish employees or directors, or trade with Israel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-President Ford's strategists have decided not to start his campaign advertising on television until three days after his first debate with Jimmy Carter, even though this means that such commercials for the Democratic nominee will have a head start.

BILBAO, Spain, Sept. 13 (Reuters)-Dissent and strikes swept the northern Basque country today, and policemen in the suburbs of this industrial port broke up demonstrations with tear gas and rubber bullets.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 13 As he has been in every practice since 1965, Joe Namath was the Jets' No. 1 quarterback today. As always, he was watched by an understudy.

SOUTH LAGUNA, Calif. Sept. 13 (AP)-Maj. Gen. Robert K. Taylor, the man who commanded the United States Army Air Corps unit that dropped the first atomic bomb at the close of World War II, is dead. He was 74 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 13 A legal attack on the practice of investigating jurors and selling the reports to trial lawyers was opened here today by Godfrev Lehman, an advertising man who has served on three jury panels over the last 20 years.

TORONTO, Sept. 13 Team Canada scored four goals in the first period against a seemingly spiritless Czechoslovak squad and went on to a 6-0 victory tonight in the opener of the two-of-three game final series for the Canada Cup of hockey.

Anyone who wished to prove that women bridge players were tougher than men could point to Mamie Lee of New York. This well-known expert was in a serious automobile accident two weeks ago while returning from a New Jersey tournament.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 13 The compromise proposal by the Presiding Bishop, John M. Allin, that women be ordained to the priesthood in areas that would accept them has evoked strong but widely differing reactions from delegates to the Episcopal convention here.

Two gray cooking pots that Croatian nationalists used as fake bombs to hijack a Trans World Airlines jet plane last weekend were examined by guards during a preflight baggage search at La Guardia Airport, a security company official said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) The Chicago Bears have agreed to pay Dick Butkus, a former linebacker, $600,000 to settle a damage suit, the player's attorney said today. Butkus, a National Football League star for nine years, had charged the Bears with breach of a five-year contract.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Civil Service Commission, which has the responsibility for investigating the backgrounds of most applicants for Federal jobs, has routinely relied on the "subversive" intelligence files of local police agencies as source material in such in quiries, according to a House subcommittee.

The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation's slow response to the PCB problem in the Hudson River and its more recent state of unpreparedness in dealing with the Mirex problem in Lake Ontario raise questions as to how effective it is in protecting the environment.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP) Following are the texts of a statement by the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry on talks with the United States, and six diplomatic notes that Hanoi said had been exchanged with Washington. The texts were broadcast by the official Vietnam News Agency and monitored in Tokyo.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 13-An Admiralty Court in Haifa has temporarily blocked the Bankers Trust Company of New York and other creditors from disposing of five refrigerated ships sailing under the Israeli flag and impounded in Britain, West Germany and Japan for alleged default in debts.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 Grant Jackson, working on a five-year plan as a starter, continued making a concrete contribution to the Yankees' one-year plan tonight.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 14 Leaders of the United Automobile Workers called a strike today against the Ford Motor Company, starting at midnight.
Isaac Stern and Friends played Schubert at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, though you would never have known it from looking at the program. The composer's name was not on it anywhere.

MONTREAL, Sept. 14 On the verge of clinching the Canada Cup tournament, a vehicle it created to prove its strength in hockey, Canada has already convinced the Czechoslovaks of its superiority on the ice rink.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 14 (Reuters) A Cabinet minister today suggested that the term "apartheid" be replaced as an official name for the Government's race policies.

Alfred E. Schumacher, a former senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Monday at Woodcliff Lake Manor Nursing Home, Woodcliff, Lake, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in Ridgewood, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 President Ford's campaign debut tomorrow at the University of Michigan is more than a sentimental homecoming 41 years after his graduation.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 14 (AP) A bay filly by Northern Dancer, a Kentucky Derby winner, and a bay colt by Never Bend brought record prices at today's third session of the 33d Keeneland September Yearling Sale.

Bernard Bergman was sentenced yesterday to one year in a city prison for bribery by a New York State Supreme Court justice who brushed aside a plea bargain under which the nursing-home promoter would have received no jail term.
Supporters of the two chief contenders for the Democratic Senate nomination gathered to rejoice last night. Instead the crowds at the two campaign headquarters waited and waited and waited.

A $34,800 suit charging breach of contract was filed against Evonne Goolagong by Vic Edwards, her former coach and manager, in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday.

Maritime Fruit Carriers one of the major seagoing successes of the 1960's has seen its once proud fleet of almost 50 vessels cut to a small flotilla of ships that are either being offered on the open market for purchase or have been impounded in various countries around the world for the company's alleged nonpayment of debts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Pentagon is preparing to ask the White House to approve a military budget of about $130 billion for the 1978 fiscal year $9 billion more than it estimated only seven months ago and $18 billion more than Congress voted for the current fiscal year.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sept. 14 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight at the start of a mediating mission in southern Africa that he hopes will convince black leaders of American sincerity in seeking peaceful solutions in South-West Africa and Rhodesia.

SEATTLE, Sept. 14 (AP) Striking nurses and 15 Seattle-area hospitals reached a tentative agreement today to end one of the longest and largest health care strikes in recent history, a Federal mediator announced.

For a price reported to be "well over $1 million," Marietta Peabody Tree has sold her East 79th Street house, long a sort of salon for Democratic Party and United Nations social life. Senator James L. Buckley opened his campaign for re-election yesterday by stressing the differences between what he called Daniel P. Moynihan's liberal stance on issues and his own conservative views.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15 The engineer of the commuter train that crashed in New Canaan on July 13 testified here today that he had jammed on the train's brakes in an attempt to avoid the accident, but that the brakes had failed to slow the crowded rush-hour train.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has become the first publicly owned corporation in the nation to earn $1 billion in any single three-month period.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The International Monetary Fund auctioned an additional 780,000 ounces of its gold today at an average price of $109.40 an ounce.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Wasting no time in criticizing President Ford's campaign-opening speech today, four Democratic Senators each attacked a separate point emphasized by Mr. Ford.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Walter J. Stoessel Jr. to be ambassador to West Germany.

Jan Peive, a Latvian scientist who served as Prime Minister of Soviet Latvia from 1959 to 1962, has died at the age of 70 after a long illness, the official press agency Tass reported yesterday in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 A SenateHouse conference committee voted today to outlaw in most instances abortions performed under the Federal Medicaid program, but the committee specified certain cases in which such abortions would be permissible.

New York City's wholesale cigarette distributors warned yesterday that a strike by Local 805 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, threatened for midnight tonight, would cost the city and state $1 million a day through increased sales of untaxed bootlegged cigarettes.

LAKE CRYSTAL, Minn., Sept. 15 After reassuring the crowd that the tractor-pull would resume after the speeches, the master of ceremonies of the "farm fest" today promised them that soon they would see "Mr. Carter and his friends in just four and a half minutes we will have Jimmy Carter here on this stage!"

TRENTON, Sept. 15 Governor Byrne signed today a bill increasing the penalties against physicians and others who cheat on Medicaid charges and said that he would ask the Legislature for more money to step up investigation of the $500 million-a-year state Medicaid program.
Stock prices moved in a very narrow range throughout the session yesterday and closed slightly higher in heavier trading.

In the next 12 months there will be 600 more of those popular safety-glass bus shelters that have been springing up around town as fast as pizza stands and massage parlors.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 15 In an effort to retain Greenwich's residential character, construction space for office buildings here will be reduced from a potential eight million square feet to one million under regulations that go into effect today.

Myron F. Warner, president of Warner Vance Inc., manufacturers' representatives to variety chain stores, died of cancer on Tuesday in St. Joseph's Hospital Stamford, Conn. He was 63 years old and lived at 5 Oak Crest Road, Darien, Conn.
The steel industry, after enjoying a brief recovery from its weak performance in 1975, is again beginning to suffer from sluggish orders and, as a consequence, is laying off workers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Soybeans, soybean meal and oil futures closed on generally weak tones today, but wheat, corn and oats prices were firm to strong.

Angelo Cordero, one of America's leading riders, was unseated at Belmont Park yesterday and his misfortune brought good fortune to a lesser-known jockey.

Audrey Osborn Elliott, a leading figure in the New York real-estate world for many years, died yesterday at her home on the East Side of Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) Walter Annenberg, former newspaper owner and United States Ambassador to Britain, has announced that he is dropping American Views, a conservative newsletter he began six months ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced plans today to make the nation's largest selling antibiotic the first drug on which reimbursement cost limits will be set in programs funded by the department.

Imre Pallo conducted.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 15 (AP) Gov. Milton J. Shapp and a Volkswagen official signed an agreement today that would bring VW its first American assembly plant, create thousands of jobs and turn small New Stanton, Pa., into a bustling industrial town.
