ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP) John F. Keenan, the special state prosecutor, has received authorization from Governor Carey to pursue conspiracy charges against former Civil Court Judge Fred Moritt of Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP) Bill Robinson slammed a two-run homer, a single and drove in three runs tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat Philadelphia, 7-2, and moved within five games of the front-running Phillies in National League East. Both teams have 18 games left.

HONG KONG, Sept. 15 (UPI) In the most intimate portrait of Mao Tsetung ever released officially by China, his bodyguards portrayed him today as a frugal and self-sacrificing worker for the ideals of Communism.

Mayor Beame, whom most politicians expect to seek re-election next year, is regarded unfavorably by half of New York City's Democratic voters, a New York Times survey of voters in Tuesday's Democratic primary has shown.

After two hundred years, principles of our constitutional liberty still escape understanding.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 15 (UPI) District Attorney Jon Holcombe of Onondaga County, who was indicted today on charges of sexual abuse and driving while intoxicated, pleaded not guilty and said he would decide next week on his official future.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Paul W. Ramsey, 71 years old, a long-time newsman and a retired State Department employee, died today at George Washington University Hospital after a long illness.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 15 After years of lagging efforts, the Government of India says that it is finally making some real progress in the battle to slow the rapid growth of population.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 15 The drought-starved Mississippi River, a major inland waterway, has ebbed to its lowest point in 20 years in the last month, spawning a rash of groundings, dangerous barge breakaways and costly delays just as the river moves into its period of heaviest traffic.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 15 A plan that would save $8.2 million a year by consolidating Fire Departments in 11 of the 12 municipalities in the county, was unveiled today by Hudson County Executive Edward F. Clark and Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City. This would be the first regionalization of services on a countywide basis in the state, the officials said at a news conference here today.

Charging "practices in violation of law" and an "unsafe and unsound condition," New York Superintendent of Banks John G. Heimann yesterday took over the American Bank and Trust Company, and arranged for it to be purchased by the Bank Leumi Trust Company, an Israeli concern.

LONDON, Sept. 15 Britons queued up at street hydrants today though it has been raining in many parts of the country for a week now. Little has been trickling into the nation's reservoirs, however, so the drought is still on.
The World Council of Synagogues, the umbrella organization for 2.5 million Jews who are members of the Conservative movement in Judaism, joined the World Zionist Organization yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 15 The most ambitious and audacious temple of culture ever erected in Paris, or perhaps anywhere, is nearing completion in the heart of the capital, amid rising controversy over its facade and facilities.
Justice Samuel A. Spiegel of State Supreme Court easily won the Democratic nomination in Tuesday's five-way primary for Manhattan surrogate.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 (AP) Guerrillas fired submachine guns and threw hand grenades today at the house of an Argentine executive of the Ford Motor Company, the police said.

The United States economy for 1977 was painted in largely rosy colors yesterday by economists and executives at a Conference Board meeting, with the only somber tones being references to the persistent presence of inflation and unemployment within an overall improving situation.
ALBANY, Sept. 15 Governor Carey today signed an executive order intended to provide more and better jobs in state government for women, blacks, other minorities and the disabled.

The trend toward lower interest rates, which was evident earlier this week in such disparate sectors of the credit markets as high grade bank holding company notes and triple A tax-exempt bonds, shifted yesterday to Government and Federal agency securities. The Treasury sold oneyear bills at the lowest rate since February 1975 and the the Farm Credit System sold short-term bonds at the lowest rates since April.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to enjoin a white family in suburban Philadelphia from trying to prevent a black couple from buying the house next door.

Debbie Reynolds, who opened last night at the Minskoff Theater in an act called "Debbie," has pep, energy and a certain amount of singing, dancing and comedic talent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) The average interest rate for new home mortgages in August climbed past the 9 percent level for the first time in 1976, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

TRENTON, Sept. 16 A decision by the State Pension Board to revoke the pension of former Gov. Robert B. Meyner won't cause him any any financial problems.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 16 Ships on the high seas are tending to pass up boatloads of refugees fleeing Indochina as nations in the area become more reluctant to grant them a haven.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 A controversial Ford Administration plan to bring private industry into the business of preparing natural uranium for use in atomic power reactors almost certainly will not be approved by Congress this year, according to Senators, staff members and energy lobbyists.
YAMPA, Colo., Sept. 12-The hardpressed cattlemen of the West have revived an old joke that has a special bite in this election year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Democrats are getting a little edgy about the Presidential election. The pros at the top of the party still feel that Governor Carter will hold most of the states in the Old Confederacy, and that they will carry enough of the Northern industrial states to win an electoral majority, but their voterregistration drive so far has been a disappointment.

Chemical Bank said yesterday it would introduce a discount securities service on a test basis for about 19,000 checking account customers in six mid-Manhattan offices. A mighty voice will be added this season to the popular Sunday Bach cantata series at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West at 65th Street. Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home operator whose activities focused public attention on corruption and neglect in care for the aged in New York City, ended months of legal wrangling yesterday and began serving a four-month Federal sentence for Medicaid and tax fraud.

The new New York State Lottery sold at least 18.9 million tickets in its first week of operation, more than twice as many tickets as any other state has ever sold in a week, John D. Quinn, the state director, announced yesterday.

Never have so few dollars spent been so richly rewarding.

SANS SOUCI means "carefree" (it was the name of Frederick the Great's 18th-century creampuff palace in Prussia), but what distinguishes the Sans Souci restaurant is caring on the part of the owners and staff. Dinner in the cream-and-gold dining rooms is delightful.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 18 Nothing will change much in Ohio State's style of play as long as Woody Hayes is the coach. The Buckeyes win with a grinding, plodding, powerful offense, a style evident today when they drove for two touchdowns without ever thinking of a pass. This enabled them to beat Penn State, 12-7, before a record crowd of 62,503 fans in Beaver Stadium and a regional television audience.

"I've been down in the water four or five times every day for the last three months and I've reached the point where the physical strain has become too much for me. Regularly, they write to newspapers to complain of nonexistent air-conditioning (or its failure), of broken seats and windows, of indescribable lavatories and of long, unexplained delays.

WASHINGTON The case Eugene J. McCarthy presents for himself as an independent candidate for President rests on a disarming but shaky syllogism: If current trends continue, Democrats and Republicans are likely to be outnumbered one of these days by voters who regard themselves as independents; Mr. McCarthy is the candidate of the independents; therefore, he is a serious candidate.

They finished building Teton Dam in southeastern Idaho during the winter of 1975. What, demanded the editor of the Musical Courier, was the character of this new project that was keeping Gershwin so busy. "American, of course, in the modern idiom," replied Gershwin, "but just the same a cross between 'Meistersinger' and 'Madame Butterfly." WASHINGTON, Sept.19 The International Monetary Fund warned the industrialized countries today that stimulative Government policies aimed at quickly reducing the present high levels of unemployment were unlikely to work.
The sequence of openings has been changed for the three plays of "A Texas Trilogy" by Preston Jones at the Broadhurst, it was announced by the producers, Robert Whitehead and Roger L. Stevens.

When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported last week that it had earned $1.01 billion in the third quarter ended Aug. 31 thus becoming the first publicly owned corporation in the nation ever to net $1 billion in a single three-month period competitors, consumer groups and Wall Street all sat up and took notice.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 19 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that after extensive talks with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia he was satisfied that the leader of the white-ruled regime would recommend to his aides that Rhodesia accept a plan for transition to black majority rule.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Mechanics and ground crew members returned to their jobs at Trans World Airlines today after tentative settlement of the day-old strike was announced.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 In South Africa last year, in a YMCA in Soweto, I saw a play written and directed by an African playwright, Gibson Kente. It was a musical called "How Long?" In the simplest terms of tragedy and faith it expressed the yearnings of South African blacks for such things as the chance for an education, the right to own a home, equality before the law.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) A home run by Jerry Morales and the seven-hit pitching of Ray Burris gave the Chicago Cubs a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today and prevented the Phillies from extending their lead over Pittsburgh in the National League East.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 19 The Panamanian Government today appeared to be reconsidering its charge that the United States was responsible for recent student riots here, but it stood by its claim that three American intelligence agents were detained while participating in the disturbances.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 19 (Reuters) A former Cypriot bishop who was defrocked for trying to oust Archbishop Makarios in 1973 died today while conducting an unauthorized mass in Limassol.
A publication that is unusual in the annals of bridge made its appearance this month. It is entitled Contest Bridge, and seems to be a compromise between a bride magazine and a state lottery.

PEKING, Sept. 19 (Reuters) China has completed the public funeral rites for Mao Tse-tung without disclosing what will happen to his body.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 19 Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn, for 10 years head of an authoritarian military government in Thailand, returned from exile today, the second major figure from his regime to re-enter the country in the last month.

The five-concert Isaac Stern and Friends chamber-music series came to a glorious conclusion yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Not all of these concerts may have been received with total rapture, but this one deserved to be.

Yoko Moroshita, the Japanese ballerina who was featured prominently in American Ballet Theater's summer season, introduced her regular partner from Japan to American audiences this weekend at Brooklyn College's new "Guest Artists Series in Dance." He is Tetsutaro Shimizu, a handsome young man with long hair and stylish vitality to his dancing. Miss Moroshita and Mr. Shimizu are the leading dancers of Tokyo's Matsuyama Ballet, directed by Mr. Shimizu's parents.

Arrests in New York City for felonies the most serious crimes increased by almost 6 percent in the first half of the year despite cuts in police manpower, according to Police Department statistics.

Despite an early show of strength resulting from prime-rate reductions by two major banks, the stock market closed mixed yesterday in slower trading.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Sept. 20 Senator Robert J. Dole dropped his accustomed tough, tail-gunner tone here today in an emotional moment before the physically handicapped people he called his "community."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Ford contended today that Jimmy Carter was proposing to increase Federal taxation of middle-income families at a time when "we should be going in the opposite direction."
TRENTON, Sept. 20 Enthusiasm at 8 o'clock on a Monday morning in downtown Trenton is a contradiction in terms.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 W. Averell Harriman, who is serving as a foreign policy adviser to Jimmy Carter, met for nearly three hours today with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in an effort to assuage anxieties about the impact of election-year speech-making on detente.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 20 Prime Minister Olof Palme's Social Democratic Cabinet resigned tonight after a decisive generalelection defeat that ended more than four decades of his party's rule in Sweden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 A controversial bill that would have given the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to set standards of competence and financial responsibility for investment advisers floundered today when the Senate, less than two weeks from its target adjournment date, failed to take it up.
The American Symphony Orchestra concert Sunday evening in Carnegie Hall wasn't an ordinary American Symphony Orchestra concert. The regular series begins Oct. 10.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 20 Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, followed Jimmy Carter today in a counterattack against the Republicans on the issue of taxes, charging that they have an "outrageous record" of opposing tax reform and favoring the wealthy.

For the first time in 12 years, the Democratic Presidential campaign in New York is being fully integrated with the Democratic state party and local Democratic campaigns for Congress and the legislature in a move that is likely to curb the squabbling that has characterized past presidential campaigns in the state.

SACRAMENTO, Calif. Unexpected opposition by the State of California to the delivery by tankers of Alaskan oil to a terminal near Los Angeles has forced Washington to reconsider basic assumptions concerning the long-awaited Alaska pipeline.

WESTBURY, L.I., SEPT. 20 Clifford Irving, who served 17 months in a Federal prison for conspiracy and fraud in connection with his bogus book about Howard Hughes, the late billionaire, has had more success as a "lawyer" than he did as a biographer.
VALETTA, Malta, Sept. 20 Prime Minister Dom Mintoff, who led this strategic island away from the Atlantic Alliance and toward nonalignment, has won re-election for another five-year term.

The smallest city in New York State won a victory yesterday against one of the biggest public utilities in the state when the Public Service Commission agreed to let Sherrill (population 3,000) set up its own power company. In the process, the utility, Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, is losing one of its largest customers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 The principal pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, shaken by government investigations, filed documents today with the Internal Revenue Service arguing that the fund is now in complete compliance with all requirements of law.

The General Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had authorized a spinoff of the capital stock of RKO General, a major affiliate with interests in radio, television, theaters and an airline.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 20 Jimmy Carter has said in an interview that he has "looked on a lot of women with lust" and that he has "committed adultery in my heart many times," but that "God forgives me for it."

LONDON In Clitheroe, a town in Lancashire, there is an unhappy Englishwoman who has been waiting since September 1957 for Britain's National Health Service to provide her with an orthopedic operation.

The trend toward lower interest rates faltered yesterday as the key Federal funds rate stayed close to 5 percent and bond traders seemed to become less convinced that the Federal Reserve would decide today to ease monetary policy.

Peter Brook's Paris-based experimental theater company, the International Center of Theater Research, is planning a two-month tour of American universities this fall with Mr. Brook's production of "The Ik,' an adaptation of Colin Turnbull's "The Mountain People."

The Chase Manhattan Corporation, which two years ago reported a $34 million securities trading overvaluation of the Chase Manhattan Bank, agreed yesterday to a Securities and Exchange Commission finding that the bank's controls at the time were inadequate.

Home health care is preferable to institutional care for many of the elderly and handicapped, but only if it is closely monitored, witnesses told a panel of officials of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare yesterday.
MARLBORO, N.Y. Picking her way cautiously through rocky vineyards and damp, pungent cellars, Lieut, Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak toured the Hudson Valley wine country Saturday.

ENGLEWOOD, Sept. 20 The bitter primary campaign between Representative Henry Helstoski of East Rutherford and Assemblyman Byron M. Baer of Englewood drew to an end tonight with the Ninth District's Democratic Congressional nomination to be decided in tomorrow's special election.
Arrests in New York City for felonies the most serious crimes increased by almost 6 percent in the first half of the year despite cuts in police manpower, according to Police Department statistics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Ford contended today that Jimmy Carter was proposing to increase Federal taxation of middle-income families at a time when "we should be going in the opposite direction."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Dr. Frank J. Rauscher Jr., director of the National Cancer Institute during its rapid expansion in the last four years, will leave about Nov. 1 to become senior vice president for research of the American Cancer Society.
THE CURSE: A CULTURAL HISTORY OF MENSTRUATION. By Janice Delaney, Mary Jane Lupton, and Emily Toth 276 pages, Dutton, $9.95.
LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP) Two British warships collided in the North Sea today and one capsized, killing two crewmen, the Defense Ministry announced. Ten men were listed as missing.

The chairman of the New York State Commission of Correction, Stephen J. Chinlund, yesterday called the state's parole system "a shambles" and "probation more of a shambles than parole." He said he was in favor of "scrapping the whole thing and starting over" because these programs did not stem recidivism.

The sky fell down on the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday at Shea Stadium. Seconds after Lee Mazzilli had belted a two-run homer with two out in the last of the ninth inning that lifted the Mets to a 5-4 victory, the Pirates seemed to have cement in their baseball shoes as they trudged off the field with their heads down, losers again to the Mets.

The voters of Sweden have ended 44 years of rule by the Social Democrats the longest tenure of uninterrupted power for any party in the world except for the Communists in the Soviet Union. The Scandinavian upheaval, not entirely unexpected, also retires to the opposition benches in the Riksdag the colorful, controversial Olof Palme, still only 49 after seven tumultuous years as Prime Minister.

John G. Heimann, the State Superintendent of Banks, will leave the Banking Department at the end of the month to become the state's top policymaker in housing, a key aide to Governor Carey said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Yields declined on Treasury bills today in the weekly sale in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

BONN, Sept. 20 In West Germany and elsewhere in Europe today the biggest political question appeared to be whether the defeat of Prime Minister Olof Palme in yesterday's elections in Sweden meant that the tide was running against Social Democrats on the Continent.

ISPARTA, Turkey, Sept. 20 (UPI) The pilot of an airliner that flew low over this village in southern Turkey and crashed into a mountainside, killing all 155 persons aboard, apparently thought he was flying at 13,000 feet, reports from the scene indicated today.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 20 And this was supposed to be the easy part of the Jets' schedule.

The stock of Dart Industries Inc. dropped 1 points closing at $36, yesterday after an announcement that Gary A. Childress, 42, had resigned as president of the company and as a member of its board of directors. Officials of the company, a diversified consumer goods manufacturer that markets Tupperware plastic containers and other products, declined to elaborate on the reasons for the resignation.

Kermit Bloomgarden, an accountant turned producer who brought to Broadway many distinguished plays, including "Death of a Salesman," "Look Homeward, Angel," "The Music Man" and "Equus," died yesterday at his home in New York City at the age of 71.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Ashlandn Oil Company cannot prevent the Federal Trade Commission from giving Congresss confidential information about its natural-gas holdings, a Federal appellate court ruled today. Ashland had argued against such disclosure on the grounds that the information might then become public.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 20 An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged in State Supreme Court today that Dominic Byrne, one of the alleged kidnappers of Samuel Bronfman 2d, the whisky heir, was not advised that a lawyer had been engaged to represent him before he confessed to the abduction.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn upheld yesterday a jury award of $2.5 million to Connie Francis, the singer, to compensate for her rape in a Long Island motel on Nov. 8, 1974.

DETROIT, Sept.20 Washington Boulevard, once the Fifth Avenue of Detroit, has become a somewhat lonely, desolate place in recent years. Many of its stores, known for offering the finest merchandise in town, have moved out or closed. It has lost its well-manicured look. And its sidewalks are no longer filled with pedestrians.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 The political corruption trial of Governor Marvin Mandel of Maryland and four accused co-conspirators finally began in Federal Court here today with a blistering prosecution statement charging the two-term Democratic Governor and his friends with secretly exploiting his power for their mutual enrichment and then lying to cover it up.

The next step in the advertising for the Empire Stakes, New York State's new and apparently successful lottery, will be to run newspaper ads showing the number of winners in various localities and maybe even listing their names.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz announced today an increase of 1 cent a gallon in Government milk supports, effective Oct. 1, but predicted it would have only "minimal" impact on consumer prices. Retail prices for most dairy products now are above the new support levels, Dr. Butz said in a statement.

Chinatown is one of the most crowded communities in New York. Staten Island is one of the least. Small Wonder, then, that to about 50 elderly former Chinatown residents a new adult home set in among the tall trees and Victorian houses of St. George, S.I., is a rather special place.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 Palestin ian, Syrian and rival Lebanese forces stepped up military operations today following the failure yesterday of cease-fire talks among their political leaders.

There was a certain American-as-apple-pie quality to President Ford's pronouncements on housing when he formally opened his election campaign in Ann Arbor last week. His pitch, indirectly, was to the young, middle-class family aspiring to buy a home.

"I don't even want my garbage going to Queens," a resident of Roosevelt Island in the East River heatedly told Mayor Beame yesterday as the Mayor opened a series of public hearings on his proposals for new community-district lines under terms of the revised New York City Charter.

Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, chancellor of the City University, has called for a budget increase next year of $18.4 million to overcome what he described as the "adverse educational effects" of the current "starvation" budget.

SASKATOON, Saskatchewan A year-long effort by the Canadian Government to nationalize partially the country's potash industry largely owned by United States interests is drawing sharp criticism on both sides of the border.

TRENTON, Sept. 20 Committees have been appointed from the New Jersey and New York Legislatures to study the causes of ocean pollution of the New York metropolitan area, and they expect to meet later this month to begin their investigation.

The Paul Taylor Dance Company, long one of the country's leading modern-dance troupes with an international reputation, has announced that it will disband "indefinitely" because of financial difficulties.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The delicate, divisive, complex and intensely personal subject of abortion has, somehow, exploded into the first major issue of the Presidential campaign.

A New York City bus driver, who the Transit Authority said was carrying a gun in apparent violation of the agency's regulations, shot and wounded a youth early yesterday, moments after the youth and two accomplices had refused to pay the fare and had stabbed the driver in the back, the police said.

Presidential candidates cannot afford and cannot be expected to reject the political support of all those who do not agree completely with them. And yet there are limits to the embraces of expediency. Even by the most relaxed standards of campaign promiscuity, former Governor Carter's Mississippi love feast with Senators James O. Eastland and John C. Stennis stretched the limits of political decency.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 20 (AP) Ken Stabler, Oakland Raider quarterback, using the forward pass like a surgical instrument, carved through the Kansas City defense for 224 yards and three touchdowns tonight, and the Raiders held off the Chiefs, 24-21.

Nearly two-third of Americans surveyed in a Gallup Poll believe that parents bear a major responsibility for the controversial test score decline in the country's schools because they have not provided enough attention, concern and supervision for their children.

Felix J. Aulisi, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice, died yesterday in Amsterdam, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 20 Senator Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic VicePresidential nominee, followed Jimmy Carter today in a counterattack against the Republicans on the issue of taxes, charging that they have an "outrageous record" of opposing tax reform and favoring the wealthy.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 20 Exploration of the north pole region of Mars, with its unexplained terracing and its clues to past Martian climate, is to begin Friday when the flight path of the Viking 2 orbiter is changed for that purpose.

Bridge books from England are nearly always of a high standard, and the new season's crop is no exception. The first of them is "Bridge Analysis" by Boris Schapiro, published here by Sterling. This is a 187 page hard-cover, moderately priced at $4.95 and available from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York.

HACKENSACK, Sept. 20 Bias again prevented the selection of a jury today in the murder trial of Joseph Kallinger. Judge Thomas F. Dalton of Superior Court questioned 52 prospective jurors. Forty-five told him they had unalterable opinions on the case as a result of pretrial publicity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The three commercial networks, all expressing some reservations about arrangements, said tonight that they would broadcast live on radio and television. Thursday night's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter.

HISTORY RE-VIEWED The exhibition "Pioneer Photographers of Brazil: 1840-1920" may well be an example of parallel but independent developments in technology. The oldest surviving daguerreotype in the Americas was made by a Father Compte, in Brazil in 1840. That was three months after announcement of the invention in Paris and earlier than any surviving daguerreotype in New York.

Domestic steel production for the week ended Sept. 18 took its largest drop of the year, falling 4.6 percent lower than in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 20 After a five-day hiatus, the United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company today resumed formal talks aimed at ending the nationwide U.A.W. strike against Ford that began at midnight last Tuesday.

Like the losing gambler who requests new cards or dice, the New York Rangers changed their uniform yesterday. It will be introduced Oct. 6, when they open the National Hockey League season against Minnesota at Madison Square Garden.

Based loosely on the World War II exploits of Marine Corps Maj. Gregory (Pappy) Boyington the series offers a glorification of drinking and brawling misfits.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 The Milwaukee Brewers gave the expiring Baltimore Orioles at least one extra day of life tonight and gave the Yankees additional time to ice their champagne.

Spurred by bitter primary contests in the South Bronx and in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, Black and Puerto Rican voters, often criticized for voting apathy, turned out in greater numbers proportionately in last week's Democratic primary than upstate voters, a survey of the primary returns showed yesterday.

By the nature of things, statistics on undiscovered scoring errors, like undiscovered murders, are not available. The vast majority of the errors that do come to light are no fault of the scorers, who maintain very high standards. Few players take the trouble to check their scores, a tedious operation, so it often needs an accident before the need to make a correction becomes known.

When a man sets out, ambitiously enough, to write a trilogy, final opinion must await the conclusion of this grand design. Last night at the Broadhurst Theater, we had the opening play of Preston Jones's "A Texas Trilogy," which will be given in repertory. The trilogy originated in Dallas and has caused considerable comment across the country.
Mr. Limb, the son of a Korean educator, was one of Dr. Syngman Rhee's closest aides in the long fight for Korean independence from Japan, which occupied his country in 1910.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Inflation held at a steady pace during August, as lower meat prices took some of the sting out of spurts in the cost of gasoline, clothing and medical care, the Government reported today.

EAST RUTHERFORD, Sept. 21 Everything was virtually in place today for the Giants-Dallas kickoff on Oct. 10 in the new Giants Stadium here. The 76,891 red and blue seats are waiting to accommodate the fans. The enclosed wall-towall-carpeted boxes are ready for occupancy at $16,000 a season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Federal Election Commission unveiled today a new computer system designed to keep voters informed on candidates' sources of campaign money and on political spending on a day-to-day basis.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 21 The 1976 Presidential contest is disrupting political patterns of 30 years' standing, and there is no better evidence of the changes than in the industrial states clustered around the Great Lakes.

TRENTON, SEPT. 21 Ann Klein, Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies, said today that voter approval of bond issues, that will be on the ballot in November would mean the renovation of hospital and prison facilities and the restoration of accreditation to Trenton State Hospital.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 21 (AP) Hal McRae and John Mayberry lashed successive run-scoring singles tonight as the Kansas City Royals defeated Oakland, 3-1, fattening their Lead over the A's in the American League West to seven games. Both teams have 11 games left, five with each other.

Representative Henry Helstoski of Rutherford, despite a Federal indictment, won renomination yesterday in a special Democratic primary election in New Jersey's Ninth Congressional District, defeating Assemblyman Byron M. Baer of of Englewood by a large margin.
Roy Boe, president of the Nets, took a hard line yesterday in refusing to renegotiate Julius Erving's contract, which has four years to run.

The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that employees of The New York Times Company represented by Typographical Union No. 6 are entitled to perform the work of preparing some advertising copy so that it can be handled by computer.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP) Bishop F. Gerald Ensley, resident bishop of the West Ohio area of the United Methodist Church, died today in Dublin. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The retirement dreams of millions of Americans could become nightmares unless Congress and the Internal Revenue Service act to help people make rational selections of Individual Retirement Accounts, a House subcommittee was told today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 Bill Rigney announced tonight that he would not manage the San Francisco Giants next year, but would remain in the organization in a position not yet defined.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The White House said today that President Ford did not need to be defended in connection with an inquiry into Republican fundraising in Michigan because "nobody has said there has been any wrongdoing" in the case.

The smoldering political situation in southern Africa is expected to be the dominant issue during the 13-week 31st General Assembly of the United Nations, which opened yesterday. Initiatives will also be taken to combat terrorism and to deal with the Arab-Israeli conflict.

The only thing that is rarer than a builder in New York today is one who, in the ordinary course of development, will of his own accord make the city a more beautiful or livable place. It has been the job of zoning to mandate amenities such as open space; most builders have become experts on how little can be done to make these spaces attractive or usable.
HACKENSACK, Sept 21 A jury of 10 men and six women, including four alternates, was empaneled today for the murder trial of Joseph Kallinger.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Federal program for monitoring the achievement of American schoolchildren has found, contrary to the beliefs of many educational critics, that reading ability has not deteriorated during the 1970's and that nine-year-olds, especially, have improved markedly.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 Jerry Koosman, the star New York Mets southpaw seeking his 21st victory of the season, was beaten tonight by a rival who had been able to win only one of nine decisions this campaign.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 21 The nationwide strike against the Ford Motor Company by more than 165,000 of its workers headed into its second week tonight, and despite a lengthy session at the "main table" between company negotiators and representatives of the United Automobile Workers, no measurable progress was made toward resolving the key issues that could end the walkout.

A City Council committee yesterday voted out a bill requiring not only that sidewalks in front of stores and residences be swept clean, but also that an additional 18 inches beyond the curb into the gutter be swept.
TETON VILLAGE, Wyo., Sept. 21 Gov. Calvin Rampton of Utah came to the annual meeting of the Western Governors' Conference here this week with a 15pound bronze cast in Salt Lake City.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 21 Secretary of the Navy J. William Middendorf 2d announced today a trophy to be awarded to the winner of the annual rowing regatta between the United States Naval Academy and Harvard University, starting next June.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) The closing price of gold in London today climbed $5.625 an ounce after a day of active trading to reach a nine-week high of $120 an ounce.
Thomas A. McGrath, a retired consumer finance industry executive, died Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 72 years old and a resident of Summit.

A small price rally in soybeans yesterday led to a large amount of selling on the Chicago Board of Trade, and by the end of the session contracts were 5 cents to 7 cents lower than the previous day. November beans closed at $6.48, down from $6.53 a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) The House voted today to outlaw betting on horse races taking place outside the state in which the bet was made. The measure would effectively end all offtrack betting on out-of-state races by 1982.

Some ten days ago, the Government of Chile revoked the citizenship of Orlando Letelier, who had been Ambassador to the United States and had held three Cabinet posts during the late President Salvador Allende's Popular Unity coalition. CRAFTY CURBS The Museum of Contemporary Crafts, which doesn't look a day over 15, is 20 years old and is kicking up its heels tonight all over the block on West 53d Street, where it is housed at No. 29. The street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas will be closed off from 8:30 P.M. to 10 P.M. Everyone's invited no charge.
TONBRIDGE, England, Sept. 20 (AP) Sir William Collins, head of a 157-year-old family company that is Britain's major publisher of the Bible, died at his home near here today. His age was 76.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The Federal program for monitoring the achievement of American schoolchildren has found, contrary to the beliefs of many educational critics, that reading ability has not deteriorated during the 1970's and that nine-year-olds, especially, have improved markedly.

"The contempt we have been taught to entertain for the blacks makes us fancy many things that are founded neither in reason nor in experience," Alexander Hamilton said nearly 200 years ago. That remains true, especially in very mistaken ideas about the slave family and the generations of poor black families since Emancipation, in 1865. Such myths inevitably affect how urban poverty is explained and policies to control or abolish it are defined.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Orlando Letelier, who was foreign minister in the Chilean government of President Salvador Allende Gossens, was killed here today when a bomb exploded in his car as it sped along fashionable Embassy Row.

Columbia's Tennis Center at Baker Field, where Dr. Renee Richards has been practicing frequently, is trying to raise $100,000 for its year-round program. In addition to improving the layout, the funds would help support the tennis team and Columbia's project to teach the game to community youngsters.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21 A detective testified today that he had not advised Dr. Charles E. Friedgood of his rights before removing the physician from a London-bound jetliner and searching him at Kennedy International Airport on July 25, 1975, a week after Dr. Friedgood had allegedly murdered his wife.

"I hit the first one good," the recently fired field-goal kicker was saying, "but they blocked it. The second one, a 39-yarder, curved to the right at the last minute. On the third one, the easy one, I was so tense I never had a chance."

CARACAS, Sept. 21 (AP) Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries favor an increase in oil prices next year, "but nothing has been said regarding the size of such an increase," Venezuela's Mines and Hydrocarbons Minister, Valentin Hernandez, said today.

The beleaguered Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation yesterday turned to Roy L. Ash, the former president of Litton Industries, and Cabinet member in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, and in a move that surprised Wall Street named him chairman and chief executive officer.

The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis Dillon, has agreed to allow Patrick J. Cunningham, the embattled Democratic leader, to plead guilty to a reduced charge of speeding rather than stand trial on a charge of driving while impaired by alcohol, Mr. Cunningham's lawyer, Michael P. Stafford, said last night.

Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak has unsuccessfully tried to talk Bella S. Abzug's likely successor in congress into stepping aside so that Mrs. Abzug could regain the Democratic nomination for her Manhattan-Bronx seat.

STEINKJER, Norway, Sept. 21 Amphibious tractors waddled ashore from Namsen Fjord and discharged shouting United States marines. Helicopters dumped a company of reserves from Kansas and Missouri onto high ground above the beachhead. Jets flew cover for the maneuver, being conducted by the Atlantic alliance.

Ingersoll-Rand faded like a spent compressor yesterday, adding to losses in the stock that followed word from its chairman on Monday that earnigs forecast earlier for 1976 now appeared unattainable.

After watching the televised reruns of the 1960 Kennedy-Nixon debates last week, I intend to look at the Carter-Ford debates with considerable skepticism, and some reserve with the hope of spotting any lies either candidate may float, and of hearing what the candidates actually say, rather than what I want to hear them say.

If Ken Norton is as successful against Muhammad Ali in their world heavyweight title fight next Tuesday night as he has been in training against his sparring partners, he might become the new champion.

The space shuttle's ceremonial, tractor-drawn jaunt out of its hangar at Palmdale, Calif., received attention last week. Of possibly greater significance was a little-publicized discussion nearly 2,000 miles away in Huntsville, Ala. At the Marshall Space Flight Center there, industry and Government space engineers discussed details of a supplementary solid-fuel rocket that would be attached to various payloads such as communications satellites and carried into orbit in the shuttle's 60foot-long cargo bay.

Three youths enter a bus, refuse to pay their fare and, when asked to leave the bus, stab the driver in the back. The driver, a former Transit Authority police officer, pulls out a revolver, fires several shots at the fleeing youths, wounding one of them.

S. Joseph Tankoos Jr., chairman of the Muss-Tankoos Corporation; founder and general partner of the Tankoos Company of New York, a realty investment concern, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital in Manhattan. He was 55 years old.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 21 (AP)-Gov. Philip W. Noel held a 100-vote lead over Richard Lorber, a wealthy car dealer, tonight in the week-long counting of ballots from a primary election to choose a Democratic nominee for the United States Senate.

Jack Ansell, a novelist and former director of special projects for the ABC television network, died Monday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 320 East 54th Street, in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 A SenateHouse conference committee failed today to reach agreement on a bill to reform the nation's scandal-ridden grain inspection system after intensive lobbying by Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz and his top assistant against a Senate compromise proposal.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 Playing the Chicago Cubs for 22 innings while chasing the Philadelphia Phillies and fighting a slump proved too much for the Pittsburgh Pirates to manage today. After beating the Cubs, 4-3, in the first game of a doubleheader at Wrigley Field, the Pirates dropped the second contest, 2-1, in 13 innings.
A small bomb exploded in a stairwell on the 24th floor of the New York Hilton Hotel last night, lightly damaging the walls of the stairwell but injuring no guests or employees.

A 20-point surge in the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday pushed the stock market to its highest level in almost four years. The performance, the best of 1976, came in the heaviest trading m almost six months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 President Ford announced today an increase of about 1.2 cents a pound in the duty on imported sugar as an interim measure to help alleviate the problems of domestic growers brought about by a collapse in the world sugar price.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 21 Ben C. Limb, a former South Korean Foreign Minister, died of a heart attack in, Seoul this morning. He was 83 years old.

Residents of Queens turned out in force yesterday to protest proposed new boundaries for police, sanitation and other municipal services as mandated by the revised New York City Charter.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 The chief defense counsel for Gov. Marvin Mandel, being tried here on charges of bribery and conspiracy involving a race track, asserted today that the two-term Democrat had saved Maryland taxpayers millions of dollars through his interest in consolidating the state's horseracing industry, one of the things he is changed with attempting to do for the benefit of wealthy friends.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Vice President Rockefeller pledged today to campaign for the re-election of a former antagonist, Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative-Republican of New York, and praised the Conservative Party as a constructive force in New York State politics.
Hudson D. Walker, art patron, art collector and art dealer, died Monday at Doctors Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

Premier Allan Blakeney of Saskatchewan pledged yesterday that adequate supplies and competitive prices would be maintained in that west Canadian province's $800 million potash industry where his moderately socialist government is in the process of taking over a 50 percent ownership.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) A federal grand jury today indicted former Representative James F. Hastings, Republican of New York, on charges of obtaining kickbacks from his staff to buy automobiles, boats and snowmobiles and to pay his children's college tuition.

WEST BERLIN Scores of artists from New York's SoHo are offering a rich and unusual feast for this city's 26th Fall Arts Festival and though the West Berliners pick at some unfamiliar morsels, they seem to be joyously intoxicated by the stimulating spirit of New York.
LONDON, Sept. 21 Britain cast a hopeful but skeptical eye today on reports from southern Africa that Rhodesia's white leadership was prepared to transfer power to the black majority.

Kissinger required cautious deliberation since it involved "the future of Rhodesia and the lives of our people."

Twelve-year-old bay horses are No. 1 on the Most Wanted List of the mounted unit of the New York City Police Department. Donna Jo Southeimer was married in New York yesterday afternoon to William R. Acquavella, art dealer and president of the Acquavella Galleries. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold Fraiman performed the ceremony in his chambers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Inflation held at a steady pace during August, as lower meat prices took some of the sting out of spurts in the cost of gasoline, clothing and medical care, the Government reported today.

The wages of workers in the Northeast are rising more slowly than the wages of workers in other parts of the country, and this is enhancing the competitiveness of the Northeast as a place to do business, a United States Department of Labor official reported yesterday.

The nation's retail merchants, who had expected a sharp increase in sales as they entered the normally hectic back-toschool season have been disappointed by a relatively sluggish sales trend.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Jimmy Carter's national economic proposals drew charges and countercharges from Republican and Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives today, with each side contending that the other was distorting the record.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 21-The Ford Motor Company said today that within the next two years it planned to market an engine that could switch from six to three cylinders and save at least 10 percent in fuel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)?The Navy has flown special search equipment to Scotland and will start hunting for an advanced F-14 fighter plane on the Atlantic Ocean floor as soon as weather permits, the Pentagon said today.

Senator Robert J. Dole, the only majorparty candidate for President or Vice President who has not made public his health record, underwent a physical examination yesterday at the Capitol medical office in Washington, according to his press secretary.

At 1600 hours yesterday (4 P.M. for you civilians) buglers stationed on each of the seven floors of the J. Walter Thompson Company began blaring "The Marine Corps Hymn" It was one way of telling the troops that the agency, which had handled all of the Marine Corps recruiting for the last 26 years, had once again won the account. The Corps is now spending $10 million annually.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The White House said today that President Ford did not need to be defended in connection with an inquiry into Republican fundraising in Michigan because "nobody has said there has been any wrongdoing" in the case.
In an effort to simplify the college admissions process, 83 private colleges, from Columbia and Princeton Universities to Colorado College, have agreed to recognize a new common application form.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Despite United States opposition, Vietnam won membership in the World Bank today. An American official said no other nation had voted against Hanoi.

Stewart R. Mott, the philanthropist, threw open that controversial multimillion-dollar quadruplex penthouse on East 57th Street for the first time last night at a party in honor of the National Committee for an Effective Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 The chairman of a House labor subcommittee said today that he was preparing legislation to place stringent limitations on the ability of a city pension fund to invest in the city it served.

Spurred by bitter primary contests in the South Bronx and in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, Black and Puerto Rican voters, often criticized for voting apathy, turned out in greater numbers proportionately in last week's Democratic primary than upstate voters, a survey of the primary returns showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Investors cashing in mutual-fund shares continued to exert a drag on the stock market last month, according to data published today by the Investment Company Institute, the industry's principal trade association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn told Congress today that the National League would expand because "it is inevitable," M. Donald Grant of the New York Mets agreed.
SANTON, Calif., Sept. 21 (AP) John Quinn, a general manager in the National League for 28 years, died at his home last night at the age of 68. He had been ill for some time.

Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak has unsuccessfully tried to talk Bella S. Abzug's likely successor in Congress into stepping aside so that Mrs. Abzug could regain the Democratic nomination for her Manhattan-Bronx seat.

CAIRO, Sept. 21 A two-day bus strike that tied up Cairo over the weekend has ended in violence and sabotage. The strike, described here as the biggest in Egyptian public utilities in 20 years, began Saturday and ended yesterday morning.
A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday indicted the hijackers on Sept. 10 of a Trans World Airlines jet, charging them with air piracy and causing the death of a New York City police officer.
WARSAW, Sept. 21 The Polish Communist Party's leadership has been severely shaken by its finding that it lost touch with public opinion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Leonard Ware, former newspaperman, Foreign Service officer and veteran of two world wars, died on Sunday at Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 76 years old.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 22 (AP) The Government has foiled a plot to overthrow President Suharto and install former Vice President Mohaad Hatta, one of the leaders of the Indonesian revolution against the Dutch, State Secretary Sudharmono announced today.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 22 The Viking II spacecraft has discovered that the permanent northern polar cap of Mars is composed entirely of frozen water, suggesting to scientists that the planet has much more water than had been expected.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 22 David Rabkin, one of 12 journalists arrested by the security police since the black unrest began in South Africa three months ago, pleaded guilty in a Cape Town court today to having written and distributed pamphlets on behalf of several banned organizations, including the African National Congress. He faces a mandatory jail sentence of at least five years.

Lord Taylor, the first big store to squirt perfume into the Fifth Avenue air, to support American designers and to name a woman (Dorothy Shaver) as its president, opened its 150th anniversary celebration last night with a party on its newly renovated main floor.

The New York Telephone Company charged yesterday that prisoners of the Metropolitan Correctional Center had made more than $100,000 in fraudulent long-distance calls from the Federal detention, facility since it opened in August 1975.

One of the few European tournaments at which the casual visitor can be sure of hobnobbing with the world's great players is the Melia Don Pepe Festival at Mazbella in Spain. This year's tournament, to be played Nov. 6 through Nov. 13, will attract Benito Garozzo, perhaps the world's greatest player, Omar Sharif, a star in bridge as well as another medium, and a party of American enthusiasts. (Information from Tannah Hirsch, 661-1918).

The New York Post agreed yesterday to turn over to the defense tape recordings of a Post reporter's interview with key prosecution witness in the murder trial of a member of a Black Muslim mosque in Harlem, according to sources familiar with the proceedings.

Senator James L. Buckley said yesterday that he favored a national healthinsurance plan that provided federally financed coverage only after medical costs exceeded a certain level, rather than the "extravagant" proposals put forward in the Democratic Party platform.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 Having used up one miracle in making up 12 games in three weeks on the first-place Philadelphia Phillies, the Pittsburgh Pirates found themselves in dire need of another today after they lost, 4-3, to the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Another piece of banking legislation that at one point had been expected to sail through Congress died today when the House Banking Commiatee decided not to press a bill to set up a $1 billion Federal bank to finance consumer cooperatives.
LONDON, Sept. 22 A British royal commission on environmental pollution urged today that further expansion of nuclear energy in Britain "be postponed as long as possible."
Jimmy Carter's earthy remarks to Playboy magazine on sexual morality and lust appear to be generating as much comment as anything else in the Presidential campaign so far.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The House ethics committee today rejected three proposals to punish Daniel Schorr, a CBS News correspondent, and ended its investigation into his unauthorized disclosure of a House intelligence committee report.
PLAINS, Ga., Sept. 22 Jimmy Carter secluded himself in his home here most of today, boning up for his debate tomorrow night in Philadelphia with President Ford.

BONN, Sept. 22 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is in trouble in the last days of the West German election campaign. His opponent, Helmut Kohl, is riding a wave of popularity with an old-fashioned, sentimental appeal to values that had almost gone out of style in recent years.

Demonstrators protesting a proposal for an amusement park on Staten Island sought unsuccessfully yesterday to present their case at a public hearing on new community-district boundaries in the borough, but their presence kept Mayor Beame from presiding at the hearing, as he had planned.

SEATTLE, Sept. 22 (AP) Dixy Lee Ray, former Atomic Energy Commission chairman, held a narrow lead today over Seattle Mayor Wes Uhlman in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Washington State.
Benjamin Graham, widely regarded as the founding father of modern securities analysis, died Tuesday at his home in Aixen-Provence, France. He was 82 years old.

MADERA, Calif., Sept. 22 Pretrial pleas and motions were postponed today in the Chowchilla kidnapping case in which three San Francisco area men are charged with the July 15 kidnapping of 26 young children and their school bus driver 19 miles northwest of here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 On Sept. 26, 1960, Richard M. Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy met in a stark CBS television studio in Chicago for history's first nationally televisied debate between Presidential candidates.
PANAMA, Sept. 22 Panama's strongman, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, is facing his most serious political crisis since seizing power here eight years ago.

Eight national and local consumer organizations today charged President Ford with 82 "counts" of anticonsumer behavior that they said had lowered American consumers' standard of living and endangered public health and safety.

MADRID, Sept. 22 The Spanish Cabinet's major military conservative was eased out in favor of a liberal today in a move by King Juan Carlos I and Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez to strengthen their program for democratic change.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)-Governor Carey of New York was quoted today as saying that he is sticking by his opposition to landing rights at John F. Kennedy Airport for the Concorde, the British-French supersonic jetliner.

DACCA, Bangladesh, Sept. 22 A 27year-old Dutch social worker and freelance journalist has been sentenced to 14 years in prison here, after a secret martial-law trial, on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government.

Durable Afro-American family organization developed in the United States in the century and a half preceding the Emancipation this despite the severe constraints imposed upon slaves, the frequent breakup of marriages and families by sale, and the absence of any legal protection for slave families.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 Some liberals who are uneasy about Jimmy Carter for one reason or another have taken to speaking of President Ford's "decency." That overworked word, covering a variety of rationalizations, has taken on a code significance, A California, Democrat said: "We don't really know Carter. And Ford's not so bad he's decent."

Mrs. Warren drew out in the stretch and beat Negotiator by 6 lengths in the $85,270 Matron Stakes for 2-yearold fillies at Belmont Park yesterday. Eddie Maple, who rode Mrs. Warren, brought home his fourth winner of the ...
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 The end of the Lebanese war is not in sight despite the scheduled inauguration tomorrow of a new President, Elias Sarkis.

The Bronx Democratic organization, led by Patrick J. Cunningham, suffered a major political setback yesterday when two candidates it backed for nominations for the State Supreme Court were defeated by the antiorganization New Democratic Coalition at the party's judicial convention for the First District (Manhattan and the Bronx.)

HARRISBURG. Pa., Sept. 22 After a review of Federal research on a mysterious disease that struck an American Legion convention in Philadelphia, the Pennsylvania health secretary believes the malady is probably new to modern medicine.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP) The two astronauts orbiting the earth in Soyuz 22 were preparing to return to the Soviet Union after a week in space, Tass announced today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 22 Although he hasn't played for a winning team since 1969, and his name doesn't appear among the league leaders these days, Joe Namath continued today to be the man the Jets look to for the winning edge.
A strong market rally was stopped dead in its tracks yesterday after the Government reported that durable-goods orders fell in August. Capital equipment stocks sagged as the hardest-hit sector.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Five manufacturers and 11 unions filed a petition with the United States International Trade Commission today seeking to curb rapidly growing imports of color television sets, mainly from Japan.
LONDON, Sept. 22 Following are excerpts from a report by the Royal Commission on Nuclear Energy dealing with nuclear energy, as made public by the Government today:

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 22-The Roman Catholc of Umtali, on trial on charges of having failed to report the presence of nationalist guerrillas, said today that missionaries faced a deep moral problem in deciding whether to act as informers.

NEWARK, Sept. 22 Bloomfield College and Seminary filed today a reorganization plan under the Federal bankruptcy laws that will keep the 108-year-old institution from closing. Creditors will receive partial payment.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 22 As the diplomats move toward a possible acceptance by Rhodesia's whites of a negotiated peace settlement, there is a striking absence here of either anxiety or enthusiasm.

PARIS, Sept. 22 Prime Minister Raymond Barre today announced a temporary freeze on prices as well as an increase in taxes on personal and corporate income, cars, gasoline and alcohol. The two moves were part of an anti inflation program submitted to the French Parliament.

BONN, Sept. 22 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is in trouble in the last days of the West German election campaign. His opponent, Helmut Kohl, is riding a wave of popularity with an old-fashioned, sentimental appeal to values that had almost gone out of style in recent years.
Although the House ethics committee dropped its case yesterday against Daniel Schorr, the CBS News correspondent's status with the network remained uncertain.

World sugar futures prices moved sharply lower and domestic prices rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exhange, reacting to the increased tariff placed by the United States Government on sugar imports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Administration officials sought to assure Congress today that the United States would closely monitor Taiwan's adherence to its newly declared policy renouncing any involvement with nuclear fuel reprocessing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 The world's less developed countries managed to maintain a "reasonably high" rate of economic growth during the global recession of 1974-75, the World Bank reported today.

Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that L. Edwin Smart would assume the posts of chairman and chief executive officer beginning Jan. 1, Mr. Smart, 52, who has served as vice chairman of the airline since last January, succeeds Charles C. Tillinghast Jr., who will retire Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 When the Presidential campaign began in earnest two weeks ago, Jimmy Carter was considered by most politicians a prohibitive favorite to defeat President Ford. This week, with roughly a quarter of the campaign gone, experts in both parties were calling the race a virtual toss-up.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) Second-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina edged Henry Bunis and fifth-seeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico breezed past Butch Walts in the second round of the $125,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis championships today.
Thomas B. Morgan resigned yesterday as editor of The Village Voice. He said he was leaving the weekly newspaper to start a national weekly magazine.

READING ROOM The Mercantile Library is a marvelously serene oasis at 17 East 47th Street in a neighborhood that teams with mercantile activity. The library association, a private membership organization, dates back to 1820, has been in its present building since 1932 and the quarters would be perhaps more at home in Mayfair than an mid-Manhattan. Among its members have been Ellen Glasgow, Willa Cather and Van Wyck Brooks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed today that, over the last three years, the number of American citizens and organizations under investigation because of their political ideologies has declined from 21,414 to 626, a drop of 97 percent.

The police said yesterday that although a Puerto Rican independence group had claimed responsibility for the small, powerful bomb that exploded at the New York Hilton on Tuesday night, they knew almost nothing about the organization and had "absolutely no leads" on the person or persons who had planted the bomb in a 24th-floor stairwell.
A small explosion shattered two glass doors at the entrance to the Paladium movie theater at 126 East 14th Street early this morning, slightly injuring a theater employee, the police reported.

Experts in television research are projecting an audience of 90 million viewers for all or part of tonight's debate between President Ford and Jimmy Carter, or close to 90 percent of all the households that are expected to be tuned to television.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 A HouseSenate conference committee broke a four-month stalemate today and reached agreement on a bill establishing a grain inspection service to combat fraud and corruption t hathas been exposed in a broad Federal investigation of the grain industry.
A number of people in Washington are engaging this morning in one of those periodic demonstrations of how not to govern the country.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 22 South Africa was reported today to have softened its stand on two key issues blocking a negotiated settlement of the SouthWest Africa dispute. The shift was said to have been communicated to Secretary of State Kissinger during his weekend talks with Prime Minister Vorster in Pretoria.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 22-A report recommending stringent measures to curb the growth and influence of Israel's Arab population was denounced today as "racist" by about 300 Israeli-Arab officials, who demanded the ouster of the Israeli official who had written the report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 President Ford is planning to devote most of his election resources to a concentrated campaign effort in New York, New Jersey and eight other battleground states, his political strategists said today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 22 By a voice vote that sounded unanimous, the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Convention today reversed itself and offered an alternative to "conditional ordination" for the 15 women "irregularly" ordained to the priesthood.

President Richard M. Nixon's landslide victory over Senator. George McGovern in 1972 was beyond a doubt, greatly aided by the Republicans' ability to portray the Democratic candidate's proposal of a $1,000 "demogrant" for all citizens as a radical and extreme costly scheme for shifting income to the poor in a way that would hurt not just the wealthy but also the great American middle class.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters) The House of Representatives tonight overwhelmingly approved legislation that would bar American firms from complying with the Arab trade boycott against Israel and would set stringent new standards for United States nuclear exports.

Some in Wall Street view this week's bid by International Telephone and Telegraph for Carbon Industries, a major coal producer, as the most recent manifestation of a developing trend whereby major industrial companies are getting control of energy resources while the getting is good.
The National Park Service yesterday disclosed a broadly based $300 million plan for the development over the next two decades of the 26,000-acre Gateway National Recreation Area.

MONTREAL, Sept. 22 With Lee Mazzilli continuing to be impressive at the plate and in the field and Jon Matlack matching his career best total in victories, the New York Mets turned back the Expos, 4-2, tonight.

Now that each of the eight Ivy football teams has a league game under its belt, the ancient group goes out against the world this week playing nonleague games. And it appears to be a hostile world out there.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 22 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger plans to meet in the United States with Sam Nujoma, the head of a leading South-West African nationalist group, to work out final details for a conference that would lead to independence for South-West Africa.
WASHINGTON, Sept.22 (AP) The dyes that make jelly beans black and maraschino cherries red were banned today for use in foods.

A dozen demonstrators who said they were from a group called Save Our Israel prevented a speech in the American Hotel last night by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey at a Citizens for Carter/Mondale Committee rally aimed at Jewish voters.

TRENTON, Sept. 22 Governor Byrne will nominate tomorrow the Assembly majority leader, George H. Barbour, Democrat of Maple Shade, to fill the long-standing vacancy on the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 For the League of Women Voters, the first debate between the Presidential candidates Thursday night will be the culmination of a long, quiet effort that originated in the Presidential campaign of 1952.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 With a flip of a coin in a backstage dressing room here today, it was determined that tomorrow night's television debate will start with a question directed to Jimmy Carter and end with a summing up by President Ford.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 The Assembly Republicans, whose current chances of winning back control of the Assembly are regarded by many politicians of both parties as slim, are lagging far behind the Democrats and the Senate Republicans in raising money for the November elections.

ATLANTA, Sept. 22 In the wake of scandal and bankruptcy in the $17 billion Medicaid program, Federal and state officials are working on reforms that would begin to move health care for the poor from the private, inflation-prone business sector into a regulated public utility.

LONDON, Sept. 22, (AP) Profit taking $2 an ounce to $118 in Zurich and $1.75 here to $118.25. It had risen $5 yesterday. The British pound fell to a low against major currencies and dragged the American dollar down with it.
Edgar J. Lorie, a designer of highfashion hats for more than 40 years, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived at 975 Park Avenue.
Hudson Strode, lecturer, writer, emeritus professor of English at the University of Alabama and author of a three-volume life of Jefferson Davis, died yesterday in Tuscaloosa, Ala., at the age of 83.

J. Manheimer Inc., a New York importer, recently received its order from Indonesia of 32 barrels of essential oils; the fragrant raw material used in perfumes and soaps. William Harness took the part of Alfredo in Verdi's "La Traviata" for the first time with the New York City Opera in the performance given at the New York State Theater Wednesday night. The only other newcomer to the cast was Margaret Goodman, who was Annina for the first time.

The nation's basic money supply, in a sudden upsurge that caught Wall Street by surprise, soared by a record $4.5 billion in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.
