MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 23 The actions of hundreds of Catskill Mountain area residents who are becoming ordained ministers to protest vague, undefined taxexemption laws may prod state legislators into correcting inequities in real-property tax legislation, according to some state and county officials.

All over town last night, eerie blue glares could be seen in the windows of apartment buildings, brownstones and bars a good indication that New Yorkers were watching the Carter-Ford debate. Or, if not that, the YankeesOrioles baseball game.

The firehouse at 104 Duane Street looks like most others in New York City, but the first thing that strikes the eye is an old open car, painted bright red, bearing a sign that identifies it as a 1920 Ford, a deputy chief's car.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 23 (Reuters) Zambia and Angola have brought their uneasy relations closer to normalization with an agreement to exchange ambassadors and to establish a joint commission to sort out their problems.

The New York State Health Commissioner, Dr. Robert P. Whalen, announced yesterday that he had decided to hold up the issuance of an operating certificate for the city's new North Central Bronx Hospital until he had received assurances that its expenses would be met and that its patients would receive quality care. He also expressed doubt that the hospital was needed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Count Astorre Oddi-Baglioni, managing director of Istituto Mobiliare Italiano in Rome, a governmental credit institution, and his wife were among the passengers killed in a Turkish Airlines plane that crashed on Sunday.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 23 After nearly four months of military occupation in more than half of Lebanon, Syria appears to be achieving some of the goals of the intervention. But many of Syria's objectives in Lebanon still pose serious problems for the rule of President Hafez al-Assad.
David M.Levitan, a jeweler in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died of a heart attack in the subway Wednesday. He was 88 years old and lied in Far Rockaway, Queens.

Edward P.Call, a former newspaperman and president since 1973 of Will, Folsom Smith, fund-raising consultants, of 19 West 44th Street in Manhattan, died Wednesday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center. He was 70 years old and had homes in White Plains and Bay Palm, Fla.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Traces of the toxic industrial chemicals called PCB's have been found in 78 samples of American mothers' milk, but the significance of this is not known, scientists said today.

Many of the state's new instant-lottery tickets, both winning and losing tickets, are duplicates, the lottery's director, John O. Quinn, said last night. However, he said such duplication had no effect on the game and did not increase the likelihood of ticket-counterfeiting.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 23 Joseph Kallinger's attorney said today in his opening statement today that his client was "totally crazy" and that psychiatrists would testify that he did not know right from wrong on Jan. 8, 1975, when, according to the charge in the case, he killed Maria Fasching, a 21-year-old nurse, in Leonia, N.J.
Wilson H. Coates, professor emeritus of history at the University of Rochester, died yesterday at Genesee Hospital in that city. He was 77 years old.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 23 School-tax rates in Nassau County for this year went up an average of 79 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation about $58 for an average house the Nassau County Board of Assessors said today.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP) William and Emily Harris, the radical couple who joined Patricia Hearst in a crosscountry fugitive flight, pleaded not guilty today to charges that they had kidnapped the young heiress.

The New York City Transit Authority has served notice of its intention to cancel Social Security coverage two years from now for 45,000 subway and bus employees. The action brought an immediate and angry denunciation from the Transport Workers Union.

Secretary of the Treasury William E.Simon broke with precedent yesterday and awarded the Treasury's highest honor, the Alexander Hamilton award, to Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

The new, stringently conservative accounting standards applied to New York City's financial records show that the city's accumulated budget deficit is $5 billion almost twice the $2.6 billion figure arrived at by fiscal experts last year.
The decline in new orders for factory and industrial equipment continued to weigh upon the stock market yesterday and sent prices lower across a broad front.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 23 The results of another biology experiment on the Viking 2 lander have been radioed to earth, but they left scientists just as uncertain as ever on the question of whether there is life on Mars.

CHTAURA, Lebanon, Sept. 23 Elias Sarkis, a 52-year-old banker, was inaugurated today as the sixth President of Lebanon under the protection of the Syrian Army and some Lebanese soldiers. He called upon all sides to strive for peace in the Lebanese civil war, which began a year and a half ago.
A woman conductor has a hard enough time of it in a field dominated by men, but if she happens to be Chinese she has a double problem.

The flowers of spring are already formed inside the stored food tissue of bulbs. But unless the gardener earnestly begins to set his bulbs into the ground this weekend or soon after, he may never realize the fragrant promise of hyacinths, daffodils and tulips next March, April or May.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 Pittsburgh Pirate fans could have been excused if they put their hands over their eyes today. For the fourth sucessive game it was the bottom of the ninth with the score tied. This time it was Wrigley Field, the Chicago Cubs were threatening and the fading Pirates looked as if they were going to lose the sixth of their last seven games.

THE TEATRO ALLA SCALA could not come to New York and stage opera. But at least it sent emissaries. Last night in Carnegie Hall the Scala Orchestra and Chorus, conducted by Claudio Abbado, with eminent soloists, performed the Verdi Requiem. Presidential debate or no Presidential debate, the hall was sold out.

THE PARIS of the 1920's and the literary generation that sojourned there have acquired an almost legendary aura, like Cam elot. And keeping the coals glowing have been the many memoirs of the sojourners, from Malcolm Cowley's classic "Exile's Return" to the recently published "The Very Rich Hours of Adrienne Monnier" by Richard McDougall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The number of violent crimes reported by the nation's police departments dropped somewhat during the first six months of 1976 as against the same period last year, but theft and other crimes against property were up, according to figures compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and released today.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 23 Neal Walk still prefers an avocado to a steak, he is still the Knicks' bearded vegetarian, but that's where the old Walk and his old "let it be" philosophy appear to end.

This week's record $4.5 billion rise in the nation's basic money supply, considerably larger than most bond traders expected, caused bond prices to drop sharply late yesterday afternoon. Prices had declined moderately in the morning

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23 Sam Nujoma, the leader of the South-West African People's Organization, flew home to Africa today after insisting that his group would not soften its terms for negotiating with South Africa on independence for the territory.

Carol Jane Greenhouse, a research analyst at the Bureau of Social Science Research in Washington, was married last evening to Alfred C. Aman Jr., an associate in the Washington office of the Atlanta law firm of Sutherland, Asbill Brennan.
UNIONDALE, L.I., Sept. 23 The only doctor in attendance here today as the New York Nets prepared for the opening of their training camp was Dr. Allan Levy, the team physician.
Investors in companies that own hospitals were recently disappointed when Congress decided not to sweeten a tax measure under which hospitals are built with the proceeds of tax-exempt bonds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Partly as a result of the prodding of Senator Sam Nunn, a relatively junior member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, the Army is reassessing its strategic assumptions and contingency plans for warfare in central Europe.
GUSTAV MAHLER has been a lively figure at the center of our orchestral repertory for some 15 years now, thanks largely to the recordings by Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.

Communicating with stockholders can be expensive, especially for small companies. As a result, at least three companies recently have made offers to buy out their small stockholders, thereby reducing their shareowner list.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) Susan Saxe and the jurors who will decide her fate on armed robbery and murder charges took a tour today of the bank she is accused of helping rob six years ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 23 (Reuters) Official results from the Swedish general election, released today, give the victorious non-Socialist bloc 180 seats in the new Parliament, with 169 for the outgoing Social Democrats and the Communists, their unofficial legislative partners.
Nine people were appointed yesterday to the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, the new agency to investigate complaints against judges.

Mayor Beame's proposals for dividing New York into 52 new community districts in accordance with charter changes adopted last November have, predictably, generated some vigorous protests at hearings in the five boroughs this week.

WASHINGTON On most Monday and Wednesday nights, Dr. W. Delano Meriwether leaves his seventh floor office at 200 Independence Avenue at about 7:30, drives his 1968 Ford to a neighborhood high school athletic field and changes from a suit to a sweatsuit while still in his parked car.

THE INTERNATIONAL Center of Photography, which opened a busy program of exhibitions, lectures and workshops only two seasons ago in the elegant old Audubon mansion at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 94th Street, inaugurates its third season today with three exhibitions honoring three venerable figures of 20th-century photographic history Andreas Feininger, Karl Struss and Theresa Bonney.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 23 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said tonight he would broadcast "a clear, positive and unequivocal statement" tomorrow giving his Government's response to the proposals for a transfer of power to the black majority presented to him five days ago by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

HACKENSACK, Sept. 23 Joseph Kallinger's attorney said today in his opening statement today that his client was "totally crazy" and that psychiatrists would testify that he did not know right from wrong on Jan. 8, 1975, when, according to the charge in the case, he killed Maria Fasching, a 21-year-old nurse, in Leonia.

IRVINE, Calif., Sept. 23 More than 2,000 families gathered in a parking lot near here Sunday, and a lot of them prayed for luck. Luck blessed 82 of the families: their names were drawn from a steel drum, and this meant they could buy one of 82 new townhouses that were for sale that day.
NEWCASTLE-UPON-TYNE, England, Sept. 23 (UPI) A fire aboard Britain's newest guided missile destroyer, the Glasgow, killed at least eight men and injured four today.
Eva Le Gallienne received the Handel Medallion, the city's highest cultural tribute, in a ceremony last night in the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

"The Golden Triangle" is a 52-minute, no-nonsense, French-made documentary arguing persuasively that the opium trade that produces 80 percent of the heroin from Southeast Asia is not a police problem, but a political problem.

JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 23 South Africa ended decades of segregation in sports today with an official announcement that the Government would sanction multiracial games at all levels and mixed racial teams in international competition.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (AP) A key prosecution witness acknowledged today that he was under pressure to testify against Gov. Marvin Mandel and four codefendants but insisted that he had made no deal to have prosecutors drop possible criminal charges against him.

Mathematics is central to every aspect of modern civilization from space navigation to the formulation of business strategy in the corporate world. Yet so highly abstract is the nature of most modern mathematical research that only on rare occasions is some major advance achieved whose nature is comprehensible to non-mathematicians.

Barbara Preminger, an actress who may currently be seen soaking her hands in Palmolive Dishwashing Liquid on the Madge the Manicurist television commercials, longs to get her feet wet on a Broadway stage.

Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader, and Frank G. Rossetti, his Manhattan counterpart, appeared yesterday to be safe in their leaderships for some time despite their defeat by the antiorganization New Democratic Coalition in contests for party Supreme Court nominations.

A spokesman for the New York City's Department of Traffic said yesterday that parking-enforcement agents who did not issue a specific minimum number of tickets each day faced the possibility of fines.

TRUMBULL, Neb., Sept. 23 More than a score of farmers shuffled about in the morning chill today outside the Harmon grain elevator in this hamlet southeast of Grand Island, alternately questioning and politically scolding Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) Former Postmaster General W. Marvin Watson pleaded guilty today to helping Armand Hammer, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, cover up illegal campaign contributions.

Miller, the former West Virginia coal miner who was elevated four years ago to the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America, opened here today a miner union convention that he did not want and that may adopt positions he will not like and perhaps cannot survive.

IT IS A GOOD SEASON in the galleries that begins with a show that would be worthy of one room in a major museum. Shows of this sort have a point to make, don't go on too long and touch in a worthwhile way on the nerve of the times.

Donald H. Bryan, vice president of the Mobay Chemical Corporation and general manager of its polyurethane division, both in Pittsburgh, died Tuesday at his home in Sewickley, Pa. He was 48 years old.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange declined less than 1 percent from Aug. 13 to Sept. 15, the exchange announced this week. The latest total was 22,671,494, down 138,213 shares.

"Branded for Life" is an attempt to make a critique of modern Brazilian society through a story of three young drifters. One is a small-time thug, the second a prostitute and the third a street urchin, a girl just past puberty. They meet, move into the same apartment, take up a three-way sexual relationship, and undertake a series of amateurish stickups, with dismal results.

THE GLORIOUS COLORS and curious shapes of 19th-century American whisky, medicine, perfume and poison bottles are attracting thousands of collectors today, bottle buffs who have formed more than 500 clubs where they share their enthusiasm and their bottles, too.

Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, is "in excellent health with only the residuals" of extensive World War II injuries, the attending physician of Congress said on the basis of a physical examination conducted Tuesday.

Fossil bones found on Canada's Arctic Ellesmere Island have led two American scientists to offer them as evidence to confirm the theory that North America and Europe were linked by a land bridge and shared the same animal species until 45 to 48 million years ago.

Eugene A.Schmidt Jr., who retired in 1969 as senior vice president and treasurer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company died Tuesday in his home, 55 Grosvenor Road, Short Hills, N.J. He was 72 years old.

MIAMI, Sept. 23 (UPI) A group of businessmen led by Charles G. Rebozo and Robert Abplanalp, both confidants of former President Richard M.Nixon, have lost a legal battle to liberalize zoning on a portion of Key Biscayne.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 23 A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that statements taken from Dominic P. Byrne and Mel Patrick Lynch, alleged kidnappers of the Seagram heir Samuel Bronfman 2d, might be used by the prosecution in next month's trial.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) The State Department said today that the inauguration of Elias Sarkis as President of Lebanon presented an opportunity to end the civil war there and rebuild the country's shattered structure.

Bagley, commission chairman, disclosed today.

TRENTON, Sept. 24 The State Department of Health will be authorized to close industrial plants that pose a threat to their employees by emitting cancer-causing substances, under legislation proposed by a special state commission studying cancer in the state.

WASHINGTON The first thing to be said about the Morris Louis exhibition at the National Gallery of Art (through Jan. 9) is this: it is a very beautiful show. The eye is ravished by an experience of color that, though subtle in design and carefully calculated in effect, is nonetheless simple, fresh and direct. There is nothing "hidden" or mysterious in these paintings, and nothing metaphysical in our experience of them.

Politics in New Jersey, rarely simple or polite, becomes particularly lively and unfathomable in the Ninth Congressional District, for this is the arena of Representative Henry Helstoski, a controversial and unorthodox individual who practices survival techniques with astonishing success. In May 1974, a scant month after the Consolidated Edison Company omitted its quarterly dividend on common stock, the lights appeared to dim for the various bond issues of the New York-based utility. Bonito and albacore also are productive off shore, while fluke are along the jetties and beaches.

WASHINGTON--The once-powerful Watergate special prosecutor's office is now a handful of caretaker lawyers tucked away in a shabby set of offices that used to house part of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's intelligence division. Nobody really expected to hear from the prosecutor or his staff again.

Not long ago a commercial for Inglenook wine that pretends to depict a joyous moment in a fiction writer's life was widely broadcast on network TV. Skillfully and expensively produced, it may well succeed in selling Inglenook, but in its revelation of writers and what they are about, it is illogical and strangely troubling.

DENVER, Sept. 25 (AP)--Lewis Oehmig of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., played par golf today and defeated John Richardson, 4 and 3, in the United States Golf Association seniors' championship at Cherry Hills Country Club. BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 (AP) W. Dale Hess, a co-defendant in the political corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, began making regular payments to a person identified as "M.M." in mid-1972. Mr. Hess's accountant testified today.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 28 A South Korean poet known for his satirization of President Park Chung Hee's Government asked for a new panel of judges today on the ground that he was not receiving a fair hearing.

TRENTON, Sept, 28 This fall's election ballot in New Jersey will be completed at 4 P.M. tomorrow. That is the deadline for filing for three legislative vacancies created this week when members of the Assembly and State Senate resigned to take other posts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 A Congressional move to block the sale of aircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia collapsed today in the face of a warning by Secretary of State Kissinger that such an action could undermine Administration policy in the Middle East.

Athlone Industries, a diversified company that sprang from the ashes of the old Holland Furnace Company, has been buying its own shares aggressively for some time and has stepped up purchases this week on the continuing theory that at current prices the stock is a bargain.

TRIPOLI, Libya Life in Libya is like the Bible Belt in Oklahoma very puritanical, according to the Ivey family.

That's the controversial ballot initiative to insure fair labor practices in California's strife-riddled agricultural areas.

Jimmy Carter and President Ford have been asked to reschedule their final television debate, set for Oct. 22, as well as the Oct. 15 discussion between their two running mates to avoid conflict with the Jewish Sabbath and a religious holiday.

THE 14TH NEW YORK Film Festival opens tonight with a Francois Truffaut, closes Oct. 17 with an Eric Rohmer, and in between has some films by directors that even the aficionados, or, as they say around the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the hard core, have never even heard of. This is part of the fun.

The Great Danbury State Fair opens tomorrow for its 107th year, a little bigger, a mite louder and unashamedly gaudier than ever before.

AIN TURA, Lebanon, Sept. 30 The Vanguard of the Lebanese Arab Army, formed four months ago and generally ignored as another military splinter unit in this land of many armies, began to emerge today as the nucleus of the new national armed forces that Syria apparently wants established in Lebanon.

TRENTON, Sept. 30 Governor Byrne's nomination of State Senator Stephen B. Wiley as a New Jersey Supreme Court justice was rejected today by Judge George Y. Schoch of Superior Court on the ground that the nomination violated the State Constitution.
HERSHEY. Pa., Sept. 30--The Pennsylvania Secretary of Health announced today steps to broaden the search for the cause of a mysterious disease that killed 29 persons in July and August.
The latest Gallup Poll on the Presidential contest shows that Jimmy Carter's lead over President Ford has been reduced from 18 percentage points to 8.

A spokesman for Richard M. Nixon said Wednesday that a published report about details of the former President's memoirs was "false."
A businessman and an accountant have pleaded guilty to charges of submitting false financial statements to obtain $3 million in bank loans for a Manhattan jewelry company that later went bankrupt.

MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS, once a desolate outpost on the northern fringe of the city, is now the home of an impressive concentration of cultural and educational institutions. The Heights area, which stretches from 110th to 122d Streets, between Riverside and Morningside Parks, includes the city's oldest university, the largest Gothic cathedral in the world, two seminaries and a music school.

For nine years Manuel Rivas has lived in a tenement that he owns at 459 East 135th Street in the Bronx. CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (UPI) Frank Robinson, the player-manager of the Cleveland Indians, confirmed tonight the ball club had offered him a oneyear, $80,000 contract to return only as a manager in the 1977 season.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Sept. 30 George Mark Appleyard of this Bergen County community is the youngest of 30,000 composers and lyricists registered with Broadcast Music Inc. He has just turned 6.

IT WAS only last year that Jerzy Maksymiuk took over the Polish National Radio Symphony Orchestra, a group founded in 1934. He and his ensemble played last night in Carnegie Hall, and the young conductor lost no time establishing his credentials as a virtuoso conductor who has podium athletics that leave even Leonard Bernstein gasping for air.

Harold P. Goodbody, a name out of Wall Street as it was a decade ago, was found guilty yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange of filing false financial reports about the former brokerage firm bearing his name and of failing to supervise the operations of the investment house.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 President Ford said today that he had never diverted any campaign funds for personal use and expressed confidence that the current investigation by the Watergate special prosecutor would show him to be "free of any allegations."

Dr. Berman is an apostate physician who has served on the faculty of Johns Hopkins, was president of MEDICO and doctored with Tom Dooley and Albert Schweitzer.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP)--Bernard Cornfeld, the millionaire financier, was sentenced today to three months in jail and fined $3,000 for his conviction on charges of defrauding the Pacific Telephone Company.

Robert Byrne the former United States chess champion, was named yesterday to head the six-man American team to the 22d International Chess Olympiad, which is set to begin Oct. 24 in Haifa, Israel.

Worker participation in management decisions has been popular in Europe for many years. "It could be American business' next big challenge, along with demand for greater job security," according to John Diebold, chairman of the Diebold Group, a management-consulting firm.

Larkin, disagreed before a House subcommittee today about proposed legislation to give the American Telephone aad Telegraph Company new monopoly powers and immunity from antitrust laws.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1--Syrian and Lebanese Christian forces today resumed their offensive against the Palestinian guerrillas, seeking to drive them out of a mountain area directly overlooking Beirut.

Kings Point, ranked ninth in Division III football, defeated Fordham, 30-7, last night at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx before an estimated crowd of 1,100.

Rees, it was a realization that he had spent too many years waiting fin the sidelines saying, "Hey coach. Send me in."

John V. Stram, an industrial designer with I.B.M. in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was in the Herman Miller showroom on Madison Avenue shortly after its doors opened yesterday morning. He had already sat on and approved of the new modular sealing designed by Ray Wilkes, which the concern is introducing.

Police Officer Joseph Campagnola asked his children yesterday morning whether they wanted to go to school or join him and his wife on the picket line around City Hall. The three schoolage children eagerly chose the picket line. Two-year-old Gina Marie came along too.

BEAUNE, France, Sept. 26--The vats are filled and fermenting now in the Burgundy wineries, and a quiet head of excitement is building up as the vintners prepare to drain the juice of the 1976 harvest into barrels for the second fermentation.

United States Customs Service officers demanded yesterday that the Japanese film "In the Realm of the Senses," which was scheduled to be shown tonight at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, be removed from the program and turned over to its New York division of import compliance as allegedly obscene.

UMTALI, Rhodesia, Oct. 1--The Roman Catholic Bishop of this border region was sentenced to ten years in prison today on charges that he failed to report the whereabouts of guerrillas who had demanded medicine at a church mission.

TRENTON, Oct. 1--A Senate commission studying the high incidence of cancer in New Jersey was told today that chemical manufacturing was not the major cause of cancer in the state, and that it was time to end "scare tactics" that charged that living here could be unhealthy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--President Ford and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko held extensive talks today on the deadlocked negotiations on strategicarms limitation but apparently failed to bridge the remaining differences.

LISBON, Oct. 1--Portugal's Socialist Government moved today to curb Communist influence in trade unions and to restore order to labor-management relations as a means of reviving the country's failing economy.

This occurred, perhaps, about the time of the 1828 Presidential election, when the last of our great diplomats in the White House lost to a Tennessee frontiersman, horse racer, gambler and Indian fighter who derided diplomacy as mere gabble and glorified military action.

Until recently, corporate executives were hesitant to open their morning paper for fear of finding a large ad announcing an attempt to take over their company. A recent wave of state legislation has now afforded them the opportunity to seek protection from such unfriendly tender offers from state attorneys general. These new statutes are known as state take-over or anti-merger statutes.

THE fall run of striped bass, one of the top game fish in New Jersey waters, is under way, with the bass chasing schools of mullet along the shoreline from Sandy Hook to Bradley Beach. Oct. 2 After having the passing and running game almost completely shut down by Stanford in the first half today, Army, directed by Leamon Hall, came back and upset the Cardinals, 21-20. President Ford and Jimmy Carter are tied in their race for the Presidency, according to a survey completed late last week by the research firm of Yankelovich, Skelley White for Time magazine. The survey indicates that each candidate has the support of 43 percent of the electorate, with 14 percent undecided.

WASHINGTON More than any other institution of Government, Congress, and what happens in it, is shaped by the interplay of personalities. After the official record of bills and resolutions and debates and votes has been entered in the appropriate annals, among the enduring impressions of the 94th Congress, which finished its work last week, will be those of individuals, ones who arrived and ones who departed, ones who succeeded and ones who failed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Leon Greenberg, a former president of the Monticello Raceway, (N.Y.) lost a bid, today for Supreme Court review of his conviction for conspiracy and mail fraud stemming from what the Government said was a scheme to defraud the raceway.

KC and the Sunshine Band are representative of two phenomena in popular music. One is the tendency of the music to self-correct, reverting to simple, danceable good times whenever things get too pretentious. The other is the apparently greater ease with which white practitioners of black music (or, in this case, white bandleaders in basically black bands) attain and sustain national success than black artists.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 Farmers in the pivotal grain and livestock states of the Midwest, who usually vote Republican, were not surprised today when the Secretary of Agriculture, Earl L. Butz resigned, and many thought President Ford had no alternative but to accept the resignation.

Steve Braun withdrew from the freeagent draft and signed a 1976 contract with the Minnesota Twins Sunday night, just before he would have ended his six years with the team. It reduced the draft pool to 28 players.
MOSCOW A group of visiting American publishers has responded coolly to a Soviet invitation to exhibit their works at a new international book fair to be held in Moscow next September.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) President Ford today signed a wide-ranging tax revision bill that eases the tax burden for individuals and businesses.

ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 4 (UPI) The bumper stickers read "For the Sake of Islip Town . . . Keep Supervisior Cohalan." Islip Town Supervisor Peter Cohalan might normally regard the stickers, despite the bad spelling, as a compliment to his administration, but he took an opposite view today since he is the Republican-Conservative candidate for Repre- sentative from Suffolk County's Second Congressional District.

A conservative tide was running in West Germany but it was not powerful enough in Sunday's election to dislodge Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and his coalition of Social and Free Democrats. In his first campaign at the Federal level, Helmut Kohl, Governor of the Rhineland Palatinate, led the Christian Union opposition back to its old position as the country's leading political force but finished about two percentage points behind the Government tandem.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 4 Syria accelerated its campaign of criticism of the leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization today, but also indicated that it was still prepared to negotiate a settlement of the Lebanese crisis with the P.L.O.
Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, two United States Government networks that broadcast to Soviet-bloc countries, were formally merged last week to form a new corporation, RFE/RL Inc.

Dr. Gabriel F. Cucolo, director of surgery and medical education at the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home at 110 84th Street in the Bay Ridge section. He was 58 years old.

Boyle, the deposed head of the United Mine Workers Union, has agreed to head a new Congressional examination of the assassinations of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Jean Bradford bought a winter coat last week in less than five minutes. What's more, in the course of six hours, she bought two suits, four pants ensembles, a dress, skirt, blouse, several sweaters, a suede vest, a scarf and a handbag, all the purchases she will need for her winter wardrobe.

When New Times magazine identified Earl Butz as the source of some crude and racist remarks, a White House spokesman announced that President Ford had reprimanded his Secretary of Agriculture severely. When the storm grew, Mr. Ford became totally inaccessible to the press.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 4 New Jersey gets a football team this week. That team will get a new defensive back this week. Neither development is expected to have much effect on the National Football League standings this season.

A group of interns and residents, demanding reinstatement as bargaining agent for hospital staff physicians, pressed forward with plans for a strike against four voluntary hospitals at 7 A.M. today despite last-minute defections by the resident staffs at six other voluntary institutions.

Negotiators for the paperhandlers' union and The New York Times and The Daily News met into the early hours today in an effort to complete a new contract for both papers and to settle manning problems at the new plant of The Times in Carlstadt N.J.

President Ford and Jimmy Carter have replied to two lists of questions on their policies and programs submitted by American physicists and engineers. The answers, while laden with campaign rhetoric, point up their differing viewpoints.

New and simplified regulations for fresh and salt-water fishing are being proposed by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, a concept, if wisely carried out, that will gladden the hearts of anglers.

Dr. Alfred E. Emerson, an international authority on the classification and social behavior of termites, died Sunday of a heart attack at Glens Falls (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Huletts Landing on Lake George.

The partners in the Arabian American 0il Company, the most highly valued oil operation in the world, are expected to complete arrangements for the Saudi Arabian Government's 10 percent takeover of the company's producing assets and concessions at a meeting in Europe next Monday. The actual announcement of the agreement is expected to be made subsequently from Saudi Arabia.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 4 Indonesia has begun an investigation to determine whether a local export company may have defrauded American and European importers of more than $l million on sales of essential oils.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 President James Mancham of the Seychelles says he is happy that his Indian Ocean republic has joined the world organization even though the costs are high for his nation of 60,000 and his delegation was bombed out of its New York hotel by explosives intended for another target.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (AP) The dollar fluctuated against European currencies today, gaining against the mark and the Swiss franc the two strongest continental currencies and easing against others.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 (UPI) Stafford L. Lambert, an aviation pioneer, died yesterday in a hospital in Woodruff, Wis., after suffering a heart attack at his summer home near Minocqua, Wis.

Col. Oliver J. Troster, a leader of the over-the-counter securities trading business, died last Saturday at Champaign, Ill., at the age of 82. Col. Troster, who was a member of the University of Illinois Foundation, the school's fund-raising body, was in Champaign for a meeting of that group.

MANILA, Tuesday, Oct. 5 Secretary of the Treasury William E. In a nonviolent protest against court delays and bail provisions, more than 350 inmates awaiting trial at the Queens House of Detention in Kew Gardens refused to be locked in their cells last night.

On Sunday, Oct. 17, the second game of the 1976 World Series will be played at night, the first time a weekend World Series game has been scheduled for what television people call "prime time." SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 Bells clang, wheels rumble, the cable car careens around a corner, tilts over the top of a hill and down the other side. Passengers shriek, the driver prays and San Francisco's most archaic, expensive and dangerous form of transportation is on its way.

California's Gov. Edmund Brown Jr. has signed into law the nation's first "right to die" measure. It provides that a patient who has made his desire known previously under a so-called "living will" may have life-support equipment, such as respirators, shut off if his death is "imminent." The new law protects doctors who act in accordance with such instructions, and it deprives insurance companies of the right to treat such a death as "suicide."

TRENTON, Oct. 4 A river basin from which American privateers preyed on British shipping during the Revolutionary War has been made a state historic district.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) Hundreds of thousands of letters from Congressmen seeking re-election are being mailed to voters at public expense.

The American Paper Institute estimated yesterday that additions to paper and paperboard capacity in the three years through 1977 would total 4.6 million tons, which would increase total capacity to 72.9 million tons.
A sudden sharp drop in arrests' has eased the problem of long delays before arraignment in New York City's criminal courts, judges and law enforcement officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Earl L. Butz, who resigned yesterday as Secretary of Agriculture, will keep a still undetermined number of his campaign commitments, with his next appearance now planned for this Friday night in Mississippi.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 John Holmes, one of the aides who lived with Howard R. Hughes before the eccentric industrialist's death on April 5, will be questioned tomorrow as lawyers seek to discover evidence to be used in the trial over the validity of a will attributed to Mr. Hughes.

Radioactive fallout from the Chinese nuclear blast 10 days ago has swept across the Pacific Ocean and been detected in eastern Pennsylvania, New Jersey, South Carolina and New York State, including unusually high readings in parts of Long Island and upstate, the Federal Energy Research and Development Administration reported yesterday.

ROLLING MEADOWS, Ill., Oct. 6, (AP) The shopping list read like a sultan's ransom. Fittingly, the Sultan of Oman was doing the $1.5 million in shopping and paying the $194,500 to charter a Boeing 747 cargo jet to get the goods home.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 6 (UPI) A 24year-old guard at the Nassau County Jail pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanon charge of conspiracy to sell marijuana.

MANILA, Oct. 6 More than 400 families have been forcibly evicted and their houses have been demolished in and around the Tondo slum area of this city, one of the worst such areas in Asia and, at the same time, the scene of a major urban renewal project of the World Bank.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged J. Pay McDermott Company and six of its officers with paying $509,000 in kickbacks to a former vice chairman of the Tenneco Oil Company for his help in obtaining business for McDermott, a New Orleans-based supplier of oilfield equipment.

HOUSTON, Oct. 6 They once served as America's lifeline across the North Atlantic, dodging German submarines to carry vital war supplies to the Allies in Europe. Now, the last of the nation's World War II Liberty Ships are quietly being buried at sea.

PORT NEWARK, Oct. 6 "I can give statistics and superlatives, but what says it all is that we are landlords for Ports Newark and Elizabeth," Derwood Hall said as he watched a ship unload pumice from Mediterranean islands one recent morning.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, Oct. 7 Thailand's military seized power last night within hours after policemen and university students fought violent battles in which 30 persons were believed killed and hundreds wounded. More than 1,700 students were arrested.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) The maximum interest rate on Small Business Administration guaranteed loans was lowered to 10 percent from 10 percent, the S.B.A. announced today.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 6 (AP) Charles Roger Albright, a pioneer in the field of visual education, died today at a Burlington convalescent home after a brief illness. He was 85 years old.

Abel Baer, a composer of such popular songs as "There Are Such Things" and "My Mother's Eyes" died Tuesday at his home, 90 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

New York City's much-criticized daycare program has been wasting more than $37 million a year because centers are underused, children are too frequently absent and staffs are required to have too many employees with overly high qualifications, a state audit contended yseterday.

The terse refusal by the Supreme Court to reconsider its earlier decision upholding the constitutionality of the death penalty for murder comes as no surprise. At the time of last July's ruling, the Court indicated that it intended to sanction capital punishment as long as its administration by state courts could not be assailed as random or unfair in nature.

Taking advantage of a section of the Federal Communications Act, Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative-Republican of New York, is forcing WNET-TV and seven other public educational television stations in the state to run political commercials for the first time.

Yonkers' sale of $83.6 million in bonds this week offers another hopeful sign of progress in Governor Carey's fight to restore the fiscal integrity of state government and bankruptcy-threatened municipalities notably Yonkers and New York City through tightly enforced fiscal controls. WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 From the easternmost promontory of Maine to the western tip of Guam, Americans are being urged to roll up their sleeves this month for the swine flu vaccine.

Luxuriously decorated with rough white plaster walls, tomatopink upholstered banquettes, tile inlaid tables and polychromed wooden wall sconces and frames, this Continental style coffee house is an offspring of Orsini's restaurant on 56th Street.

James H. Last week, a Manhattan seamstress, Mary Bray, won $100 simply for doing what she does almost every day going to the supermarket. A challenge by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to a proposal by the Cannon Mills Company to purchase Cannon shares owned by Gulf and Western Industries has been welcomed by at least one small shareholder.

The tantalizing title of Jack Gelber's new play is "Jack Gelber's New Play: Rehearsal." It is a play within a play. In it, actors are rehearsing a play about prison, in which the actor playing "the author" is persuaded to act as a convict, a character who is raped by a fellow inmate, and who, metaphorically, is raped by the "system." To complicate the metaphor, the reallife director is Mr. Gelber himself.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 8 The murder trial of Dr. Charles E. Friedgood began today with the prosecutor characterizing him as a man consumed by lust and greed who had killed his wife with a massive infection of Demerol.
Francesca Paolozzi was married to Carlos Padilla here yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Carol Anderson.
LISBON, Oct. 8 President Ford's statement that democracy in Portugal was a foreign-policy "success" for the United States stirred general resentment among the Portuguese today.

PEKING, Oct. 8 China announced tonight that the body of Mao Tse-tung would be placed in a crystal sarcophagus, and displayed in a mausoleum to be constructed in Peking.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 8 The puffs of smoke mounting from his thick pipe are a measure of the intensity of Ivor Richard's concentration. The harder he is thinking, the faster they come.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 8 (Reuters) Sweden's new Prime Minister, Thorbjorn Falldin, presented to Parliament today a 20member Cabinet including five women and delivered a policy speech that abandoned his election-campaign insistence on halting the spread of nuclear power plants.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 The Soviet Union and Angola signed a friendship treaty today that provided for "cooperation in the military field."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The United States has decided to end its refusal of months to take part in Cabinet-level Soviet-American commissions and has proposed to Moscow that a Joint Commerce Commission convene in Washington in two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 After three weary days of intensive campaigning from Iowa to Florida, Senator Walter F. Mondale came home early today to begin getting ready for next week's debate a lot of reading, a lot of discussion with staff and experts, and maybe a little tennis.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 8-- At 1:56 P.M., Tom Mullen took a small step for Giant-kind and moved on to green AstroTurf at Giants Stadium.

LISBON, Oct. 8 Portugal announced today a 60 percent surcharge tax on luxury and superfluous goods in a move to reduce consumption and restrict imports. This was part of a series of austerity measures taken to try to reduce the country's balance of payments deficit. "The country is spending abroad more than what we earn; this situation cannot continue," Antonio Sousa Gomes, Minister of Planning and Economic Coordination, said today at a news conference.

The Mahler Month continued last night in Carnegie Hall with James Levine using the services of two singers. For the first half of the program, Maria Ewing made her debut with the New York Philharmonic in selections from "Des Knaben Wunderhorn" and the "Ruckert" Songs. Then, for the last movement of the Fourth Symphony, the popular Judith Blegen sang the soprano solo.

In its November issue last year, Esquire magazine published a profile of Richard N. Goodwin, author and former Presidential aide, entitled "The Second Tricky Dick." Mr. Goodwin threatened to sue, and as part of the subsequent out-ofcourt settlement, Esquire will print an unusual rebuttal by the late founding editor Arnold Gingrich in its forthcoming issue.
Sunday store openings, begun by major retailers Aug. 29 and joined by additional retailers since, have helped sales in New York City and the metropolitan area.

Rain or no rain, Proud Delta probably will go to the post at Belmont Park today in the first running of the $132,375 Ruffian Stakes. According to Peter Howe, her trainer, the 4-year-old filly "just doesn't like mud." On that kind of track, Proud Delta feels insecure. But Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott, in whose Montpelier colors the filly races, apparently has decided the ill-fated Ruffian deserves the best memorial salute possible.
Steamboat Bills and Belles are gathering today for a blast a rare Hudson River "fall foliage cruise" all the way to Albany with a return trip tomorrow.

MADRID, Oct. 8 The Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez tonight approved a draft bill to legalize independent trade unions but at the same time decreed limitations on wage raises that are expected to provoke working-class opposition.

More than 200 guards from Rikers Island forced rebellious inmates at the Bronx House of Detention back into their cells yesterday following weeks of intermittent protests over allegedly high bails and long trial delays in the court system and visiting rights at the jails.

The 5,000 rightists who in a Madrid manifestation this week demanded the ouster of the Government and military rule in Spain have dramatized the intractable political problem confronting King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez Gonzalez.

Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, formerly the third-highest official in the government of El Salvador, was convicted in Manhattan yesterday of participating in a bizarre conspiracy to sell 10,000 submachine guns to undercover agents posing as gangsters.

The college football season has apparently been dedicated to the principle that the mighty will eventually get their come-uppance. Never have so many big ones of the recent past been felled by so many of the formerly downtrodden teams.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The national unemployment rate eased a trifle in September, but there was no fundamental change in the employment-unemployment picture, the Labor Department reported today.

After 33 years in which he was unable to marry his francee and companion, Prince Bertil of Sweden, the bachelor uncle of King Carl XVI Gustaf, will now be able to take as his bride Lillian Craig, an Englishwoman, in December, the royal court in Stockholm announced yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8 The Yankees, the glamour team of the American League past, and the Kansas City Royals, the most successful of the American League's expansion clubs, concluded preparations today for tomorrow's start of the league's newlook playoff.
Meyer Machlis, a lawyer who emigrated to Israel 40 years ago died Wednesday at his home in Petach Tikva. He was 72 years old.

Three brief years of freely elected government in Thailand, brought about by a student revolt against military rule, have now come to a sad end. The return of former strongman Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn, followed by a bloody crackdown on student protests, provided the pretext the military sought, evidently since January, to terminate Thailand's first wobbly experiment in democracy. Southeast Asia and the world are poorer for it.

ALL paint experts agree that whether you are painting only part of the trim or the entire house, the most important part of any outside paint job is the preparatory work. PARIS Even at midnight, the temperature seems tropical inside the ancient, stuffy Joinville Studios where Alain Resnais is shooting "Providence," his first movie in English. DETROIT The import boom appears to be over. Sales of imported cars, which reached a peak of 18.4 percent of the American market last year, are down to 14.4 percent for the first eight months of this year-the sharpest decline since the steady climb of import sales in the early 1960's. Louis La Russo's new play "Wheelbarrow Closers," which opened at the Bijou Theater last night, is a melodrama about the death of a salesman who has no particular wish to die. It is crudely written, obviously plotted, but has a certain raw strength. But not enough.

MINISINK FORD, N.Y., Oct. 11 Shaking with exhaustion and shivering with cold after capsizing in the icy Delaware River rapids, a two-man canoe team from Michigan today was the first to cross the finish line here in the first of what is hoped to be a major annual professional whitewater race.
ROME, Oct. 11 Three Palestinians protesting Syrian intervention in Lebanon shot their way into the Syrian Embassy here today, took five hostages, then surrendered to the police after two hours.

HACKENSACK, Oct. 11 When the jury begins deliberations in the Joseph Kallinger murder case tomorrow, it will have psychiatric tesitmony to consider that varies greatly from the psychiatric testimony studied last year by a Pennsylvania jury that convicted the Philadelphia cobbler of robbery.

LOS ANGELES Oct. 11 An amazing performance by the San Francisco 49er defense, which held the Los Angeles Rams scoreless at home for the first time in 27 years, produced an upset 16-0 victory tonight, which put the 49er in first place in the National Football Conference's Western Division.

Domestic steel production for the week ended Saturday fell to its lowest level since the second week of this year. the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11-In a country where the Government is formally atheist and the church has frequently been persecuted, the inauguration of a new Basilica of Guadalupe here tomorrow is evidence of the continued strength of Catholicism and, in particular, of the cult of the Virgin Mary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 The Government has found itself unable to spend money this year as rapidly as it had planned, and many economists are beginning to think that this "shortfall" in Federal spending is one of the main reasons why the economic recovery shows signs of weakening.

George L. Clark Jr., the Brooklyn Republican leader, plans to be fishing at Breezy Point today when President Ford makes three campaign stops in Brooklyn, the President's first campaigning in New York State.

Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau shocked Canadians recently with his pessimistic view of the country's future.
